gold_sents: The plaintiffs filed a lawsuit on March 8, 2014, alleging that the City of Montgomery, Alabama, improperly imprisoned them for failing to pay traffic fines.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they did not have an ability to pay the fines due to their financial circumstances and that the city did not consider their ability to pay.[SENTMARKER]On May 1, 2014, the District Court granted the plaintiffs motion for a preliminary injunction, preventing the city from collecting more money from traffic tickets of plaintiffs'.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2014 the parties filed to dismiss the case pursuant to a settlement agreement, which included numerous changes to Municipal Court proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In October 2018, a plaintiff sued Denver over its bond fee requirement.[SENTMARKER]Within a few months, the defendants changed their policy and submitted an Offer of Judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2018, a Denver resident was arrested for alleged violations of municipal ordinances.[SENTMARKER]When a judge sets a monetary bond, Denver will release the defendant upon payment of that bond only if the defendant also pays a $50 bond fee in order to be released.[SENTMARKER]The defendant, who was unable to pay the bond fee, was detained in jail for five days solely because he could not pay a $50 fee.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered his release upon his payment of $10 and his submission to GPS monitoring.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, 2018, Denver sent this debt to collections.[SENTMARKER]On September 20, 2018, Denver had 34 people detained on a bond of $100 or less, one on a mere $10 bond.[SENTMARKER]On December 13, 2018, the court entered a judgment in favor of the defendant in the total amount of $30,000, which included all reasonable recoverable costs and reasonable attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: On May 22, 2012, several national and local news agencies filed a § 1983 lawsuit against the state of Idaho, alleging that the policy of the Idaho Department of Correction to prohibit public viewing of the preparatory phase of the execution process, during which the inmate is restrained and the IV is inserted, violates the First Amendment right to free speech and the Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on June 5, 2012, but the Ninth Circuit reversed the denial, on June 8, in time for the injunction to apply to the scheduled execution of Richard Leavitt.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, the District Court entered a permanent injunction ordering the Idaho Department of Corrections to modify their execution procedures to allow witnesses to the execution throughout the entire execution process.

gold_sents: In 2016, prisoners that had completed their sentences but remained incarcerated by the Illinois Department of Corrections filed this class action against the state in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Illinois statutory scheme governing mandatory supervised release (MSR) for sex offenders and the requirement for offenders to have an approved “host site” in order to be released from custody violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded the plaintiffs summary judgment on the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction on January 15, 2020,  requiring IDOC to present a plan for releasing class members from custody, and quarterly reports outlining steps that were being taken to ensure that all class members would be properly released by January 2, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court's supervision of IDOC's progress is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2017, a class of homeless sex offenders filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Illinois against the Attorney General of Illinois and the Director of the Illinois Department Of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by denying them the right to live in compliance with the terms of mandatory supervised release (MSR) by imposing unmeetable restrictions on where they can live.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on three grounds, including that the plaintiffs were indigent and homeless.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on two of the four grounds, and the case was dismissed on the third.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit reversed the lower court's decision in favor of the defendants on the fourth ground.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 21, 2015, a private plaintiff sued the City of Dodge City, Kansas and Ford County in a civil rights action arising under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Dodge City's wealth-based post-arrest detention scheme violated the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, and a declaration that the City's wealth-based detention practices were unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle that the City would be enjoined from holding an arrestee in custody after a non-warrant arrest on the basis of inability to post bond.[SENTMARKER]The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the injunction but the case otherwise appears closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2004, a Dodge City resident and a family member filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Kansas, alleging that the city's policy of refusing to release arrestees from jail unless they pay a generic and arbitrary "bond" amount violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for entry of a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff, and the Plaintiff and Ford County filed a joint motion to enforce the final judgment.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the City to release all individuals arrested (for non-warrant arrests) in the City for violation of municipal ordinances of the City on Own Recognizance Bonds ("OR Bonds") without further conditions of release as soon as practical after booking and will not require individuals to post any type of monetary bond pursuant to an established schedule for the alleged offense.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the Plaintiff’s claims for damages, costs, and attorney fees with prejudice, and his request for class certification was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, prisoners in the Kentucky Clark County Jail filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, alleging that the state did not afford adequate procedural right prior to unlawfully charging inmates a fee for their incarceration without an order from the sentencing court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment, permanent injunction of the practice, and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss and dismissed all claims alleged in the complaint with prejudice, and all pending motions were denied moot.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the plaintiffs appealed but the appeals court affirmed the judgment of the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 26, 2013, a man was arrested and admitted to the Clark County detention center.[SENTMARKER]After being released from the jail, he received a written demand from the Jail to pay more than $4,000.00 in fees relating to his incarceration in the Jail.[SENTMARKER]The following day, he filed a class action lawsuit against the jail and the jailer, Frank Doyle, alleging that the jailers violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Kentucky Constitution by charging him for the costs of his incarceration without an order of a sentencing court.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the federal claim with prejudice, and dismissed the state claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit affirmed the district court's decision on appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: This 2017 class lawsuit was brought by two residents of East Baton Rouge Parish in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, in charging fees in addition to bail to be released from prison before trial, the defendant RHI had violated federal and state anti-racketeering law, their Due Process and Equal Protection rights, and the right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a private settlement, and the case was dismissed on February 20, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2018, a group of individuals arrested for criminal offenses filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the East Louisiana Parish Sheriff's Office, Rehabilitation Home, Incarcerated, and the Prison for violating the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs sought monetary relief from Defendants' extortionate and unconstitutional pretrial supervision practices, which violated the state and federally-protected rights of the Class members.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Sheriff violated their constitutional rights by jailing them until they were able to pay RHI's initial fee, engaging in a pretrial supervision scheme that allowed RHI, under Cleve Dunn's direction, to extort additional fees and costs from the proposed Class by wrongfully threatening future jail time and court sanctions for nonpayment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for partial dismissal of the case in February 2019, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, indigent former criminal defendants filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants had a practice of imprisoning individuals who had failed to pay court debts without meaningfully determining whether the individuals had the ability to pay the debt.[SENTMARKER]In August 2018, granted plaintiffs’ motion for class certification, and held that the Judges’ policy/practice of not inquiring into the ability of the persons falling within the certified class to pay before they are imprisoned for non-payment of court debts was unconstitutional, and that the Judges’ failure to provide a neutral forum for determination of such persons’ ability to pay was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the lower court on August 23, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendants petitioned the Fifth Circuit to rehear the case en banc on September 6, 2019, but the court denied to rehear on September 30.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a petition for writ of certiorari in the U.S. Supreme Court on December 20, 2019.[SENTMARKER]Cert was denied on March 3, 2020.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 18, 2020, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana on behalf of a group of pre-trial detainees in the Orleans Parish criminal district court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the Roderick and Solange MacArthur Justice Center and Civil Rights Corps, alleged that the defendants violated the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution by setting conditions of release for people who are arrested and charged with certain crimes in Orleans Parish.[SENTMARKER]The defendants created and applied a scheme of post-arrest detention and release procedures that requires presumptively innocent arrestees to pay a bond to a commercial surety to secure their release.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2020, Governor Jon Bel Edwards signed Act 110 of the 2020 session of the Louisiana Legislature.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the defendants' motion to dismiss with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2019, the plaintiffs filed an emergency petition for writ of habeas corpus, which was denied without reason.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the plaintiffs' petition for review on November 1, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In response to the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, Congress passed the CARES Act, which created, among other things, the “Paycheck Protection Program.”[SENTMARKER]Under this program, small business owners could apply for a loan from the Small Business Administration; if they later certified that all of the loan funds had been used for qualifying expenses, the loan would be forgiven.[SENTMARKER]The SBA’s rules disqualified many small business owners with criminal records.[SENTMARKER]Several small business owners brought this lawsuit against the SBA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, challenging this criminal record exclusion.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, the court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the SBA to extend the application deadline for the named plaintiffs from June 30 to July 21, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The following week, Congress passed follow-up legislation extending the deadline for all applicants to August 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of July 29, 2020, further developments in the litigation are pending.

gold_sents: On May 27, 2015, a person jailed by the City of St. Ann, Missouri (the City), for failing to pay the fee required under the City's secured bail system, sued the City in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, arguing that the City had violated the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and asking for declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, attorneys' fees, and costs.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the Judge assigned to the case, Judge Rodney W. Sippel, granted a stay in the proceedings to allow the parties to test the effects of a provisional settlement agreement, under which plaintiff agreed to drop his non-equitable claims, and under which the City agreed to end its secured bail policy and pay the plaintiff a $10,000 fee for acting as a class representative.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2018, a Consent Agreement was signed by Judge Sippel, whereby most of the original relief sought was agreed to by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The Court retains jurisdiction for two years, which may be extended for one more year upon agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2015, a homeless man filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Eastern district of Missouri on behalf of a class of impoverished arrestees who were held in jail because they could not afford to pay a generically set bond amount.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in August 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: The City will not hold an arrestee in its custody for another municipality on charges prosecuted in a municipal court for more than 10 hours; the City will notify all arrestees in writing upon release of the time, date, and place at which they are required to appear in court, if any; and the Plaintiff will be required to pay the sum of $10,000 as a class representative fee.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2016, the District Court granted the parties' motion for entry of a stay in this matter for up to a period of one year.[SENTMARKER]On September 2019, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the motion, and the parties entered a final judgment in August 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to negotiate a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is expected to be entered in January 2020.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2016, a group of individuals who were placed in jail because of an inability to pay fines, penalties, and other charges filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued thirteen St. Louis County municipalities under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and § 2201.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by ArchCity Defenders and private counsel, asked the court for declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In their complaint, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendant municipalities engaged in a deliberate and coordinated conspiracy to fill their coffers by extorting money from thousands of poor, disproportionately African-American people in the St. Louis region.[SENTMARKER]On April 24, 2017, the case was dismissed as to all defendant municipalities except the City of St. Ann.[SENTMARKER]The case (including mediation efforts) is ongoing against the City.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 24, 2014, a group of inmates filed a class action lawsuit against the City of St Ann, Velda village Hills, and Beverly Hills in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants kept hundreds of people in their jails for non-payment in each of the past five years.[SENTMARKER]The defendants failed to provide inmates access to a shower, limited inmates’ use of phones, and did not allow inmates to shower until they had been at the jail for a week.[SENTMARKER]In August 31, 2013, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that they were deprived of their right to a fair trial.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In June 2017, a man awaiting criminal trial and Lexington National Insurance Corporation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the Criminal Justice Reform Act violated the bail provision of the Eighth Amendment, due process under the Fourteenth Amendment, and freedom from unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment because the act favored non-monetary pre-trial release conditions over bail.[SENTMARKER]After and appeal to the Third Circuit regarding denial of preliminary injunction and a subsequent denial of certiorari in the Supreme Court, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 14, 2017, a New Jersey criminal defendant filed a class action suit in the District Court for New Jersey against the Attorney General, the District Attorney's Office, and the Camden County Prosecutor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that New Jersey's criminal justice reform law violated his Fourth Amendment rights by imposing severe restrictions on his pretrial liberty without offering him the opportunity to be released on monetary bail.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction and granted his request for a hearing to determine probable cause for further detention.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for an injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendants have filed a motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: Persons in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) brought this class action against DOCS and the New York State Division of Parole (DOP) for the extra-judicial imposition of sentences requiring post-release supervision.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was denied by the District Court, and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion for summary judgment was granted with respect to several defendants, but denied on the issue of qualified immunity; and plaintiffs' cross motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of liability for three officers was granted.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the qualified immunity decision, but the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendants moved for summary judgment again, but that motion was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently scheduled for trial in Summer 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 1, 2011, the Legal Aid Society of New York filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the New York on behalf of a group of individuals who had been sentenced to post-release supervision (PRS) in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Civil Rights Act of 1871.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the grounds that because plaintiffs’ constitutional rights were not clearly established at the time that those rights were allegedly violated, state officials were entitled to qualified immunity for their actions.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was remanded to the district court for a determination of whether the plaintiffs had timely filed their petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]The court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction because they had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Second Circuit and the defendants appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit held that the defendants’ practice of administratively adding a term of PRS to sentences in which PRS had not been No. 152836cv 1 Earley was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that this practice violated clearly established Supreme Court precedent.[SENTMARKER]The Court remanded the case to the District Court to determine whether the defendants had a chance to seek appropriate resentencing.

gold_sents: Civil Rights Corps sued Tulsa County and various judicial officers, alleging that the court system operated a wealth-based detention system by detaining arrestees without inquiring into their ability to pay bail.[SENTMARKER]While the plaintiffs motion for preliminary injunction was denied, the plaintiffs motion for class certification is still pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2018, a group of people arrested in Tulsa County, Oklahoma, filed a class-action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Oklahoma on behalf of hundreds of people detained in the Tulsa County jail solely because they could not afford to pay money bail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's wealth-based detention scheme, which jails people who are unable to meet secured financial conditions of release, violated their equal protection and due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on the same day, finding that the plaintiffs were members of a class of persons detained without a probable cause determination.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded for consideration of the public's interest in light of the new rule, which requires the jail to post bail for those who have not received due process compliant bail hearings and are allegedly detained in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the class certification motion, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2015, a consumer class action was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Pennsylvania on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by RealPage to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that RealPage violated the Fair Credit reporting Act by failing to timely update the criminal record information that it maintains to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged or sealed.[SENTMARKER]In addition, RealPage failed to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information it maintains about consumers to those consumers who made a request for their "file," and failed to disclose the sources of information for the criminal conviction data it includes in its responses to consumer file requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in March 2015 that included a $936,200 settlement fund for payments to the class members and for attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on the merits, with prejudice, with the parties agreeing not to appeal the decision.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
pegasus_output_sents: In February 2020, the Nashville CommunityBail Fund (NCBF) brought this action against the Honorable Howard Gentry, in his official capacity as Davidson County Criminal Court Clerk, to challenge the constitutionality of Davidson County Local Rule Governing Bail Bonds 10(B) under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment right against excessive bail; the Fourteenth amendment right to due process; and the right to a fair trial.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to comply with the terms of the consent decree and to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would not appeal the decision of the court to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
pegasus_output_sents: The Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, Texas, the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity, and other entities and officials, alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in connection with the city's debt collection policies and practices for Class C misdemeanor traffic tickets.[SENTMARKER]EPIC sought a preliminary injunction to prohibit the defendants from collecting voter data unless and until they completed a privacy impact assessment as required by the E-Government Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied EPIC's request for preliminary injunction, but granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]EPIC appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, which affirmed the district court's denial of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In January 2016, two indigent women that served imprisonment terms at the Randall County Jail filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the City of Amarillo's municipal code created a modern-day debtors' prison and violated their Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]In August 2016, the Court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss and ordered the plaintiffs to pay $3,660.00 in litigation costs.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the city of Amarillo, Texas, alleging that the city's fine collection system is unconstitutional as applied to indigent individuals.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's policy and practice of threatening debtors with incarceration for unpaid debts without informing them of their constitutional rights violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Due Process Clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the plaintiffs failed to state a plausible claim for municipal liability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: Foster children in Georgia's Fulton and DeKalb Counties brought suit against the state and counties Division of Family and Children Services.[SENTMARKER]The class of children alleged that they did not receive necessary treatment and services while spending months in emergency shelters, experienced abuse and neglect as a result of an insufficient number of caseworkers, and received inadequate health care and emotional services while in foster care.[SENTMARKER]In 2005 and 2006, the plaintiffs reached settlement agreements with the state, Fulton County, and DeKalb County.[SENTMARKER]As of November 2018, the State is still under the supervision of the independent monitor in order to meet the court-ordered benchmarks, having not yet completed sufficient improvements.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2002, a class action lawsuit was filed in the Superior Court of Fulton County on behalf of a class of Fulton and DeKalb County foster children and a subclass of African-American foster children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to correct alleged deficiencies in the foster care system.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motions to dismiss and for summary judgment, but the Tenth Circuit vacated and remanded with directions to consider separately each provision of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2005, the district court entered a consent decree between the plaintiffs and the defendants, which required the defendants to pay approximately $10.5 million in attorney's fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The parties were unable to reach an agreement as to the appropriate amount of fees or expenses to be awarded.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the District Court referred the case to mediation, where the parties agreed to pay the entire cost of the mediation.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved the consent Decree on October 27, 2005, and the parties filed suit for class certification on June 6, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 19, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, which remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with the Supreme Court's decision in the NAACP case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, who are children in the custody of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), brought suit against the state alleging abuse, neglect, and lack of services.[SENTMARKER]After the New York Times published several articles about the deaths of children in the care of DYFS due to lack of care, in 2003 the state entered into a settlement agreement providing for a systematic overhaul of the state child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The latest modification of the agreement was made in 2015 and remains in force.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services, Department of Human Services, and the State of New Jersey (collectively, the "defendants"), filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New York on behalf of two homeless children who were placed in the custody of the Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the children's civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate in-home services, failing to adequately monitor the children, and failing to comply with federal and state laws and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a modified settlement agreement in July 2006 that required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with home care services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for dismissal in part, and denied the motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, children in the custody of the New York City Child Welfare Administration ("CWA"), and children who, while not in the custody of CWA, are or will be at risk of abuse or neglect and whose status is known or should be known to CWA, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against both the city and state for systematic deficiencies that jeopardized their well-being.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed on December 13, 1995, and the parties reached to two separate settlement agreements, one with the city and one with the state, on December 2, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs returned to court in January 2001, seeking an order directing the state to comply with specific terms of the state settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the state had acted with insufficient diligence in implementing the information management system, and therefore extended the terms of the agreement in this area and directed that the plaintiffs receive semi-annual reports.[SENTMARKER]The defendants provided a January 2017 report to show that they were continuing to develop, implement, and update their information systems for child welfare needs.[SENTMARKER]A year later, the court ended its supervision of the portions of the settlement that it had retained jurisdiction to enforce.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 1995, a class action was brought in the United States District Court for the New York District against the City, the State, and the Mayor of the City.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's child welfare system was failing to protect thousands of children in the care of the Department of Social Services.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged systemic deficiencies in the administration of the system.[SENTMARKER]The district court approved two settlement agreements between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The parties moved jointly for class certification and approval of a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to approve the settlement agreements on March 31, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to dismiss the case on June 18, 1996.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 1996, the District Court declined to certify a class and dismissed the complaint.[SENTMARKER]On July 27, 1998, the parties informed the court that they were engaged in settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]On the eve of trial, the parties filed the two settlements, which were approved by the court on July 27, 1998.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 1999, the parties notified the court of their settlement negotiations and the court approved the settlements.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 18 1996.

gold_sents: This was a class action challenge to New York's unnecessary institutionalization of children in foster care in psychiatric facilities.[SENTMARKER]The initial settlement agreement, entered on February 28, 2011, provided for increased community-based placement opportunities for children in foster care with mental illness as well as individualized planning, staff training, and monitoring.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the initial settlement agreement, on July 7, 2011, the plaintiffs agreed to release defendants from all liability in exchange for payment from defendants.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2016, the parties agreed to extend the Court's jurisdiction until June 30, 2016, at which time its jurisdiction presumably expired.
pegasus_output_sents: May 2010 | U.S. District Court | Eastern District of New York | Title 11 of the Americans with Disabilities Act (the "ADA"] On May 12, 2010, a group of children in foster care filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the NYC Administration for children's services (ACS) violated the ADA by improperly placing and detaining children in acute-care psychiatric hospitals longer than necessary and failing to move these children to the least restrictive placements appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on October 12, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a new policy and procedure for the provision of emergency and inpatient mental health services for children in the foster care and child protective system.[SENTMARKER]On October 12, 2010, the parties entered a Stipulation and Order of Settlement, which is final and binding on all parties.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2013, an eleven-year-old child in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS), filed a lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas, Abbeville County, South Carolina, against SCDSS and the Boys Home of the South (BHOTS), alleging that, as a result of Defendants' failures, Plaintiff was sexually assaulted on multiple occasions, causing him severe and permanent mental injury.[SENTMARKER]Following removal to Federal Court, in early 2014, Plaintiff settled with both SCDSS and BHOTS for an undisclosed sum of money.[SENTMARKER]BHOTS also permanently closed as a result of the lawsuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2013, a South Carolina foster child filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the Boys Home and the State Department of social services (SCDSS) alleging that he was sexually abused while in foster care by another foster child, A.R.[SENTMARKER]Dkt.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the sexual abuse was preventable because the SCDSS and BHOTS allegedly had notice and knowledge that the foster child alleged inadequate supervision at BHOTS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were not provided with urgently needed medical and mental health treatment after the alleged abuse and that the defendants failed to provide them with adequate protection and met their needs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment on January 21, 2014 and the case was dismissed on March 24, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement on June 28, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The funds for John Doe will be placed in a discretionary trust and an educational trust for his benefit.

gold_sents: On January 12, 2015, a class action lawsuit was filed against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging numerous deficiencies in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2015, the parties reached an interim settlement agreement, providing for an end to certain SCDSS practices, as well as for studies of additional SCDSS practices.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring revealed incremental improvements in conditions, and the settlement remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 4, 2016, a group of children in South Carolina's foster care system filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina alleging that the state had violated the children's constitutional rights by failing to provide them with basic health care services.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in a Final Settlement Agreement (FSA) in which the state agreed to develop a Health Care Improvement Plan (the "Plan") for all children in foster care in the physical or legal custody of the state.[SENTMARKER]The FSA required the state to provide medical and dental assessments, periodic medical/physical and dental health screenings, and follow-up treatment to Plaintiff Children as required under the "Early, Periodic Screening, Diagnosis and Treatment" provisions of the Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the FSA on October 4, 2016 and the parties filed a joint report on the progress of the FSA in the following months.[SENTMARKER]The joint report was submitted to the court on January 5, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs in March 2019, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 23, 2007, a wheelchair-bound customer filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California alleging violations of the Americans with disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Disabled persons Act (CDPA) in two Chipotle restaurants in San Diego.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice upon the defendants' motion to dismiss, but the Ninth Circuit remanded the case to the district court with instructions to enter judgment that Chipotle's 19 written policy violated the ADA and to issue appropriate injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held that the high walls at the two restaurants were in violation of the written policy and that the restaurants need not comply with these requirements.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing filed this ongoing lawsuit on behalf of several LSAT test takers against the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC).[SENTMARKER]The State claims that LSAC routinely denies reasonable accommodations to test takers with disabilities in violation of the California Unruh Civil Rights Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In 2014, the parties have agreed to a consent decree that the court approved.
pegasus_output_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on April 12, 2012 against the Law School Admission Council, Inc. (LSAC) alleging that LSAC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Unruh Civil Rights Act (UCR) by failing to grant individual plaintiffs' requests for disability-related accommodations to test-takers of the Law 19 Admission Test (LSAT) in a manner accessible to individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]On May 29, 2014, the parties reached a settlement in which LSAC agreed to abide by the procedures used by LSAC and widely used in law school admissions for a period of four years.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, which was approved by the Court on May 29, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would not enforce the terms of the consent decree for the next four years and that the defendant would no longer be required to provide individual plaintiffs with a notation on their test-taker's score report indicating that their exam scores were earned under non-standard time conditions.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the defendant to provide the plaintiffs with an accessible scribe, a computer for the writing 13 sample, and allow the plaintiffs to use a written sample of the test.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed to pay a civil penalty to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Disabled plaintiffs sued a public transit agency for violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act, alleging their bus system presented numerous barriers to access, subjecting the plaintiffs to delay, embarrassment, and ridicule by passengers and drivers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, in which the defendant agreed to remedy the problems with its bus system and pay $250,000 in damages, fees, and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2000, two individuals with disabilities filed this suit in the District Court for the District of Denver against the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City had violated the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs and by denying the benefits of its services, programs, and activities, as more fully set forth above.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in July 2000.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was final and binding on all parties, including all principals, agents, and employees of the City.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the City to comply with the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The City also agreed to provide training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics, as well as timely refresher training for any operator or mechanic who demonstrates a lack of knowledge of proper wheelchair lift operation, maintenance, and repair.[SENTMARKER]On or before September 3, 2001, the City shall ramp or otherwise provide access to the restrooms at the Alpine Slide/stables area on the east side of the rodeo grounds.

gold_sents: Disabled patrons of a concert venue filed a class action against the owners and operators of the venue for failure to remove barriers to access.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Defendants agreeing not to obstruct wheelchair areas and to pay damages and attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 26, 1992, a Colorado nonprofit organization representing persons with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Colorado against the owners, operators, lessors, and/or lessees of Fiddler's Green, a concert hall in Denver, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide adequate seating for persons with mobility limitations and their nondisabled companions despite being repeatedly requested to do so.[SENTMARKER]The class sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on January 26, 1992.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2015, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Passenger Railroad Corporation (Amtrak).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, for decades, Amtrak had failed to make its stations accessible to individuals with disabilities, including individuals who use wheelchairs, and of necessary remedies to bring its services, programs, and activities into compliance with the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The complaint included an NDRN-generated report alleging that Amtrak stations across the country were inaccessible in violation of the ADA, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, the parties agreed that the ADA would remain in effect for 10 years from the effective date of the complaint, and that the parties would submit a Sunset Analysis to the DOJ and Federal Railroad Administration (FRA).[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that Amtrak would maintain records showing the dates and length of training, instructors, and attendees, including job titles.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Amtrak agreed to pay a total of $1 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest to the parties.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On July 22, 2013, attorneys from United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the State of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that nearly two hundred children with disabilities were unnecessarily segregated from their communities and the general population by the State, which had placed them in nursing homes.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ sought an injunction requiring the State to comply with Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12131-12134, which, as interpreted by the Supreme Court in Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]In June 2014, the case was consolidated with another pending case, which is in the Clearinghouse as PB-FL-0007.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 4, 2014, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida entered a final judgment against the State of Florida in a lawsuit brought under title II of the Americans with disabilities Act of 1990 (the "ADA").[SENTMARKER]The ADA requires the State to provide services in the most integrated setting appropriate to the needs of children with significant medical needs.[SENTMARKER]In the past, as many as 20% of children in nursing facilities were in the State's custody because of the state's administration of its Medical Foster Care program.[SENTMARKER]The State reduced funding for private duty nursing services by approximately six million dollars in 2010 and failed to provide sufficient reimbursement rates for in-home nursing services, or failure to provide such services.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the State violated the ADA because it planned, administered, and funded its system of services for children with disabilities in a manner that results in the unnecessary institutionalization of hundreds of children and placed other children at serious risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment, which is subject to court approval, requires the state to comply with the terms of the final judgment.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the state will be required to ensure that children with medical needs in the community have opportunities to move to more integrated settings, provide educational opportunities to children and young adults who are placed in these facilities, and provide adequate reimbursement rates.

gold_sents: In 2005, two organizations that advocates for people with disabilities filed this lawsuit n the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the City of Detroit, claiming that the city had failed to meet federal and Michigan accessibility standards in altering intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the parties negotiated a plant to correct the affected intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]As of 2018, a special master continues to monitor implementation of the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: The Center for Community Access, Inc. and Michigan Paralyzed Veterans of America (MPVA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in June 2006 against the City of Detroit, Michigan, under the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504) alleging violations of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in August 2006 that required the City to install curb cuts and other improvements to meet the required accessibility standards and codes.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that the City would pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2010, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the City, finding that the defendants had violated the terms of the settlement agreement and ordering the defendants to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees, costs, and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: This was a case brought to make a 300 unit apartment complex in Canton Township, MI accessible to persons with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in 2006 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two individuals and the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The suit eventually resulted in about three quarters of a million dollars in retrofits, damages to the plaintiffs and attorney fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2006, a disabled resident of Canton, Michigan filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan, alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to design, construct, and/or operate a housing complex that was accessible to and useable by individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were repeatedly retaliated against by the defendants because they asserted their rights under the fair housing act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a partial settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs injunctive relief and to make improvements to the housing complex.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the court on September 20, 2006.

gold_sents: A class action lawsuit was filed on July 10, 2012, against the Mississippi Department of Education, under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA), alleging that the defendant had failed to execute its responsibilities under IDEA, by not ensuring that the Jackson Public School District provide disabled students with a free and appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment, even after conducting an investigation into the School District and identifying its systemic failure to meet its IDEA obligations.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on September 29, 2014 stipulating the implementation of a Program Sustainability Plan for the 2014-2015 school year.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2015 District Court Judge Daniel P. Jordan III granted a motion to dismiss with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed on behalf of children with disabilities in the Jackson Public Schools in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the individuals with disabilities education improvement act of 2004 ("IDEA") and the class of similarly situated special education students.[SENTMARKER]The defendants alleged that the plaintiffs had been denied the educational and supportive services they needed to achieve academically, and had been forced into substandard segregated settings with little to no appropriate academic programming and related services.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for preliminary injunction and granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with free appropriate public education and to create a separate alternative school program to serve only students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: On August 3, 2006, plaintiffs, a group of disabled persons receiving public benefits filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the South District of New York against the New York Human Resources Administration alleging that it discriminated against disabled persons by involuntarily segregating them by transferring their public benefits cases from local benefit centers to three hub centers that only serviced people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved a proposed settlement agreement in June of 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 19, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of persons with disabilities and persons eligible for public assistance on the basis of handicap in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the New York State Human Rights Law (N.Y.[SENTMARKER]Human Resources Law).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction prohibiting further case transfers from local Job Centers to the hub centers, a class certification, and a settlement of monetary claims.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in November 2005, and the case was transferred to this court in November 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on November 7, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendant would provide plaintiffs with draft training materials for their review and comment and would pay the plaintiffs reasonable counsel fees and costs as part of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Students sued the New York City Department of Education, the City of New York, and the chancellor of the New York City Department of Education to seek injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and New York state law.[SENTMARKER]The student plaintiffs are either student in Staten Island District 75 schools or vulnerable to being sent to those schools, which are separated from New York City community schools.[SENTMARKER]District 75 students receive their education in a restrictive setting where they are largely isolated from interactions with students who do not have disabilities.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief in the form of a permanent injunction against future violations and an order for a remedial plan to reimagine policies, practices, and norms that will permit each student to learn in the most integrated setting possible.[SENTMARKER]The case remains open.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] New York City Department of Education, City of New York, and Disability Advocates, Inc. filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Brooklyn on behalf of students with disabilities who are being educated in segregated and unequal public schools and classrooms in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the New York Human Rights Law (NYCHRL).[SENTMARKER]The Named Plaintiffs and putative Plaintiff Class represent students who receive education in a Staten Island District 75 school or classroom or are at significant risk of being placed in a community school classroom.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs' counsel is experienced in federal class action litigation, including in education, special education, and the civil rights of persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' counsel sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: Four blind or visually impaired library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking relief under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the Library's new program to lend e-reading devices was discriminatory, because the Nook Simple Touch devices the library had procured were inaccessible to visually impaired users, and because accessible alternative devices were available.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The library agreed to transition to the exclusive use of accessible devices within four years, and to add ten accessible e-readers within 60 days of the settlement date.
pegasus_output_sents: The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA"), 42 U.S.C.  12132, and Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (" Rehabilitation Act") prohibit discrimination on the basis of disability when institutions in receipt of federal funds can not discriminate in access to e-book technology.[SENTMARKER]In 2010, four blind library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Library's lending program violated Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Final Settlement Agreement, which required the Library to comply with Section 504 by refraining from lending any inaccessible e-reader device to its blind patrons, and to purchase e-reading devices that are fully accessible to both patrons who are blind and patrons who do not have such disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Library also required the plaintiffs to pay reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed a suit in federal court on January 20, 2011, against Millcreek Township, PA and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the sidewalks and intersections in Millcreek were not in compliance with the disability accessibility mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the parties partially settled, with the Township and PennDOT committing to adhere to ADA requirements in the future and to retrofit sidewalks and intersections where necessary.[SENTMARKER]A series of consent decrees, over which the court retains jurisdiction, have been entered and the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2011, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania on behalf of persons with disabilities who relied on wheelchairs to travel in the streets.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Title II of the Americans With Disabilities Act ("ADA") and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 ("Section 504") by failing to make certain improvements to Millcreek's pedestrian walkways, intersections, and other facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree and Partial Settlement with respect to some of the claims, but not all, of the plaintiffs' claims, and the parties agreed to allow at least fifteen days to agree upon any modifications to the consent decree and partial settlement.[SENTMARKER]As part of the partial settlement, Millcreek agreed to install at least 110 curb ramps each year until the remaining curb ramps are installed, to establish a nondiscrimination and sexual harassment policy, and to inform its employees that sexual harassment will not be tolerated and employees who practice it will be disciplined.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction to enforce all terms of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]In the meantime, the parties have continued discussions and negotiations regarding several unresolved additional issues.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 1996, parents of a student with autism filed this lawsuit on his behalf against the Arkansas Department of Education and the Williford School District under the IDEA, the ADA, Section 504, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The parents claimed that their son was unfairly discriminated against due to his disability and was deprived of an appropriate education.[SENTMARKER]In 2004, the Eastern District of Arkansas Court held that neither defendant had violated the federal statutes and found for state and the school district.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 1996, the parents of an autistic boy sued the Arkansas Department of Education and the Williford School District, alleging violations of the Individuals with Disability Education Act (IDEA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act ( 504 of the Rehabilitation Act) in the Little Rock District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed all of the plaintiffs' claims with prejudice, finding that the defendants did not violate federal law.[SENTMARKER]The case was then consolidated and the district court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment on the basis of the state's Eleventh Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the case was re-opened and the court remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with two hours of occupational therapy for their autistic son.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2000, a group of gay and lesbian students filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California alleging that the school district violated their civil rights by failing to protect them from harassment and discrimination based on their actual or perceived sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the district's anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policies did not adequately address the hostile environment that the plaintiffs experienced at Golden West High School.[SENTMARKER]The district agreed to implement a "Mandatory Student Training Program" for all of its certificated employees, administrators, and non-certificated staff who are responsible for monitoring student behavior.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim on the basis of associational standing.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order on June 30, 2005, requiring the district to provide one training session to all students in one grade level in all VUSD high schools and 20 continuation schools on the subject of preventing harassment, discrimination, and school safety.[SENTMARKER]The consent order is effective immediately upon the entry of the consent order, or 60 days after the last report under 6 Section X is received, whichever date is later.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the district will provide one mandatory training session in which all students are instructed about the legal obligations of VUSD employees and will not be obligated to pay any services.

gold_sents: The plaintiff, Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) sued the U.S. Department of Education to compel compliance with its FOIA request related to its investigation of Princeton University.[SENTMARKER]The defendant notified Princeton of the request and the lawsuit, and Princeton then filed a lawsuit against SFFA to enjoin the disclosure of the materials requested under FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The present case was consolidated into that suit, and the parties jointly stipulated to this case's dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2016, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. (SFFA) filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the district of Columbia against the Department of education for failing to comply with the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and its corresponding regulations.[SENTMARKER]SFFA sought all documents concerning the investigation of Princeton University in the FOIA request filed on January 11, 2016.[SENTMARKER]As of October 27, 2016, SFFA had not received any documents from the Department in response to its FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2016, John Carroll, an officer of the Department’s Civil Division, had a telephone conversation with Edward Office, the President of SFFA, and Edward Office’s counsel about SFFA’s FOIA request; on June 10, 2016, the Department said that it was processing the documents that are responsive to your request, but needed additional time due to the volume of documents requested, which it estimated to be "exceed 1,500 pages."[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2016, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan granted the Department's motion for summary judgment, finding that the Department had made no reasonable effort to search for responsive documents, had failed to produce any documents responsive to SFFA's request, and had not produced any documents under the claim of exemption.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2017, Judge Chutka dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement that required the Department to provide the requested documents to the Plaintiff by August 31, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On August 31, 2017, the Department filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On November 30, 2017, the Court granted the motion for partial summary judgment.

gold_sents: Princeton sued U.S. Department of Education and OCR in a "reverse FOIA" to stop them from releasing documents related to an OCR compliance review to Students for Fair Admissions, Inc., which had submitted a FOIA request and filed a lawsuit against the DOE to compel disclosure.[SENTMARKER]Parties voluntarily dismissed case.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 27, 2016, a student group filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Washington (D.C.) against the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights (OCR) seeking to compel disclosure of certain documents and information relating to the University's undergraduate admissions program submitted to OCR in the course of an OCR compliance review.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the University had discriminated against the complainant on the basis of race and national origin in the admissions process, and that the materials at issue were the subject of a pending FOIA request, FOIA Request No. 16-00645-F (the "FOIA Request"), and accompanying suit.[SENTMARKER]The University brought this action for permanent injunctive and declaratory relief under the Administrative Procedure Act to set aside the Department's and OCR's final decision to disclose the documents as arbitrary and capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2017, the court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment, and remanded the case to the Department and OCR for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2010, a group of students with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Education for failing to provide accessible free public education to students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]After negotiations, the court approved a Consent Decree in March 2015.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Monitor continues to file periodical assessments as the State works toward full compliance under court supervision.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2015, a group of students with disabilities filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Orleans Parish School Board (OPSB) and the New Orleans Public School Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were represented by the ACLU, alleged that they were denied access to public school because of their disabilities and that their disabilities were not adequately addressed by the school.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in a consent decree that required the school board to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The school board agreed to provide annual technical assistance to each school under its jurisdiction regarding the prohibited practice of undocumented suspensions and to develop and disseminate information to parents of students at each school about prohibited practice.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required that each school develop a written complaint investigation protocol describing the school’s process for investigating allegations of discrimination on the basis of disability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2002, a group of students at Westfield High School filed a lawsuit in the United States district court for the district of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school had violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting them from distributing candy canes with an attachment that contained the story of the candy cane and some Bible verses to fellow students.[SENTMARKER]The school denied the group access to show the film, because it was "church related," and the school feared that allowing students to wear the armbands would result in a disturbance among the students.[SENTMARKER]On December 2003, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on December 2003 and the plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the school's motion to dismiss the case.
