gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: The National Federation of the Blind, The Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates, Inc., and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland on May 31, 2018 against the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights, Department of Justice, and Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the March 5, 2018 issuance of a new Office of Civil Rights (OCR) manual, which allegedly eliminated certain substantive rights of complainants that the OCR was designed to protect, violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (CRCPA).[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to pay $50,000 in attorneys' fees and costs in full and final settlement of any and all claims for attorneys' costs in connection with this case.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the case would be dismissed with prejudice one year from the date of the filing of the complaint unless the parties jointly move the Court to reopen the case because the terms of this agreement have not been consummated.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed without prejudice.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 12, 2019, a nonprofit organization representing students with disabilities and their families filed a lawsuit in the District of Maryland against the Office of the Civil Rights of the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Departments of Education in the United States District Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Office violated Title IX by failing to investigate a complaint that a student had been raped by a male student while walking home from school.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the Office failed to conclude the investigation when it did not conclude that the student was the victim of sexual harassment or assault and failed to provide appropriate support services to the student as she struggled to continue her education.[SENTMARKER]The Office's failure to investigate the complaint led to the Plaintiff's complaint being dismissed by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2020, the Office issued a new rule, titled "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities receiving Federal Financial Assistance" (the "Rule").[SENTMARKER]The Rule was designed to ensure that Title IX programs and activities receiving federal funds would not be subject to discrimination on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The Rule requires the Office to report to the Office for Civil Rights on any violations of Title IX, Title VI, Title II, and Section 504, and to provide the Office with a copy of the Report and Complaint within three months of the Rule's release.[SENTMARKER]The Court dismissed the case on May 6, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Office is required to report back to the Court on the implementation of the new rule.[SENTMARKER]In a parallel action, the Plaintiff and the Office filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was dismissed on July 12, 2019.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 16, 2006, two black high school seniors filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan challenging the implementation of a state constitutional amendment that was to go into effect on December 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties to the case either took no position or consented to the relief, and the Court granted the motion to intervene on December 14, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the State of Michigan's motion to dismiss and ruled that the state statute was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 18, 2008, the District Court issued a final order granting summary judgment in favor of the Attorney General, concluding that the portions of Proposal 2 that affect Michigan’s public institutions of higher education impermissibly alter the political process in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]On November 8, 2006, the day after Proposal 2’s approval, a collection of interest groups and individuals, including the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigration Rights and Fight for Equality By Any Means, filed suit in the district court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, a black woman in Akron, Ohio, alleged that her real estate agent could not show her certain residences because the owners had specified they would not sell to black persons.[SENTMARKER]The NAACP alleged that the school board had maintained a system of de jure segregation.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2007, the case was consolidated in this court for briefing and argument.[SENTMARKER]In its March 18, 2008 Opinion and Order, the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit overturned the District's grant of summary judgment and dismissed all claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In late 2003, several students with disabilities filed a lawsuit against the New York City Department of Education and the New York City School Board for failing to follow the orders of impartial hearings requiring them to compensate or fund tuition and services for the special education needs of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2008 a settlement agreement was approved which included injunctive and compensatory relief.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2003, a group of parents of children with disabilities filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of their children who attended a non-public program that was not approved by the New York State Education Department to provide education to students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' failure to comply with the final decisions and orders of Impartial Hearing Officers (IHOs) violated their rights under the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for class certification, and the parties agreed to a settlement that provided for the payment of $1,590,625.25 in attorney's fees and $132,705.93 in expenses.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to the release of the defendants from any further enforcement of the IHOs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2012, a parent, individually and on behalf of their student-child with an educational disability in the Buffalo City School District, filed this class action complaint in the the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Buffalo City School District Board of Education and its superintendent denied free appropriate public education to children with educational disabilities, failed to promptly provide children with disabilities related services, and failed to provide parents with meaningful participation in their children's educational decision-making process.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required more timely speech and language therapy for members of the class and awarded attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in March 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2012, a class action was brought in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York on behalf of children and their parents who are educationally disabled.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the rights of the children by failing to provide a free appropriate public education (FAPE) to children who are classified as learning disabled under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the New York State Education Law and regulations and other statutes.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was appealed to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed the district court's decision on June 17, 2014 and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement requires the defendants to comply with all federal and state laws and regulations relating to the education of children with disabilities and to provide services to such disabled students where services for non-disabled students are no so delayed.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (1) the district must provide the individual plaintiff with a free FAPE, including special education and related services; .[SENTMARKER](2) the district's policy precludes parental involvement and the implementation of services; .[SENTMARKER](3) the district will not deny the right of parents of such children their legal rights under the IDEA; and (4) the District will not discriminate against students who are learning disabled.

gold_sents: On February 15, 1996, students filed a class action lawsuit against Owasso Independent School District ("OPS"), claiming that it had violated  Title IX of the Education Amendment of 1972, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by intentionally denying  female students an equal opportunity to participate in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 1996, the Court entered a consent decree, which settled each of the claims stated in the Complaint and resolved all claims asserted against individuals who were named in their official and individual capacities, dismissing claims for damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, a group of female high school students filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Oklahoma on behalf of all female students in the District who wished to participate in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District had violated Title IX by knowingly and deliberately discriminating against female students by failing to provide equal opportunities for female students, including the daughters of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The District agreed to fund and sponsor girls' sports in a manner which does not discriminate against female athletes.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed to construct an on-campus softball field which is comparable in quality to the District's existing baseball field.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the District agreed not to construct a softball/baseball work-out facility until such time as it had completed the softball field provided for within this Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and granted their motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Parents, on behalf of female students of Chouteau Public Schools, brought suit against the school district alleging that the school had violated female students' rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and Title IX of the Education Amendment through disparate treatment with respect to interscholastic athletics and programs.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the school district agreed to take steps to remedy the discriminatory actions by, among many things, providing coaching, facilities and equipment to both male and female athletic teams on a gender-neutral basis.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2000, a group of female students filed this class action lawsuit against Chouteau public schools in the Northern district of Oklahoma, alleging that the school district violated Title IX by denying female students meaningful participation opportunities in interscholastic and other school-sponsored sports.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Chouteau has failed to effectively accommodate the interests of the female students and that its actions constitute violations of the Title IX rights of these students.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including the provision of locker rooms and facilities for both practice and competition; and (7) publicity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on June 30, 2000 and entered into by Judge Michael Burrage, requires Chouteau to fund and sponsor a sufficient number of additional athletic teams for female students, provide female students with off-season training opportunities, and provide female athletes with a gender neutral system for attracting coaches for all of its teams.[SENTMARKER]The school district also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to work out the details of the settlement agreement in a separate document.

gold_sents: A lawsuit was filed on behalf of all school-age students with disabilities in Pennsylvania seeking to increase the number of children with disabilities educated with their non-disabled peers, and to make sure schools provided real supports to make sure inclusion would work as required by the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]After eleven years, the parties reached a settlement; however, the final report demonstrates many of the terms of the agreement was not met.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 1994, a group of parents of children with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the Pennsylvania Departments of Education, and members of the State Board of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their right to a free appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment by failing to identify disabled students, develop individual educational programs or plans, and provide a free Appropriate Public Education to the maximum extent reasonably possible.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to develop a program of comprehensive personnel development to train regular and special education personnel in promising educational practices for the provision of supplementary aids and services to students with disabilities in regular classrooms.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to create materials to disseminate information to parents about training opportunities and materials that parents can seek assistance in obtaining these aids and service for their children.

gold_sents: In 2015, a transgender boy filed a lawsuit against his school district because they would not allow him to use the boys' bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the school district's motion to dismiss, but the appeals court reversed and remanded, and the district court has since granted a preliminary injunction allowing plaintiff access to the boy's bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed to hear the school district's appeal in 2016, but later remanded the case after the Department of Education and Department of Justice withdrew their prior guidance on the issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiff's graduation from high school rendered the case moot.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2018, the district court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February 15, 2019, and a motion for summary judgment on March 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2019, the court granted the summary judgment; the defendant appealed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 9, 2014, a Gloucester County High School student filed a Title IX lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Virginia against the Gloucester County School Board (the "School Board"), alleging that the School Board's transgender restroom policy violated Title IX and the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the policy discriminated against the student on the basis of his sex in violation of Title IX.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed G.G.[SENTMARKER]'s Title IX claim and denied his request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit vacated the district court's June 23, 2016 preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court granted a stay of the District Court's mandate.[SENTMARKER]The School Board then implemented the policy and created three single-stall unisex restrooms for use by all students, regardless of their biological sex or gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The District Court then granted a temporary restraining order and entered a final judgment in favor of the school.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Ricoh Company, Ltd. and Taylor Made Digital Systems, Inc. alleging that Ricoh violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII) and Title I of Title VII (Civil Rights Act) of 1991 by subjecting a female employee to unlawful sex and race discrimination when it refused to allow her to return to her position.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Ricoh agreed not to engage in retaliating against any current or former employee because he or she opposed any practice of race discrimination or sex discrimination or participated in any manner in any way in any investigation.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Ricoh agreed to post on its website its anti-discrimination policy which includes but is not limited to race and sex discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is effective upon its entry by the Court.

gold_sents: In 2008, six Best Buy employees filed a class action lawsuit against Best Buy alleging discrimination on the bases of race and sex.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the implementation of policies to protect employees against discrimination and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On December 8, 2015, the monitor reported that Best Buy had complied with the terms of the consent decree and it thus expired.
pegasus_output_sents: The California Department of Justice's Office of Civil Rights and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit on behalf of African-American, Asian-American and female employees in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Best Buy systematically discriminated against African-Americans and other minorities by refusing to hire qualified applicants who passed Best Buy's pre-hiring tests into entry-level positions.[SENTMARKER]Best Buy also allegedly retaliated against employees who complained about the company's discriminatory treatment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Best Buy agreed to implement a series of anti-discrimination and anti-harassment policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the terms of the decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree, which became effective on January 1, 2004, requires Best Buy to post its non-discrimination policies on its intranet website, to post a message in support of its anti-retaliation policies, to train its general managers regarding the complaint process, to provide training to all employees in how to use the registration 10 of interest and the internal job posting systems, and to provide for the filing, investigation, and remedying of complaints of discrimination on the basis of race, color, national origin or gender.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Best Buy will designate an officer ("Monitor") who will oversee Best Buy’s policies and 12 practices.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to final approval by the court.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 28, 2004, three former employees of El Paso Corp. filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against El Paso and its pension plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that El Paso converted its defined benefit pension plan from a traditional defined benefit plan to one based on a final average pay formula to one on a cash balance formula.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the charge and the EEOC was unable to resolve the controversy.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.

pegasus_output_sents: This case arises out of Morgan Stanley's systemic company-wide discriminatory treatment of its female financial advisors and female registered financial advisor trainees in violation of federal and applicable state civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The Named Plaintiffs each filed a charge of discrimination with the EEOC alleging, among other things, that Morgan Stanley discriminated against them and a class of similarly situated persons throughout the United States on the basis of their sex in several aspects of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged the services of Hunter Hughes, Esq., a highly experienced professional mediator, skilled in mediation of complex class actions, including employment discrimination litigation.[SENTMARKER]In April 2007, the Named Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint naming Morgan Stanley Co. pegasus_output_sents: On August 2, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware against I.G.[SENTMARKER]Burton Company, Inc., a Delaware-based company, alleging that the company violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) by firing employees and applicants based on their age.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that LG.[SENTMARKER]Burton subjected certain individuals to disparate treatment on the basis of their ages, seventy-five (75) and above, by discharging them from employment.[SENTMARKER]In its complaint, the EEOC alleged that the defendants violated the ADEA by failing to provide the EEOC with any and all copies of the company's policies and procedures regarding age discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed to the following terms: (a) the parties would not deduct their share of Social Security and Medicare contributions from the payment to the complainants; .[SENTMARKER](b) the defendant would provide a representative of the EEOC to enter the company; .[SENTMARKER](c) the company would provide training to its employees on the requirements of ADEA; .[SENTMARKER](d) the defendants would pay monetary relief in the amount of Twenty-Two Thousand Dollars ($22,000.00), less all lawful deductions to John Collison; and (e) each party would bear its own expenses, costs, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is final and binding and will continue to be in effect for a period of three years from the date of filing.

pegasus_output_sents: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida on January 12, 2006 against Discount Auto Parts, Inc., a Florida corporation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.  2000e- 5(f)(1) by subjecting women to sexual harassment in violation of Title VII and by terminating one of the women in retaliation for asserting her rights under Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the EEOC on behalf of a class of similarly situated women who were adversely affected by such practices.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay $150,000 to the plaintiffs and to provide them with a copy of its policies, procedures, and training manuals regarding sexual harassment and/or retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were not disclosed, but the parties agreed that the settlement would be subject to the execution of a confidentiality agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendant to provide the plaintiffs with an opportunity to object before serving the subpoena on the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the EEOC in March 2007 against the defendant, finding that the defendants had violated the terms of its settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On June 30, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII sex discrimination and retaliation suit in the Fort Lauderdale U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against DTG Operations, Inc., (doing business as Dollar Rent A Car) on behalf of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The employee intevened in the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree that provided for monetary relief ($395,000) and injunctive relief, such as antidiscrimination, antiretaliation, training, and notice-posting provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the southern district of Florida on June 30, 2004 against Dollar Rent A Car, a nationwide rental car company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII and Title I of the civil rights act by subjecting a female employee to a sexually hostile work environment and discharging her in retaliation for opposing sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2005, the parties entered a consent decree, which required the defendant to provide a complete copy of its policy against sexual harassment and retaliation within thirty days of the entry of this decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay a total of $395,000 to the complainant, who was the victim of a physical battery in April of 2003.

gold_sents: In September 2002, the Chicago District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit against HQ Global Workplaces, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging discrimination on the basis of disability and retaliation in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the defendant maintained policies on leave and part-time status availability precluding reasonable accommodation in violation of the ADA, terminated complainant based on her disability, and disciplined complainant's manager for providing complainant with a reasonable accommodation.[SENTMARKER]Following some discovery, the parties jointly dismissed the lawsuit in May 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2001, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Illinois against HQ Global Workplaces, Inc., a Chicago-based employer.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the employer discriminated against a female employee on the basis of her disability by maintaining policies on leave and the availability of part-time status which precluded reasonable accommodations in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice and without costs by agreement on April 2001.

gold_sents: The EEOC filed suit against Sears Roebuck and Company, alleging that Sears violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by enacting an inflexible workers compensation policy, and failing to provide reasonable accommodations to employees seeking to return to work after injury.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a consent decree, which required payment to individual claimants, revision of policies, recordkeeping, reporting, and training.[SENTMARKER]The matter appears to be closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2004, the Chicago office of the EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois on behalf of a class of Sears employees with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sears violated Title I of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) by unlawfully maintaining an inflexible one year leave policy, which provided for discharge of employment after a year instead of "reasonable accommodation" and which instead provided for termination of employment, all in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Sears failed to accommodate one of its Chicago-area employees, John Bava, with a reasonable accommodation after he was injured while working for Sears and terminated him on account of his disability, which constitutes an adverse employment action.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC also alleged that the inflexible leave policy did not provide for reasonable accommodation and that Sears did not return Bava to work in an available position which he could have performed.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion to dismiss the case, and the parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed that Sears would comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required Sears to provide reasonable accommodation to Bava and other employees who lost their jobs because of Sears' one-year worker's compensation or medical-disability leave policy.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, pregnancy, or national origin.

gold_sents: On February 8, 2006, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against the Board of Trustees for Southern Illinois University under Title VII in the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The Department of Justice asked the court for injunctive relief, alleging that the defendant discriminated against non-specified minorities on the basis of race and white males on the basis of race and gender.[SENTMARKER]The day after, the parties entered into a consent decree with injunctive reliefs and the case was dismissed on December 2, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 16, 2006, the United States Department of Justice filed this complaint against the Board of Trustees of the University of Southern Illinois ("SIU Board"), alleging that the Board violated the provisions of Title VII by denying paid fellowship positions to students who are either of a specified race and/or national origin or who are female.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the SIU Board maintained and continued to maintain the following paid fellowship programs open only to students on the basis of race, national origin and religion.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2006, the parties entered a consent decree, which was entered by Judge J. Phil Gilbert of the United District Court for the Southern district of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the Board to: (i) provide live mandatory training to all academic recruiters and employees engaged in recruiting activities on behalf of SIU for paid fellowships regarding Title VII's prohibitions against discrimination; .[SENTMARKER](ii) post a copy of the consent decree in a prominent public place in the main office for recruitment of each College and School at SIU; .[SENTMARKER](iii) cease publication, distribution or dissemination of any information that suggests or infers that paid fellowships positions are set aside, reserved or in any way restricted on the based of race or national origin; and (iv) provide a copy to each individual who has any role in the recruitment, selection, hiring or employment of persons for paid Fellowship positions.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the parties will continue to pursue policies and practices that are the same or similar to those alleged in the complaint.

gold_sents: In 2001, four former employees of Mid-West Wire Specialties, Inc. filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant discriminated against them on the basis of their sex, female, in violation of Title VII, in that they were sexually harassed by other employees of the defendant and faced retaliation for resisting the sexual advances.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the parties reached a settlement that awarded monetary damages and backpay for for class members.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in August 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2001, two female employees filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Illinois on behalf of approximately 47 female temporary workers in the Chicago area.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subject to a hostile work environment, quid pro quo sexual harassment, and retaliation in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to pay approximately $500 (five hundred dollars) to each of the female workers.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the company to hire a Spanish-speaking administrator to enforce its anti-harassment policy.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 3, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 12th, 2000 eight female employees filed suit in the United States District Court in the Northern District of Illinois against DaimlerChrysler Corp.  They alleged DaimlerChrysler engaged in age discrimination, gender discrimination, race discrimination, and violations of the American with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]As discovery progressed various plaintiffs were added and some were dismissed from the case.[SENTMARKER]Settlement negations concerning the remaining plaintiffs resulted in individual settlement agreements.[SENTMARKER]The exact terms of these settlements are not available.[SENTMARKER]The case was completely dismissed on October 29th, 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 21, 1991, two African-American female employees of DaimlerChrysler Corporation filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Illinois against DaimlerChrysler and the International Union of the United Auto Workers Local Union alleging that they were discriminated against because of their race and sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants had created and condoned a work environment that was hostile to women and African-Americans with regard to promotion, training, and skills qualification.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DaimlerChrysler failed to accommodate their disability by refusing to allow them to take ten-minute breaks to perform a blood sugar test and administer any needed medication prior to the Defendant’s own scheduled breaks.[SENTMARKER]On November 30, 2000, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Fed.R.Civ.P.[SENTMARKER]4.03 (Rockford) v. Daimler Chrysler Corporation.[SENTMARKER]On July 26, 2001, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 21, 2014, a group of African-American Financial Advisors (FAs) filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern district of Illinois against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. (Merrill Lynch) alleging racial discrimination in hiring, compensation, account distribution, and “teaming” (the grouping of brokers that handle particular accounts) and seeking to litigate the claims as a class.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Merrill Lynch’s long history of systemic discrimination against African-Americans and women was well known.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs’ initial motion for class certification in August 2010, and the court dismissed the entire case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the plaintiffs filed a companion case in the district court, alleging that the firm’s retention bonuses to Merrill Lynch FAs discriminated against African Americans and female FAs by disproportionately advantaging white males.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to amend the complaint to include race and gender discrimination claims under Title VII, and the case was dismissed in 2006.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2014 and the Supreme Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the plaintiffs sought class certification on the basis of Merrill Lynch's alleged discrimination against black brokers and the firm's account distribution and teaming policies.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the plaintiffs had not proved that the retention bonuses violated Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case and the parties entered into a consent decree that required Merrill Lynch to increase its representation of African American brokers to 6.5%.

gold_sents: In December 2013, the EEOC brought this suit against Bright Petroleum for scrutinizing, disciplining and discharging against its female employee who filed a charge of sex discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC and Bright Petroleum entered a three-year consent decree on December 12, 2014.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2013, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District Of Indiana against Bright Market, d/b/a Bright Tucker, alleging that the company retaliated against a female employee by subjecting her to scrutiny, discipline, and termination because she filed a charge of discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the employer's actions were intentional and demonstrated a reckless indifference to the worker's protected rights.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought back wages plus interest and compensatory and punitive damages, as well as other relief, including a permanent injunction to prevent the company from engaging in any future retaliation against any person.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in January 2015 and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree, which was entered by Judge Sarah Evans Barker, enjoined the employer from discriminating or retaliating against anyone because of opposition to any practice made unlawful under Title VII, and required the employer to pay $15,000 to the EEOC's attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was for three (3) years following the date of the entry of the decree.[SENTMARKER]In July 2016, the parties agreed to a joint and severally liable for any late or returned check fees, to be paid on a monthly basis.[SENTMARKER]In August 2018, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2005 a group of former employees of the Boeing Company filed suit in the United States District Court of Kansas against the Boeing Company (Boeing), Spirit Aerosystems Inc. (Spirit), the Onex Corporation (Onex) and Midwestern Aircraft (Midwestern).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive and monetary relief as well as class certification, alleging pattern or practice of age discrimination, disparate impact and disparate treatment by the defendants during the layoff and rehire process, in connection with Boeing's sale of its commercial airplane manufacturing facilities to Onex.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought eight claims, two of which were dismissed during the pleading stage, five were dismissed as the District Court granted summary judgment in the defendants' favor in two separate opinions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the 10th Circuit Court, but the 10th Circuit affirmed the lower court's decisions.[SENTMARKER]The remaining claim in the case after the Circuit Court decision was the plaintiffs' ADEA claim of disparate treatment.[SENTMARKER]A number of individual plaintiffs settled with defendants.[SENTMARKER]After the plaintiffs failed to appear at a hearing on a motion to dismiss, Judge Melgran granted the motion.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed on February 9, 2015, and the appeal was dismissed on June 16, 2015 for failure to prosecute.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 2006, a group of former Boeing employees filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Kansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Age Discrimination In Employment Act (ADEA) and the Employment Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) by terminating and failing to rehire employees over the age of forty when they sold their commercial airplane manufacturing facilities in Wichita, Kansas and Tulsa, Oklahoma to Spirit AeroSystems, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The defendants required Boeing employees to sign a "Consent to Release 5 Personnel Information" form, which violated the ADEA and the Older Workers Benefit Protection Act (OWPCPA), and the OWPCPA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In February 2001, the EEOC brought this Title VII sex discrimination action against the Jonesboro Manufacturing Company on behalf of an employee who claimed that a male coworker repeatedly made inappropriate sexual comments to her, and after she complained nothing was done.[SENTMARKER]The defense immediately filed a motion to dismiss for failure to timely serve the summons and complaint.[SENTMARKER]While this motion was pending, the EEOC voluntarily dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 1996, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District Of Louisiana against Jonesboro Manufacturing Company, Inc., a Monroe, Louisiana-based manufacturing company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant had engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex, in violation of Section 703 and 704 of the Title VII Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The defendant had an anti-harassment policy which was maintained in the main plant in Monroe, but all of the sexually offensive actions described herein occurred in the Jonesboro facility.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not take appropriate reasonable steps to prevent the plaintiff from being subjected to illegal harassment.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on October 2.[SENTMARKER]1997 and the defendant agreed to pay the plaintiff and any individuals in like or related situations, including but not limited to lost wages, in amounts to be determined in the course of the proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation claim against Tasa, Inc., (doing business as Orr Minden Country Chevrolet) on behalf of a black employee who had a pending race discrimination charge and no discipline or warnings at the time of his firing.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was filed with a joint motion for a consent decree, which the Court (Donald E. Walter) approved on November 11, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the decree provided for damages ($60,000 to the employee) and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties bore their own costs.[SENTMARKER]Under the decree, Tasa, Inc., had to provide annual Title VII training to all employees in Louisiana, to post an EEOC poster in a conspicuous location, to report to the EEOC annually the date, attendees, and subject matters of the Title VII trainings, and to institute and follow a promotion policy.[SENTMARKER]The promotion policy required that all vacant positions be posted before an employee is promoted to the positions, that all qualified candidates be interviewed, and that all applications, resumes, and interview notes be maintained.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired automatically after three years.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 17, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana against Tasa, Inc. d/b/a Orr Minden Country Chevrolet, a Louisiana corporation doing business as Orr Minden Chevrolet, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging an African American employee in retaliation for filing a charge of discrimination with the Commission.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that David Thompson was unlawfully discharged by Tasa because of his race, and that his discharge was motivated by the retaliatory animus of its owner Larry Coker.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which Tasa agreed to pay Thompson injunctive relief and to implement an anti-retaliation training program for all of its officials, managers, supervisors, and employees.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to post all vacant positions before promoting any employee to the position, and to institute and follow promotion policies and procedures pursuant to which, for the duration of this Decree, it shall: (i) post each vacant position before promotion to a permanent position; .[SENTMARKER](ii) post all positions before promotions to permanent positions; and (iii) provide the employee with a copy of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree remained in force for three years after the date of the entry of this consent decree, and the parties agreed not to appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 31, 2004.

gold_sents: On April 13, 2015, a transgender man who was fired when he refused to sign an agreement to present and be treated as a woman at work as a condition of his employment filed a Title VII sex discrimination claim in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC later intervened in the case.[SENTMARKER]District Judge Carl Barbier directed the parties to arbitrate the case pursuant to an arbitration agreement between the plaintiff and his employer.[SENTMARKER]After the conclusion of the arbitration, which yielded monetary relief for the individual plaintiff, the EEOC continued to litigate the case to obtain injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Judge Barbier entered an 18-month consent decree which required the defendant retrain its employees and post notice of what constitutes a violation of equal employment opportunity policies.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana on December 10, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant, First Tower loan, LLC, violated Title VII by terminating a transgender employee because of his sex, in violation of Title VII and the Louisiana Employment Discrimination Law.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed not to discriminate on the basis of gender identity, transgender status, or sex stereotyping.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Carl Barbier on December 5, 2015 and required the defendant to comply with the terms of the decree for 18 months.[SENTMARKER]During the term of the consent decree, the parties were required to pay the EEOC's costs and attorney's fees incurred in this action.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by Judge Barbier, and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On July 8, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, against Avado Brands, Inc, alleging that it violated the terms of a prior Negotiated Settlement Agreement with the plaintiffs due to a racially hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay $9,166.21.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 8, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ( EEOC) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the district of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, from November 1999 to June 2002, a manager at Don Pablo’s Restaurant harassed and discriminated against a female employee on the basis of her race and subjected her to different terms, conditions, and privileges of her employment based on her race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Negotiated Settlement Agreement, which was approved by the bankruptcy court and became effective on or about Decemher 1, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the female employee in the amount of $50,000.00 for her economic losses, compensatory damages and punitive damages, as well as her reasonable attorney's fees and costs and expenses, and such additional relief as the Court deemed just.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the EEOC on July 9, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered by Judge Richard Bennett of the District Court, and the parties entered a consent decree on July 10, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to provide two (2) hours of anti-harassment training to all management employees at its facilities concerning racial discrimination and harassment, prohibition against retaliation, and other laws enforced by the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to post in all or places where notices to employees are customarily posted in the state of Maryland, and to maintain tor two years from the date of posting a copy of the consent decree to its current employment opportunity policy on race harassment and discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the employer to provide each employee with an orientation to its race and national origin harassment and equal employment opportunity policies.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of an African American employee (plaintiff-intervenor), filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Coca-Cola Enterprises, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant did not promote the plaintiff-intervenor because of his race, African American.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to promote the plaintiff-intervenor to a higher-paying position as well as pay him $60,500.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the district of Maryland on December 2000.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant had refused to promote Mark Mason to the position of Field Service Manager in the Baltimore/Washington Cooler Service Department because of his race, African-American.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly discriminated on the basis of race in the wages and other compensation and benefits that were paid to Mr. Mason.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the defendant entered a consent decree with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Benson Everett Legdale and was effective for three years from the date of entry of this decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to pay compensation to the plaintiff and to provide training for all managers above the grade 15 level in the cooler service department.[SENTMARKER]The parties also entered a final judgment in favor of the defendant, which was approved by Judge Legdale.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment did not require any further enforcement of the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the parties entered a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement did not include any monetary relief.

gold_sents: The case was brought by African American employees of Friedman's, a jewelry store, and sought equitable and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged they had suffered from working in a racially hostile work environment and alleged that Friedman's had engaged in a pattern and practice of racial discrimination in hiring, promotion, compensation, and other terms and privileges of employment.[SENTMARKER]The case was finally settled on February 12, 2009, after Friedman's had entered into bankruptcy two times.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs and class members received over a million dollars for costs with a portion to cover attorneys' fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 6, 2003, African American employees of Friedman's, Inc. filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under the Civil Rights Act of 1866 against St. Paul Mercury Insurance Company (St. Paul) alleging racial discrimination in employment practices of the insurance company.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and permanent injunctions, injunctive relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in November 2005, but the parties failed to reach a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On January 14, 2005, the parties filed a bankruptcy petition in the Southern District of Georgia and the case was administratively closed in order to allow parties to pursue settlement agreements.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, 2003, the plaintiffs filed this class action suit, alleging a pattern of discriminatory employment practices against African Americans and African American applicants who applied for employment at the company in any retail store or in the store organization between March 6, 1999 and December 9, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged in mediation before the court, but the mediation failed to produc a settlement that included the insurer's allegedly discriminatory practices.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a settlement in which the insurer agreed not to discriminate on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on January 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the insurer on March 26, 2006, and the insurer filed a Chapter 11 petition on January 28, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The bankruptcy case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 9, 2017, three transgender individuals filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia alleging that the government's new transgender policy violated their equal protection rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of the Accession and Retention Directives and the Sex Reassignment Surgery Directives.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs' cross-motions for summary judgment and remanded for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On January 4, 2019, the Ninth Circuit vacated the district court's preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court granted the defendants' motion to stay the nationwide effect of the injunction pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court's decision was consistent with the Court of Appeals's ruling in Karnoski v. Trump, which held that a stay of the preliminary injunction would upend, rather than preserve, the status quo.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit remanded the case to the District Court to consider the merits of the defendants’ motion to dissolve the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The District Court agreed with the plaintiffs, finding that the defendants had established a likelihood of success on the plaintiffs’ equal protection claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, three Pocomoke City, Maryland police officers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they suffered racial discrimination and retaliation by their employer in violation of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights and the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, two of the officers reached a partial settlement with Pocomoke City requiring adoption of anti-discrimination policies and procedures by the police department and awarding monetary damages to the officers.[SENTMARKER]As of September 30, 2020, the case is still ongoing pending a final settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2016, the EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of the Maryland against the City of Worcester County, the Worcester County Sheriff's Office, and the State of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Title VII by unlawfully terminating their African American patrolman from his position as a patrolman and by retaliating against African American officers who complained of racial harassment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was entered into with the consent of the parties, on January 20, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and other costs.[SENTMARKER]The decree also prohibits the defendants from discriminating on the basis of race, and requires them to provide a neutral reference to any potential employer that contacts the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII racial-harassment and retaliation suit against A & R Truss Company for violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.).[SENTMARKER]Alleging that Defendant had repeatedly subjected a black employee at the New Buffalo facility to racially offensive epithets and had met the employee's complaints with threats and intimidation, the EEOC sought monetary and injunctive relief, including compensation for emotional harm and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a one-year consent decree that provided monetary and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The employee received $20,000.[SENTMARKER]A & R Truss was subject to an array of anti-harassment, anti-retaliation, training, policy, and notice provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (" EEOC") filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant, AR Truss Company, engaged in unlawful employment practices or otherwise ratified such practices which violated Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendant agreed to pay $25,000.00 in alleged non-pecuniary damages and to develop a policy which complies with the anti-harassment provisions of Title VII and its prohibitions against discrimination based on race and other protected status.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendant to provide training to its current managers, and any new managers hired during the effective dates of this Decree, on Title VII, as amended and its prohibited harassment based on the race and protected status, and to post a notice in a conspicuous place which sets forth an employee's rights regarding the federal anti-discrimination laws.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant was required to pay the EEOC's costs of this action.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on March 2, 2006, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In December 2013, the EEOC brought this suit against Guardsmark, LLC for discharging its employee who opposed sexually inappropriate conduct in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in September 2016, which provided Guardsmark would not retaliate against employees, would train employees on retaliation and sexual harassment, and Guardsmark would pay 115,000 in monetary relief to plaintiff-intervenor.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 24, 2013, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against Guardsmark, LLC, a security company that provides security services to General Dynamics Land Systems, Inc., alleging Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII) violations.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Guardsmark unlawfully discharged employee Christopher Smith by discharging him in retaliation for his opposing sexually inappropriate conduct in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought monetary compensation for Smith, including back pay and compensatory damages for emotional distress, as well as punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which Guardsmark agreed not to retaliate against an employee who has made an internal complaint of employment discrimination or to withhold any amounts from payment of compensatory damages or attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Victoria A. Melonie on July 9, 2014 and is scheduled to expire on September 6, 2017.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed an age discrimination action against Seagate US, LLC. Plaintiffs alleged that they were terminated under false pretenses.[SENTMARKER]Upon termination, plaintiffs were forced to sign a release of liability, stating that they would not bring action against Seagate.[SENTMARKER]The court declared that the Releases offered to those Plaintiffs terminated pursuant to the 2004 RIF ("reduction in force") are invalid as a matter of law.[SENTMARKER]The court declared that the releases signed by Plaintiffs pursuant to the 2004 SIRP ("special incentive retirement plan") were valid, and the claims of those plaintiffs were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]A private settlement was reached on November 15, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on January 26, 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2008, a group of former Seagate employees filed a class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the district of Minnesota.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Seagate engaged in a pattern or practice of age discrimination in connection with terminations, selection process, opportunities for open positions and hiring.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were all over the age of forty when their employment with Seagate terminated in 2004 because of their ages as part of a group termination.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the company required them to waive their rights to file charges with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the Minnesota Department of Human Rights (MDHR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for decertification and dismissed the case with prejudice in part and without costs to either party.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 11, 2006, three employees of Best Buy filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Minnesota.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Best Buy engaged in a pattern or practice of age discrimination against its older employees and other similarly situated employees.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the plaintiffs and others similarly situated were adversely affected by Best Buy's failure to comply with the Older Workers Benefit Protection Act ("OWP Act"), and that the defendants' practices, policies and procedures, in violation of the OWP Act, were willful.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed on August 11, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In December 2004 plaintiff, a quadriplegic who was not hired by defendant, alleged that defendant's employment practices were discriminatory under Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and under Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial and the jury found in favor of the defendant and awarded $11,478.87 in costs against the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff appealed the judgment to the 11th Circuit and on March 13, 2009 the appellate court issued an opinion affirming the lower court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 1, 2004, the EEOC filed this suit against UMB Bank Financial Corporation in the United States District Court for the Western district of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that UMB failed and refused to hire a disabled employee because of his disability.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by failing and refusing to hire the employee for a Customer Service Representative position based on his disability, his perceived disability, and/or his record of disability and instead hired other non-disabled individuals.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment on the issue of whether the EEOC made a good faith effort to conciliate in good faith before filing suit.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for partial summary judgment, finding that the EEOC had not fulfilled its statutory duty to do so.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On September 21, 2007, the EEOC filed a claim in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 on behalf of two aggrieved female employees.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Defendant, Bodega Bars, engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the parties entered into a consent decree that required the Defendant to not engage in sex discrimination or sexual harassment of employees, establish a sexual harassment policy and training program for employees, as well as pay monetary damages to the two aggrieved employees.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumed closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 21, 2007, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against Bodega Bars USA, d/b/a Mosaic Restaurant, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by committing unlawful employment practices with respect to its employees, Aimee Boss and Morgan Hagedon.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Defendant's customer and investor, Andrew Gladney, made unwelcome sexual advances or unwelcome offensive comments of a sexual nature to both of its employees after having been asked to quit making such remarks by management or the employee to whom such remarks were directed.[SENTMARKER]Despite these efforts, Defendant has failed to pay the Plaintiff-Intervenors a total of $10,000, exclusive of interest, owing since March, 2009, in violation of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]On July 2, 2008, the Court entered a Consent Decree requiring Defendant to adopt a sexual harassment policy, post a copy of its policy on the employee bulletin board or similar location in all of its restaurants, create a complaint procedure notice, and provide two hours of sexual harassment training to all new restaurant managers.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was in force for a period of two years from the date of receipt of each complaint, and required the defendant to keep records of any and all internal complaints of possible sexual harassment received during the term of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay $10,000 to each of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to approval by the parties.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation suit against Quik-Chek, Inc. on behalf of a black employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Quik-Chek had fired the employee in retaliation for complaining about racial discrimination and threatening litigation over the discrimination and the company's response to her complaints.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in mediation, which the Court entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree provided $11,500 to the employee and contained an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]Defendant had ceased business operations, and the decree included provisions, such as antidiscrimination training and EEOC reporting, that would activate if Defendant resumed business activities.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2006, the EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of North Carolina against the owner and operator of a chain of convenience stores under the Title VII Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by discharging Wanda Smith in retaliation for her complaints about racial discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed not to discriminate against any person on the basis of race or any other protected category within the meaning of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent decree, the parties agreed to pay Wanda Smith the sum of $11,500.00 in settlement of the claims raised in this action.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to report compliance with Title VII to the EEOC within fifteen days of the entry of this decree by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The term of the decree was five years from its entry by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction of this case for the reason set out in the decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 30, 2006.

gold_sents: In August 2006, the EEOC brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina on behalf of two female employees of Cinelli's restaurant.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the company violated Title VII by subjecting two female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the court entered a default judgment because the defendant failed to respond.[SENTMARKER]The employees were awarded approximately $87,674 in back pay, compensatory damages, and punitive damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 3, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against S.G.T.[SENTMARKER]Cinelli's, Inc., d/b/a Cinelli’s Ristorante, Inc, alleging that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the civil rights act of 1991 by subjecting a class of similarly situated women to a hostile work environment and by constructively discharging them as a result of the harassment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the women were subjected to unwelcome sexual comments and gestures, as well as touching such as hugging, kissing and biting the women's buttocks.[SENTMARKER]The harassment was perpetrated by one of the defendants' managers who was in the women’s direct line of supervision.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought a permanent injunction, damages, injunctive relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: EEOC's Charlotte, NC office filed this lawsuit alleging discrimination based on national origin against the defendant, Sears, Roebuck & Co. in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina (Eastern Division) on 09/16/1998.[SENTMARKER]EEOC alleged on behalf of a job applicant who was a naturalized American of Mexican origin that the defendant refused to hire him because of his national origin and specifically Spanish accent.[SENTMARKER]The district court's granting of summary judgement to the defendant was reversed on appeal.[SENTMARKER]The defendant and the applicant settled and voluntarily dismissed his part of the case, while the EEOC and the defendant entered into a 1-year consent decree, which prohibited national origin discrimination and mandated training and posting of an Equal Employment notice.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 1998, the EEOC filed this suit against Sears, a national retailer, alleging that it failed or refused to hire Francisco G. Santana because of his national origin, Hispanic (Mexican-American) because of discrimination due to national origin.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by failing or refusing to hire Santana.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted Sears's motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to: (a) post an Employee Notice in a place where it is visible to all employees at its Morehead City, North Carolina store; .[SENTMARKER](b) provide annual training to all managers concerning the federal employment discrimination laws; .[SENTMARKER](c) ensure that all managers abide by the requirements of its equal employment opportunity policy; and (d) provide a copy of its nondiscrimination policy at the time of hire or transfer.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit, which remanded the case to the district court for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
