pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2007, the United States filed this complaint in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Middle District (NCMD) in the North Carolina Middle District.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that two female employees of the University's Department of Police and Public Safety (DPPS) were subjecting them to sexual harassment in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was entered on April 28, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (a) the University/NCATSU shall provide, at its own cost, mandatory training on the law of equal employment opportunity and prohibited discrimination based on sex to all supervisory employees in the DPPS, including the Chief, Majors, Captains, Lieutenants, Sergeants, and Sergeants; .[SENTMARKER](b) the parties agreed not to provide negative employment references for the complainants to any future prospective employer that inquires about their employment in the Department; .[SENTMARKER](c) the defendants would not deduct its share of taxes, if any, from the monetary awards; and (d) the defendant would post all General Orders pertaining to complaints and investigations of sexual harassment to its DPPS employees.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in September 2008.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay a total of $266,000 in damages to each of the two complainants.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in December 2005.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation suit against Blackwell's Book Services on behalf of a black employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the employee was  abruptly fired in retaliation for passing on complaints of racial discrimination and harassment and in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.).[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought its costs and monetary and injunctive relief for the employee, including a retaliation prohibition, back pay, job search expenses, compensation for emotional harm, and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The employee intervened, bringing claims for hostile work environment, impairment of contract, and violation of New Jersey law.[SENTMARKER]The employee later dismissed her claims voluntarily, and the EEOC and Blackwell's entered a settlement agreement, which the Court entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the2-year decree, the employee received $65,000, and Balckwell's was subject to an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this suit on behalf of an African American employee in the United States District Court for the District of the New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by firing the employee when she complained about racial harassment by a white supervisor at the defendant's facility.[SENTMARKER]The defendant denied the EEOC's allegations.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by Judge Wolfson on May 2005.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to pay monetary relief to the plaintiff, provide training to its employees, maintain records of all actions it took to prevent discrimination at its facilities, work sites, and contract sites during the term of the decree, and provide the EEOC with copies of all written materials provided to at least two of its employees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered into in May 2005.[SENTMARKER]On May 2005, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 2006 and the parties agreed to settle the case on November 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2004, the plaintiff filed this class action lawsuit in the Eastern District of New York on behalf of all Hispanic and/or non-white refreshment concession personnel who were hired, employed or offered employment by the defendants, Restaurant Associates and RA Tennis Corp.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants engaged in unlawful employment discrimination on the basis of national origin and race respecting the assignment of positions and locations to food vendors employed at the U.S. Open Tennis Tournament.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that the defendants were deliberately and overwhelmingly assigning beer wagons to non-Hispanic white people over other demographics.[SENTMARKER]The parties soon reached a settlement which was approved by U.S. District Court Judge Robert M.[SENTMARKER]Levy, and Restaurant Associates agreed to pay damages.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In December 2017, a group of African American employees of the Fire Department of New York (the "FDNY") filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the New York, alleging that the FDNY discriminated against African Americans and Hispanics in the hiring, placement, advancement, and compensation decisions.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that FDNY's practices for screening and selecting applicants for entry-level firefighter positions discriminated against black and Hispanic applicants under a disparate impact theory.[SENTMARKER]Two years later, in 2015, the parties entered into a settlement concerning both monetary relief and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]In September 2018, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on the pattern-or-practice claims, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the plaintiff-intervenor, the complainant, filed this class action lawsuit against Pitt-Ohio  Express, Inc., a transport company, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pitt-Ohio discriminated against women by refusing to hire women as truck drivers or dockworkers, in violation of Title VII 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2008, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiff-intervenor and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $265,000 in monetary relief and  $305,000 in attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]That same month, the court approved a consent decree between EEOC and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]This decree required the defendant to pay $$2,430,000 to EEOC (to be distributed to women that were affected by the defendant’s discrimination), to adopt anti-discrimination policies, to offer driver and/or dockworker positions to the women that were discriminated against, and regularly report to the EEOC to ensure compliance.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against Pitt Ohio Express, LLC ("Pitt Ohio") alleging that Pitt Ohio violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII") by failing to hire a qualified female applicant for a truck driver position at its Cleveland, Ohio terminal.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that since September 1, 1997, Pitt Ohio refused to hire or offer to hire female applicants based on their sex.[SENTMARKER]Pitt Ohio also allegedly failed to comply with Title VII's hiring practices and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on October 8, 2008 pursuant to a consent decree between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires Pitt Ohio to: (i) provide EEOC with a training proposal within 30 days of the date of this decree; .[SENTMARKER](ii) conduct a thorough investigation of its hiring practices; .[SENTMARKER](iii) provide the EEOC with written notice to any potential purchaser of its business, or of any potential successor of this action; and (iv) incorporate into its personnel policies and procedures an equal opportunity component.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are and shall be binding upon Pitt Ohio.

gold_sents: In August 2001, the Cleveland District Office filed this lawsuit against Sundance Rehabilitation Corporation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, the Equal Pay Act of 1963, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint specifically alleged that the defendant required terminated employees to sign a waiver of claims against the defendant, including EEO violations, in order to receive severance pay.[SENTMARKER]Following discovery and motions for summary judgment for both parties, the District Court granted summary judgment to the EEOC in July 2004.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in September 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals reversed the District Court's judgment in October 2006.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted an extension of time to file a petition for a writ of certiorari in June 2007.[SENTMARKER]However, the docket does not indicate that this option was exercised.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 1, 1999, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit against SunDance rehabilitation Corporation in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that SunDance violated the antiretaliation provisions of Title VII and the ADA by requiring employees fired in a reduction in force to waive their rights to file an EEOC charge and to participate in EEOC proceedings as a condition of receiving severance pay.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment in favor of the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, SunDance appealed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the EEOC, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2007 the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio to enforce Title VII, 42 U.S.C. §2000e, et seq.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]asked the court for injunctive and compensatory relief, alleging the defendant had violated Title VII by discriminating against two employees in the defendant's police department on the basis of their race (white) in termination of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement and the Court entered a three year consent decree on May 23, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to implement new policies to deal with racial discrimination complaints and provide mandatory nondiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individuals were to receive monetary awards, and one of them receive reinstatement.
pegasus_output_sents: In July 2006, the United States filed this suit against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio, alleging that the defendant had discriminated against two former police officers on the basis of their race.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) on behalf of the EEOC and the Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in July 2006 to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to: (a) report to the EEOC any complaint of discrimination or retaliation made by any individual pursuant to its written policies and procedures; .[SENTMARKER](b) take appropriate action to remedy the effects of its discrimination against the two former officers; .[SENTMARKER](c) provide the EEOC with a copy of the defendant's policy and procedures that prohibit employment discrimination; and (d) pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Donald C. Nugent of the Northern District Court of Ohio on July 24, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case without further order of the court, and the case was closed on July 31, 2006.

gold_sents: On December 9, 2011, an openly gay former employee of Ohio Bell Telephone Company filed suit in U.S District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging that he had been dismissed in violation of the ADA, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, and multiple sections of Ohio's Civil Rights Act. Plaintiff took his husband's last name after the couple was married in Massachusetts and had AIDS and alleged he was fired for those reasons.[SENTMARKER]The court denied Defendant's motion to dismiss and the case settled in September 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: In February 2012, a former Ohio Bell employee filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, alleging discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (OCRA), Title VII, and gender discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Ohio Bell violated the OCRA by terminating the employee when he missed work for his father's funeral.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiff's claims, arguing that there was no evidence that the employee's termination was based on his gender, and that his termination was unrelated to his disability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion, finding that the plaintiff was not entitled to a presumption that the defendant discriminated against him or her because he is homosexual.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted Ohio Bell's motion for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 18, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice ("D.O.J.")[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the City of Sulphur in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma alleging that the City discriminated against a Mexican-American employee on the basis of his national origin, when it failed or refused to promote him and took no action to remedy the effects of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]sought injunctive and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On February 23, 2001, the Court entered a consent decree, containing injunctions on discrimination and retaliation, with orders to the defendant to implement a nondiscriminatory policy and antidiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individual received $45,000.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired after five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 21, 2001, the EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma against the city of Sulphur, Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the city violated Title VII by failing or refusing to hire or promote a city employee on the basis of his national origin, Mexican-American, when the employee was denied a promotion to the position of Sanitation Department Superintendent.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was entered by Judge Frank H. Seay on February 26, 2001.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the city to comply with the terms of Title VII and to pay the EEOC's costs and expenses, including attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered with the consent of the parties, and the parties agreed that this action would be settled by appropriate consent decree without the burden of litigation.

gold_sents:
On November 3, 2003, African-American employees of Kraft Foods filed a lawsuit against their employer in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. 2000e, contending that Kraft had discriminated with regard to discipline and hiring.[SENTMARKER]

The court approved a preliminary settlement agreement on May 1, 2007 in which Kraft agreed to pay $1.325 million and grant other forms of non-monetary relief.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 1999, a former employee of Kraft Foods' Philadelphia Bakery filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that Kraft Foods discriminated against African-Americans with respect to job discipline and classification, and that the Plaintiff was under-represented in the Philadelphia Bakery's higher-paying skilled jobs.[SENTMARKER]In December 2006, the Plaintiff and the Plaintiff's union filed a settlement agreement in the Court.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the Plaintiff will be required to submit a report to the Court detailing how it has improved its anti-discrimination policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The Court will also require the Plaintiff to submit to the court a copy of the audit of the Philadelphia bakery's Affirmative Action Programs, racial diversity, equal pay, and disciplinary measures regarding minority employees, and specifically, African American personnel.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the Court will dismiss the case with prejudice, except to the extent necessary to effect the settlement.

gold_sents: Four plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, filed a lawsuit against Latrobe Specialty Steel Company for violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).[SENTMARKER]All four plaintiffs were over the age of fifty and were terminated following the discovery of inappropriate emails on their work email accounts.[SENTMARKER]Despite the plaintiffs' claims that the emails were a pretext for age discrimination, the court held that there was no evidence that but for their ages, the plaintiffs would not have been terminated.[SENTMARKER]Thus, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant, which was affirmed by the appellate court.[SENTMARKER]Taxation was assessed against the plaintiffs in the amount of $21,863.88.
pegasus_output_sents: October 2007 | U.S. District Court | Western District of Pennsylvania ||| Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) ||| 2010 ||| Latrobe Steel Company (LSS)<n>In October 2007, a group of former Latrobe employees filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that LSS discriminated against them because of their age by terminating them for sending sexually explicit emails on company time and equipment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of LSS, concluding that the plaintiffs had failed to demonstrate that "but for [sic] their ages," LSS would not have terminated their employment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court vacated the summary judgment and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This sexual harassment case was brought by the Memphis office of the EEOC in 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case was resolved by Consent Decree in November 2007 which provided individual relief and also required anti-discrimination training, posting of policies and reports to the EEOC.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 5, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against A&I Products, Inc. (A&I) on behalf of two female employees, Ann Boyd and Jennifer Wilson, who were subjected to sexual harassment by a co-worker and retaliated against them after Boyd filed a charge of discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the two women were subject to unwelcome sexual harassment because of their sex and that the harassment created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2007, the district court granted summary judgment on the EEOC's retaliation claim, but the EEOC appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, which overturned the decision.[SENTMARKER]On December 7, 2007, the parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed to implement a series of corrective measures.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay a total of $15,000 to each of the two plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to create an anti-harassment and anti-retaliation training program for all employees at the defendant's Memphis facility.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 7, 2007.

gold_sents: The Memphis Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Paramount Staffing, Inc. in September 2006 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee (Memphis).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination and retaliation based on race (African American) and national origin (American).[SENTMARKER]The parties settled out of court on a two-year consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 19, 2010, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit against Paramount Staffing, Inc., a Memphis-based temporary staffing agency.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Paramount discriminated against African-American and Hispanic employees by failing to place them into temporary positions because of their race and national origin, and by retaliating against one employee who complained about the discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the court on August 19, 2010.[SENTMARKER]As part of the decree, Paramount agreed to post its hiring and placement policies in English and Spanish, post a neutral reference to any potential employer of Earnestine Toler who may request a job reference, and to provide training to management employees to ensure that its work environment is free of discrimination in any form.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Paramount will not retaliate against any employee who participated in the EEOC’s investigation or who otherwise may complain about any discrimination in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The decree will remain in effect two (2) years from the date of entry.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) brought this suit against Sharp Manufacturing Company in the U.S. District for the Western District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sharp violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to provide the complainant with reasonable accommodation and discharged her because of her disability.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief as well as punitive damages against the defendant.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the court approved the parties’ consent decree.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of one year and instructed the defendant to: refrain from unlawful employment discrimination and retaliation; report to the EEOC on compliance with Title VII; revise its policies on reasonable accommodations; post notices of this agreement in their offices; pay $30,000.00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 26, 2004, the EEOC filed this suit against Sharp Manufacturing Company of America, a division of Sharp Electronics Corporation, in the United States District Court for the Western district of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Sharp violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 by failing to provide an employee with a reasonable accommodation and discharging her because of her disability, osteoarthritis.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed that Sharp would not engage in any employment practice which has the purpose or effect of discriminating against any individual on the basis of their disability.[SENTMARKER]The decree required Sharp to post a notice at its Memphis facility for an extended period of time containing the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge S. Thomas Anderson on January 23, 2009 and is being posted as part of the remedy agreed to between Sharp and the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]On January 23, 2009, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by Judge Anderson.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, Sharp filed a dispositive motion to the extent that no ADA claim was permitted on the grounds that the employee was substantially limited in her ability to walk and that Vaughn was not otherwise qualified to be a casual employee.

gold_sents: On January 22, 2004 a group of Fairfield Resorts employees filed this class action lawsuit against Cendant Corporation, Fairfield Resorts, and 15 individuals working at Fairfield Resorts in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were filing suit over alleged sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation they experienced on the job.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2005, Judge William J. Haynes approved a consent decree granting monetary relief to plaintiffs and other female employees.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 2004, six former and current female employees of Fairfield Resorts, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division, alleging sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Tennessee Human rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to sexual harassment and gender discrimination in the workplace, and that the defendants retaliated against them by demoting them to positions in which their monthly income was significantly reduced, by denying them promotions for which they were qualified, and by subjecting them to other adverse terms and conditions of employment.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint, which was dismissed by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $50,000.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the defendants to publicize in each of its work locations the specific identity of the individual(s) to whom any complaints of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation can be made.[SENTMARKER]In the event that the parties do not mutually agree to mediate the dispute, then either party may apply to the Court for appropriate relief to enforce the provisions of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree were not to exceed $50,000.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2006, The Dallas District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of U.S. Concrete, Inc. under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. On April 3, 2008, Judge Reed O'Connor approved a consent decree over the remaining claim that the defendant had violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay the complainant $50,000 in backpay, conduct ADEA training for its employees for two years, and post a notice about federal anti-discrimination employment laws.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2006, the EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Texas against Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a Dallas-based concrete company, alleging that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 ("ADEA"), as amended, when it terminated an employee because of his age and failed or refused to rehire him on this basis.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed not to appeal the summary judgment ruling on the EEOC's ADA claims until the term of the consent decree expired in two years.[SENTMARKER]As part of this consent decree, the parties also agreed to pay $50,000 to the EEOC for its costs associated with this action, including attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered on April 17, 2006, and the parties were notified that this case has settled.

gold_sents: On November 9, 1999, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Texas, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, as amended, against Parfumes De Couer Limited, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought reinstatement of the applicant, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant fired the complainant based on her sex because she was pregnant.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2001, the District Court entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $5,000.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas on March 26, 2001 against Parfumes de Couer Ltd., Inc., a Dallas, Texas-based fragrance company.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by discharging a female employee based on her sex, female, and because of her pregnancy.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to implement policies and practices that provide equal employment opportunities for all of its female employees, and eradicate the effects of the defendant's past and present unlawful practices.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Sidney A. Fitzwater and is subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On September 19, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a black employee, filed a lawsuit in the Western District Court of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge David Briones) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the plaintiff-intervenor $84,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 19, 2002, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company (hereafter "Union Pacific"), alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII") by discharging an African American employee who had a felony conviction in the seven year period preceding their application for employment and who did not disclose that information in their application.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay $84,000 to the charging party, who had been reinstated to his job (without back pay) through defendant's internal complaint process approximately 20 months after his discharge.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also enjoined the defendant from retaliating in any manner whatsoever against any employee employed by the Railroad in the El Paso, Texas Transportation Department for opposing any employment practice made unlawful by Title VII.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant was required to mail or e-mail copies of its Equal Employment Opportunity policies to its management and supervisory employees in the transportation department for the duration of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendant was also required to provide training to its managers and supervisors that explains the damaging effects of race discrimination and retaliation.

gold_sents: This class action suit was filed on January 12, 2006, under 38 U.S.C. § 4301, et seq. ("USERRA") in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff class consisted of all past and present pilots of American Airlines who are or were members of the United States Armed Services and who took military leave from January 2001 to 2006.[SENTMARKER]They asked the court for injunctive and declaratory relief, alleging that American Airlines had violated USERRA by discriminating against pilots who took military leaves of absence.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that they were unfairly charged fewer "in service" days which prevented them from bidding on a number of benefits including flight schedules, paid vacation time, and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]Pilots who had taken comparable types of non-military leave were not similarly penalized.[SENTMARKER]After filing two amended complaints, and the court denying the defendants' second motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs motion to certify class, preliminarily approve settlement agreement, and approve forms of class notice.[SENTMARKER]This motion was granted by U.S. District Court Judge Barbara M.G.[SENTMARKER]Lynn in a final order on August 1, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 2001, three former American Airlines pilots filed this class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Northern District Of Texas against American Airlines, Inc. and the Allied pilots Association.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that American had violated the Uniformed services Employment and reemployment rights act by denying them the ability to bid on flight schedules based on their seniority status and to earn other employment benefits, including paid vacation time and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, from 2001 through 2002, American Airlines placed pilots who took military leave on "leave of absence" status pursuant to the 1997 Collective bargaining agreement negotiated by American and the Association, which represented American's pilots.[SENTMARKER]Without denying the plaintiffs' claims, American Airlines required each pilot to credit each pilot with five hours of sick leave for each month the pilot was "in service" during the year.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the collective bargaining agreement effectively denied the pilots' ability to bidding on flights based on seniority and earned vacation time.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 28, 2008, and the parties entered into a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required American Airlines to comply with the provisions of the Collective Bargaining agreement and to pay the plaintiffs in full.[SENTMARKER]The judgment also required the plaintiffs to pay their attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of Washington, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended by Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Huntwood Industries, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant subjected the plaintiff-intervenor to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, female, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge Frederick Van Sickle) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $100,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of Washington against T R A Industries, Inc., a Spokane, Washington-based manufacturer of custom cabinets.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by subjecting a female employee to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to implement a series of corrective and preventive measures to further the objectives of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to develop and implement an anti-discrimination and anti-sexual harassment policy and manual on discrimination and harassment, to provide equal employment opportunities for all 25 employees, and to provide a discrimination-free work environment for its employees.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to pay $100,000 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendant on August 20, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In March 2002, the Seattle District Office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Laidlaw Inc., a school bus company, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington for alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complainant intervened in May 2002, alleging that the defendant violated the Washington Law Against Discrimination and state tort law by discriminating against her on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial in June 2003.[SENTMARKER]The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on their federal and state law claims and in favor of the defendant with regard to punitive and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded $3,029.78 in economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed in September 2004, but the appeals were dismissed in October 2004.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against Laidlaw Transit, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Laidlaw Education Services Corp., alleging Title VII violations.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Laidlaw violated Title VII by discriminating against female employees on the basis of their sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated to the dismissal of these appeals, and the case was settled on April 1, 2004.[SENTMARKER]On April 1, 2004, the jury found in favor of the EEOC and awarded the plaintiff $3,78 economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages with costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: In June 2006, the EEOC filed suit in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the restaurant chain International House of Pancakes (IHOP), its former president, and another company that together with IHOP operated restaurants throughout Illinois and Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e) and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (42 U.S.C. § 1981a) on behalf of two female employees and similarly situated employees of the Defendants.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the Defendants engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex and retaliation, and that they had subjected female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the jury held for the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the parties settled, and the Court approved a Consent Decree/Settlement Agreement (lasting 2 years) that awarded monetary damages to two female claimants and promised injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2007, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on behalf of two female servers at an International House of Pancakes (IHOP) franchise in Racine, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the servers were sexually harassed in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.  2000e et seq., when an assistant manager at the IHOP restaurant subjected them to a sexually hostile working environment based on their gender.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, Management Hospitality of Racine, Inc. d/b/a IHOP, and Salauddin Janmohammed, were found to have violated Title VII by allowing the work environment to exist at any restaurant at which they provided management consulting services.[SENTMARKER]The jury found in favor of the two servers on the hostile work environment claim, and the defendants agreed to pay $50,000 as damages to Ms. Michelle Powell.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Flipmeastack was ordered to create a new sexual harassment training program for all employees under its direct or indirect supervision that emphasizes the responsibility of supervisors to prevent and correct promptly and sexually harassing behavior.[SENTMARKER]The company was also ordered to post, at all restaurants that it manages, a toll-free number for harassment and discrimination complaints by employees and a written anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policy.

gold_sents: Five non-profit organizations focused on environmental justice filed this lawsuit against the Environmental Protection Agency for failing to issue preliminary findings in Title VI complaints.[SENTMARKER]Judge Armstrong granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss with regard to each individual claim addressing a specific complaint in which the EPA failed to issue preliminary findings.[SENTMARKER]Judge Armstrong granted the defendant's motion to dismiss with regard to the claim that the EPA's pattern and practice of failing to issue preliminary findings violated the APA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered settlement talks which have, as of October 2019, been unsuccessful, and the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2016, the San Francisco District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in a Title VI suit brought by the Sierra Club and California Air Resource Board (CRB).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the EPA violated Title VI by permitting an oil-refinery expansion in a low-income and African American community in Beaumont, Texas, without examining possible disparate impacts on the basis of race and ethnicity and by conducting the permitting process in a manner hostile to Spanish-speaking residents.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the EPA's motion to dismiss for lack of standing, and the parties engaged in extensive settlement discussions, which were ultimately unsuccessful.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the EPA agreed to conduct an environmental impact assessment of the facility's impact on the community.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the district court and the case was closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In July 2013, a private Christian college and a Christian university filed this lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Iowa against the Departments of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Department of Labor (DOL) alleging that the 2010 ACA's contraceptive mandate violated their religious rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the mandate required the schools to provide free coverage of certain contraceptive services, including so-called emergency contraceptives that cause early abortions, to their employees and their dependents.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that each time their claims were rejected each time, the schools had to seek an accommodation from the government.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the schools' request for a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of the mandate and the accommodation process, and enjoined the government from enforcing the mandate against any insurance issuers and third-party administrators offering health insurance to the schools.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the district court's decision, and the case was remanded to the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts on May 16, 2005 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the department's provision of more than a million dollars of public funds to a ministry called "The Silver Ring Thing" (SRT) that uses federal abstinence education funding to bring "unchurched" students to Jesus Christ constituted an unlawful establishment of religion and a governmental endorsement and preference for religion in general and specific tenets of the ministry in particular.[SENTMARKER]The ministry developed a three hour presentation that was meant to occur directly following a mandatory abstinence education assembly in public schools and which, according to the plaintiff, was "permeated with religion."[SENTMARKER]In a two-year settlement agreement entered on February 22, 2006, the defendants acknowleged that they had terminated the SRT grant effective January 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The agreement provided that defendants would not fund SRT's abstinence eduction as it had been structured and implemented during the fiscal year 2005, that strict requirements would be made before considering funding any future proposals from SRT, and that extensive monitoring of SRT's activities would occur if SRT was given a grant.

pegasus_output_sents: February 2010 | First Circuit | U.S. District Court | District of Massachusetts ||| First Amendment | First and Fourth Amendment ||| Massachusetts Civil Rights Act .<n>On February 1, 2010, a Boston resident filed this civil rights lawsuit against the City of Boston and three Boston police officers in the United States District Court for the District of the Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights under the Massachusetts Civil rights Act by arresting him for recording his oral communications while they were arresting him without his consent or knowledge.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted summary judgment on the grounds that the officer was entitled to qualified immunity based on the absence of a clearly established First Amendment right to videotape police officers on public business.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's decision in favor of the officer.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit held that the First Amendment protected the right to record and display video of police carrying out their duties in a public place.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, and the parties settled the case for $170,000 in damages and legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2012, evangelical Christian business owners filed a RFRA challenge to rules adopted pursuant to the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, arguing that the rules infringed on their religious freedom by requiring them to provide coverage for emergency contraception through their group health insurance plan.[SENTMARKER]In November 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the contraception mandate did not substantially burden the plaintiffs' religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit granted expedited en banc review, and oral arguments occurred on May 23.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, 2013, the 10th Circuit reversed the District Court's injunction denial and sent the case back to the District Court, with instructions to consider two prongs of the injunction inquiry and to rule on the plaintiffs' injunction motion.[SENTMARKER]The next day, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' emergency motion for a temporary injunction pending the full injunction hearing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted cert., and on June 30, 2014, affirmed the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court said other ways were open to the government to reach its asserted interest of ensuring the availability of contraception coverage.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, Hobby Lobby and Mardel filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the Western district of Oklahoma against the federal government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the regulations issued under the Patient Protection Act of 2010 violated their First Amendment rights and their rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA) and the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case was appealed to the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals for the United States.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2013, the Supreme Court reversed the district court's denial of the preliminary injunction and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, a group of religious-based universities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Western District of Oklahoma under the First Amendment, Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against federal government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Affordable Care Act's requirement that employee and student health plans provide coverage of contraception violated their religious foundings.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the Supreme Court granted certiorari on the question of whether the accommodation to the contraceptive services mandate as applied to religious nonprofits violates the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated with six others.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a per curiam order remanding all seven cases to their respective courts of appeals, and ordered that the parties be given time to come to agreement on ensuring contraceptive access without burdening religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]Following revised HHS policies, the District Court permanently enjoined the defendants from forcing religious organizations to provide contraceptive care.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed
pegasus_output_sents: In 2014, the religious non-profit organizations of Oklahoma Baptist and Southern Nazarene filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma challenging the Affordable Health Care Act's mandate that requires health insurance plans to provide free coverage of certain contraceptive services, including so-called emergency contraceptives that cause early abortions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs object to the mandate because they believe that their religious duties include promoting the physical well-being and health of their employees by offering them health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the defendants filed a petition for a writ of certiorari with the Supreme Court to review the Tenth Circuit's decision for contraceptive coverage to which it has religious objections.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the defendants' petition, and the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the government's motion for an injunction, but the parties agreed to stay proceedings until March 1, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, Bishop Zubik, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburg and the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Pittsburg filed a U.S. District Court lawsuit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Government challenging the the contraception mandate of the Affordable Care Act. After the Trump Administration took office, the parties settled and dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2010, Congress enacted the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, Pub L No. 111-148, 124 Stat.[SENTMARKER]1029 (the "ACA" or the "Act"), requiring employers with religious objections to cover certain contraceptive services in their employee health insurance plans.[SENTMARKER]In May 2012, the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh and the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Erie filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Western District, alleging that the Act violated their rights of religious conscience under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 ("RFRA") and the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a preliminary injunction, which was converted to a permanent injunction in one of the cases, and the government agreed to pay $3 million in costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the case was remanded to the Court of Appeals for the Third, Fifth, Tenth, and D C Circuits for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 22, 2013, a group of nonprofit religious organizations filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Administrative Procedure Act and the First Amendment against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]On December 26, 2013, United States District Court (Judge Todd J. Campbell) denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The same day, the plaintiff filed an appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit (No. 13-6640).[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2013, the 6th Circuit affirmed, holding that the ACA did not unlawfully burden the plaintiffs' religion.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded back to the 6th Circuit in light of a Supreme Court case Zubik v. pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, a group of Catholic organizations, including Catholic Charities of Tennessee, Camp Marymount, MQA, St. Cecilia Congregation, and Aquinas College, filed suit in the District Court for the Middle District, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive coverage requirement violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act; the Free Speech, Free Exercise, and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendment; and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The district courts denied the plaintiffs' motions for a preliminary injunction, and the case was remanded to the district court for further consideration in light of the Supreme Court's decision in Hobby Lobby v. gold_sents: On February 1, 2012, Criswell College, an evangelical Protestant college located in Dallas, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas against the Federal Government seeking to enjoin enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage in employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs contend that this mandatory contraception coverage violates their sincerely held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction because it was not ripe for review.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2010, The Criswell College, a Texas non-profit corporation, filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, alleging that the government's mandate under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) violated its First and Fifth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the mandate required the college to provide health insurance coverage for abortion, abortifacients, embryo-harming pharmaceuticals, and related education and counseling, or provide plans that cause access to the same through its insurance company.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the college's group health plan is not grandfathered under the ACA.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2012, the government finalized a rule that imposes a definition of preventive services to include all FDA-approved "contraceptive" drugs, surgical sterilization, and education, and counseling for such services.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the complaint without prejudice, and the case was closed on April 9, 2013 without prejudice.

gold_sents: The lawsuit was based on fair housing testing that DOJ had conducted between July 2008 and January 2009, in which rental agents made a series of racialized remarks, steering white testers away from certain locations, and implying that black applicants were more likely to fail criminal background checks.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2009, the United States Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. §3601, against operators of the Rolling Oaks Apartments, seeking injunctive and monetary relief for race discrimination.[SENTMARKER]After the court (Judge Mark Fuller) denied cross-motions for summary judgment, the matter settled.[SENTMARKER]In February 2011, the Court entered a four-year consent decree enjoining the Defendants from discriminating on the basis of race in the operation of the Rolling Oaks Apartments and ordering  $15,500 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2009, the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the owner, manager, and assistant manager of a residential apartment complex in Clanton, Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race or color, in violation of the Fair Housing Act of 1988 and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 (the "Fair Housing Amendments Act").[SENTMARKER]The defendants allegedly discriminated against qualified applicants or tenants because of their race and/or color by making statements indicating that a sign for a credit check and police background check was adopted to discourage black potential tenants from applying for an apartment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly made statements indicating there was a preference against black tenants at Rolling Oaks Apartments.[SENTMARKER]On February 3, 2011, the defendants entered a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to provide and process rental applications on a non-discriminatory basis and to maintain all rental applications, whether deemed complete or incomplete, and any correspondence about the availability of dwelling units at the apartment complex.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants are required to post an easily readable "For Rent" or "Vacancy" sign or notice at each apartment building in which a dwelling unit is available for rent, and to hold in-person training for all new Management Agents.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of their motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2009 the United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against First United Security Bank under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. claimed that the Bank had engaged in a pattern or practice of home-mortgage lending discrimination against black applicants.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2009 an agreement was entered that required the Bank to change several of its practices and to pay monetary damages to some African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the agreement were satisfied and the case dismissed in April 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2014, the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U,S.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Southern District of Alabama against First United Bank and its subsidiary, First United security Bank, alleging that the defendant charged African-American borrowers higher rates than similarly-situated white borrowers on home mortgage-related loans.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that African-Americans were charged higher rates for first-lien refinance loans originated in 2004 for owner-occupied one-to-four family houses in west central Alabama on an equal basis with majority-white tracts.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendant engaged in a pattern or practice of racial discrimination in the setting of interest rates for the refinance loans by failing to serve the lending needs of majority blacks and whites on equal basis.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed not to discriminate on the basis of race or color in any aspect of a residential real estate-related or credit transaction.[SENTMARKER]The agreement, which is subject to court approval, requires the defendant to post and display in each branch or ofilce a notice of non-discrimination in each of its advertising and promotional materials.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to pay a civil penalty to the United States.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on June 12, 2015.

gold_sents: In November 2011, two undocumented Mexican immigrants and three fair housing groups filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a state statute violated the Fair Housing Act and was preempted by federal immigration law because it required mobile home owners to pay for a government-issued registration while prohibiting undocumented residents from making payments to government officials.[SENTMARKER]Because the law made it illegal to possess a mobile home without registration and because it was illegal for undocumented residents to obtain the registration, the law effectively made such persons homeless.[SENTMARKER]The District Court (Judge Myron H. Thompson) enjoined the State from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed, but the Eleventh Circuit rendered it moot because in May 2012 the Alabama legislature amended the statute to exclude mobile home registration.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case in May 2014, upon stipulation of the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2011, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the State of Alabama, the revenue commissioner for the state, and two individuals for violations of the federal Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that  30 of the Beason-Hammon Alabama taxpayer and citizen protection act, 2011 Alabama, violated the Supremacy Clause and Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, with the order set to expire on December 7, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On December 12, 2011, the defendants filed a motion to dissolve the order, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This case resulted in the largest residential fair lending settlement in U.S. history, with $335 million being paid to compensate African-American and Hispanic borrowers who were allegedly charged more based on their race or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: The Federal Reserve Board and the Department of Justice's Office of Civil Rights today announced a settlement in the federal district court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The settlement, which is subject to court approval, is the first time that the Justice Department has alleged and obtained relief for borrowers who were steered into subprime mortgage loan products while placing non-Hispanic borrowers with similar creditworthiness in prime loans.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Countrywide's policies and practices, as described herein, were intentional, willful, or implemented with reckless disregard for the rights of black and Hispanic borrowers and non-applicant spouses of married mortgage loan applicants.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that these borrowers were charged higher fees and interest rates because of their race or national origin, and not because of the borrowers’ creditworthiness or other criteria related to borrower risk.[SENTMARKER]As a result of this discrimination, the complaint further alleges that qualified African-Americans and Hispanics were placed in subprime loans rather than prime loans even when similarly-qualified non- Hispanic white borrowers received prime loans, and that Countrywide failed to impose meaningful limits or guidelines to stop the discrimination.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the settlement requires Countrywide to implement policies and procedures to prevent discrimination if it returns to the lending business during the next four years.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C.  3601-3619, and the Equal credit Opportunity Act, 15 U.N.C  1691-1691f("ECOA").

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Southern District of California against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc., under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On December 1, 2013, the District Court entered a consent order that prohibited the defendant from discriminating on the basis of race or national origin and required the defendant to  place $3 million into a settlement fund.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016 after the defendant had substantially complied with the consent order.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California entered a consent order against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc., a San Diego-based mortgage lender, for discrimination against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending practices.[SENTMARKER]The consent order, which was entered on December 29, 2016, requires the lender to implement specific, race- and national origin-neutral standards for the assess ment of broker fees on residential real-estate-related loans that the lender underwrote.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay a total of $1 million in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2014, the City of Los Angeles  filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JP Morgan Chase Bank, under Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) and Fair Housing Act/Fair Housing Amendments Act (FHAA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the defendants lending practices were predatory and intentionally discriminated against minority borrowers, and had a disparate impact on minorities.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2015, the plaintiff field an ex parte application to stay the case pending appeal of related action.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, 2015, the case was dismissed as stipulated.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2012, the City of Los Angeles filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JPMorgan Chase Co., JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., Chase Manhattan Bank USA, and Wells Fargo 4 Co. alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by denying credit to certain neighborhoods based on race, color, or national origin in their 27 residential real estate-related lending transactions.[SENTMARKER]The City's damages include lost tax revenues and the need to provide 21 increased municipal services.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed in 2012 to a global settlement with the Department of Justice, HUD, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and the 25 state attorneys general.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, and each party shall bear its own costs, expenses, and attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: This sex discrimination fair housing case was brought by the United States in 2010 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa against the owners of an apartment complex and their manager, alleging sexual harassment by the manager of two female tenants.[SENTMARKER]The women claimed they were subjected to offers of maintenance services in return for sex, pervasive, unwanted touching, gestures and remarks.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff claimed these actions constituted a pattern and practice of sexual discrimination in violation of the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]Though the owners had gone out of business during the course of the litigation, they entered into a five-year Consent Decree that included detailed prohibitions against sex discrimination, should they ever again engage in the business.[SENTMARKER]The manager was forever banned from any job involved in any aspect of the operation of any dwelling.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $80,000 in compensatory damages to aggrieved persons identified by Plaintiff and $15,000 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2011, the United States of America filed this civil action in the Northern district of Iowa against Property Management, L.C., and Elders, Inc. alleging that the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of sex in the rental of residential units at Park Towers Apartments in Waterloo, Towa (''Park Towe rs').[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant's conduct constituted a pattern of discrimination or a den ial of rights to a group of African-American and Hispanic residents of the apartment complex.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to settle the case by entering into a consent order, which required the defendants to adopt a nondiscrimination policy, provide a statement of compliance to the court, and conduct in-person training on Fair Housing.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was entered by Chief Judge Linda R Reade on September 22, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice five years after the date of entry of the consent order.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 22, 2012.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2013, a group of African-American homeowners brought a class action suit in the United States district court for the district of Massachusetts on behalf of themselves and similarly situated homeowners.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of giving mortgage brokers discretion to increase the credit rate above the rate otherwise available to the homeowner resulted in higher mortgage rates for African-Americans than similarly situated white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]Although the policy was neutral, the policy had an adverse effect on African- Americans in that they paid higher discretionary charges on their home loans than did similarly situated whites.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 2007, the district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to pay more than $1 million in disgorgement and injunctive relief to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the final judgment to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal and the case was closed on March 31, 2007.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 29, 2008, the United States brought this civil rights action in the District of Nebraska against the Latvian Tower condominium association and its president, Karl Tegtmeyer.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by adopting and enforcing a Master Deed and By-Laws that prohibited children under the age of 16 from occupying or residing in a condominium unit in Latvian Tower.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the allegations in any manner, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent order on November 12, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The consent order requires the defendants to post a fair housing sign in all common areas of the condominium complex, post a notice that they will not discriminate in any aspect of the sale of dwellings against prospective buyers because of familial status, and to pay the complainants in civil rights fees and court costs.

gold_sents: An association of residents of a New Jersey neighborhood filled a lawsuit claiming that the defendants' redevelopment plan for the Gardens neighborhood represented a violation of the Fair Housing Act and the United States and New Jersey Constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants' redevelopment plan, which razed numerous homes in a minority neighborhood, was discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the District Court's pretrial decision in favor of the town to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which reversed, and found that the plaintiffs were entitled to a trial.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari to review the question whether disparate impact claims were available under the Fair Housing Act.  About two weeks prior to the scheduled argument, the parties settled; the city will construct 44 new homes, 20 for current residents in exchange for allowing redevelopment.[SENTMARKER]Seven households that elected to relocate will be compensated.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2005, a group of residents of a neighborhood in Mount Holly, New Jersey, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of the New Jersey against the Township of Mount Holly alleging that the Township's denial of a building permit for the redevelopment of the neighborhood was racially discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the township's representation that residents who wanted to remain in the neighborhood were minorities and were homeless were not true.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the Township and dismissed the plaintiffs' prerogative writ claims.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the Third Circuit, which reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit held that the District Court had established a prima facie case of disparate impact sufficient to withstand summary judgment, and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the township agreed not to discriminate on the basis of race, color, or national origin.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Low-income minority individuals in need of affordable housing filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the Town of Smithtown, complaining that  Smithtown operated its voucher program with a residency preference that discriminated on the basis of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The court entered an order and final judgment approving the parties' settlement agreement under which the Town of Smithtown agreed to implement an anti-discrimination educational program, to affirmatively market the Section 8 Program to minority persons, to inform the public of its non-discriminatory policies, to maintain and preserve records for purposes of recordkeeping and reporting, and to pay $925,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]This settlement remains in effect until 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2007, a group of African-American and Hispanic residents of Smithtown, New York filed a lawsuit against the Town, alleging that the Town had violated the Fair Housing Act and the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution by using a residency preference for allocation of Section 8 housing vouchers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Smithtown's policies and practices in connection with the Section 8 program discriminated in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the rental of a dwelling because of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the Town agreed to: (i) open its Section 8 waitlist only when there are fewer than 100 applicants on the waitlist; .[SENTMARKER](ii) provide mandatory training to all of its current employees and agents involved with the Program; .[SENTMARKER](iii) make reasonable changes to the content of its promotional materials; .[SENTMARKER](iv) pay a settlement fund to the plaintiffs; and (v) promote the Program to minority applicants.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Joanna Seybert of the District Court for the Eastern District Of New York on December 13, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice as to Smithtown without costs.

gold_sents: On December 06, 2010, the United States filed suit under 42 U.S.C. 3601 of the Fair Housing Act against the owner of the Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Judge Kenneth Karas).[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff, represented by the Untied States Department of Justice asked the Court to 1) declare the Defendant's conduct a violation of the Fair Housing Act, 2) enjoin the Defendant from discriminating on the basis of race in the rental of dwellings, 3) award monetary damages and 4) assess a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the Plaintiff claims the Defendant's rental practices discriminated against African American prospective tenants.[SENTMARKER]On April 4,2012, the parties reached a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant was enjoined from further discriminatory rental practices on the basis of rate, and paid $150,000 in damages and $25,000 as a civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 5, 2010, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit against Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC, d/b/a Burgundy Gardens, alleging that Burgundy Gardens discriminated against African Americans who were seeking rental housing because of race or color.[SENTMARKER]Burgundy Gardens agreed to a consent decree in which it agreed to pay $150,000 to a victim fund that will be available to compensate people who were harmed by the discriminatory rental practices of BURGUNDYS, and to pay a civil penalty of $25,000.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required Burgundy Gardens to implement a Nondiscrimination Policy of Nondiscrimination, educate its employees on federal and state housing discrimination laws, and submit periodic reports to the Government containing information about its rental activity.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on April 16, 2012.

gold_sents: The United States filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act against architects and developers of an apartment building claiming that the defendants designed and constructed the building so that it was inaccessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff entered into two separate three-year consent decrees; one requiring the architect to make all of its future designs compliant with the FHA and to pay a $20,000 civil penalty; the other with the developers requiring extensive retrofits to the building, $60,000 in damages and a $35,000 civil penalty.
