gold_sents: On April 12, 2012, the United States sued GFI Mortgage Bankers under the Fair Housing Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act for charging African American and Hispanic borrowers higher fees and costs for home mortgage loans than it charged similarly situated white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a Consent Decree on August 27, 2012, which required GFI to pay $3.555 million and implement fair lending policies and a fair lending monitoring system.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 2, 2012, the Department of Justice and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit against GFI Mortgage Bankers, Inc., a New York-based mortgage banker, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that GFI engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and national origin by charging African-American and Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates and fees on home mortgage loans compared to similarly-situated non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, GFI's home-loan pricing policy resulted in significant disparities in the cost of home loans between African-Americans and white borrowers between 2005 and 2009.[SENTMARKER]GFI agreed to settle the case by entering into a settlement agreement that requires GFI to adopt policies and procedures that require its employees and agents, in the process of an applicant's selection of a loan product, to explain the benefits and consequences of each loan product discussed.[SENTMARKER]GFI also agreed to develop a fair lending program designed to ensure compliance with the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2014, a non-profit organization that provides housing assistance to formerly incarcerated individuals filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant, who owned and managed a multi-building apartment complex, had a discriminatory policy that unlawfully prohibited anyone with a criminal record from renting an apartment.[SENTMARKER]After years of discovery and litigation, the parties settled for over $1 million.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 1, 2014, The Fortune society filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the defendants in the Fair Housing Act of 1968, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and color at the Sandcastle, a multi-building apartment complex they own and manage in Queens, New York.[SENTMARKER]According to the suit, defendants maintain and enforce a policy of automatically excluding any person with a record of a criminal conviction from renting or living in an apartment at the complex, which causes an unjustified disparate impact on African-American and Hispanic applicants in violation of FHA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also purport to require potential tenants to have a credit score above 600.[SENTMARKER]In August 2015, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of standing, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]In September 2016, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. Spatt granted defendant County's motion for summary judgment dismissing all claims against it.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2014, Judge Spatt issued a final order for the plaintiffs and ordered Defendant Garden City to take a number of steps to prevent discrimination and to increase access to affordable housing.[SENTMARKER]After Judge Spatt's order, both parties appealed the decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed in part and remanded in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is back in the lower courts on remand.[SENTMARKER]On remand, Judge Spatt found that the plaintiffs had met their burden at trial in demonstrating that the Garden City’s proffered reasons for its chosen zoning change could have been met by another practice, such as R-M zoning, that had a less discriminatory effect.[SENTMARKER]Magistrate Judge Arlene R. Lindsay thereafter awarded plaintiffs $5,255,108.94 in attorneys fees and costs from Garden City.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 2019, Judge Spatt signed the parties’ stipulation of discontinuance with prejudice, except without prejudice as to the court’s jurisdiction for the purpose of interpretation or enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the County to pay $5,400,000 to the plaintiffs to be used for the purpose of furthering and promoting mixed-income affordable housing; $120,000 to NYCC to be used for activities related to fair and affordable housing; and $400,000 to plaintiffs’ counsel for attorneys’ fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2005, a non-profit housing developer filed a lawsuit against the Village of Garden City and the Village Board of Trustees alleging that the Village violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, MHANY Management, Inc., alleged that the defendants violated the fair housing law by changing the zoning of a certain area of the village and by failing to provide certain services to its former members.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of standing and failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2016, the Second Circuit affirmed in part and vacated in part the final judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to a settlement.

gold_sents: This 2011 federal fair lending lawsuit in the Western District of Texas was brought by the United States against a local bank the U.S. alleged had engaged in a pattern or practice of providing loans to Hispanics only at higher rates than to non-Hispanics, without justification.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, submitted simultaneously with the complaint, the bank agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure nondiscriminatory pricing, and to numerous other implementation provisions, including fair credit training, systemic monitoring, complaint resolution processes, and $91,000 in damages to aggrieved persons.[SENTMARKER]The provisions of the order were scheduled to last 4 and 1/4 years.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 1974, the United States of America filed this complaint in the United District Court for the Western district of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the bank had engaged in a pattern or practice of lending discrimination on the basis of national origin in the pricing of unsecured consumer loans.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, from at least 2006 through December 31, 2009, the bank charged higher interest rates to Hispanic borrowers as compared to non-Hispanic borrowers.[SENTMARKER]In 2010, the bank agreed to pay $91,600 to compensate for monetary damages that affected persons may have suffered as a result of the alleged violations of the federal fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]The bank also agreed to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans originated by the bank.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval, and the bank has agreed to comply with the terms of the settlement.

gold_sents: The United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity Acts against PrimeLending, claiming that the defendant displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination in lending on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Primelending agreed to refrain from practicing race based discrimination, submit to a monitoring and reporting program, provide borrowers with a general notice of nondiscrimination, provide equal credit opportunity training to its employees, provide a total of $2 million to be distributed among those aggrieved,  allocate any unclaimed portion of the $2 million to organizations that provide general financial education to African-American borrowers, and maintain a complaint resolution program to resolve discrimination claims.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development ("HUD") filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Prime Lending, Inc. ("Prime Lending"), a retail mortgage lender, alleging that Prime Lending discriminated against African-American borrowers by charging them higher interest rates and fees than non-African-Americans.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Defendant's policies and practices violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant agreed to pay $22,000 to the Plaintiff and to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans secured by residential real estate originated by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the Defendant agreed not to charge more than 100 basis points in interest to African-Americans until April 1, 2011 and to pay the Plaintiff $22,000 in compensation.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice at the end of the trial.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2013,  the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis State Bank, alleging that it charged Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to the rates it charged white borrowers, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the District Court (Judge Robert A. Junell) approved a consent order in which the bank agreed to implement a variety of practices to address these alleged violations and to pay damages to aggrieved borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order remained in effect until early 2017.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no substantive docket activity after 2014, the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2011, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ( FDIC) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis state bank.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC alleged that Fort Davis charged higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans to Hispanic borrowers than to similarly situated non-Hispanic white borrowers from January 1, 2008 to December 31, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC also alleged that FDSB did not properly instruct its loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the Bank failed to supervise or monitor the loan officers' performance to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a consent order (Conviction Order) in which FDSB agreed to pay $159,000 to compensate Hispanic borrowers who may have suffered monetary damages as a result of the alleged violations of ECOA and to implement a complaint resolution program to address potential disparities based on national origin in its lending practices.[SENTMARKER]The consent order also required FDSB to provide a notice of non-discrimination that provides substantially the same information as is contained in Appendix A of the Consent Order to its management officials, loan officers, and any other employees or agents who participate in the origination of the Bank's loans covered by this Consent Order.[SENTMARKER]FDSB also agreed to a monitoring program designed to ensure that it is in compliance with the provisions of the consent order.[SENTMARKER]The Court entered a final judgment in favor of FDSB on December 31, 2010, finding that the Bank had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin and ordering it to pay the plaintiffs $159,000 in monetary damages.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.  Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 13, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Wisconsin filed this complaint against Southport Bank in the United States District Court for the District of Milwaukee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that from 2007 to 2008, Southport charged hundreds of African-American and Hispanic wholesale borrowers higher fees than non-Hispanic white borrowers, not as a result of their creditworthiness or other objective criteria related to borrower risk, but because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]Southport's business practice was to allow its mortgage brokers to vary their fees and thus alter the price set based on a borrower's objective credit-related factors.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC found reason to believe that Southport had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by allowing wholesale brokers to charge higher fees for home loans than white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2008, Southport closed ComCor, and Southport did not conduct any type of broker monitoring to determine whether there were disparities between the total fees charged to minority and white borrowers in the home loan market.[SENTMARKER]Southport agreed to settle the case by entering into a consent order in which it agreed to pay a total of $325,000 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was entered by Judge J. Stadtmueller on October 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent order are subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The court will retain jurisdiction for the duration of the order, after which the case shall be dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 26, 1986, a resident of a Connecticut institution for persons with developmental disabilities filed this suit in the District of Connecticut alleging violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the state of Connecticut violated the CRIPA by failing to provide adequate medical care to all of its residents, failing to integrate the institution with the St. Louis School District, and failing to comply with a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court found the defendants in contempt of court for failing to implement the consent decree and ordered the defendants to submit an implementation plan to the court.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, claiming that the court did not have jurisdiction to hear the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2005, and the parties entered into a joint consent decree, which was approved by the court on July 21, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the state to provide all residents with adequate medical and mental health care, integrate the school with the school district, and submit quarterly compliance reports.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2005, the court dismissed the case, finding the state in contempt.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an appeal, and the case was dismissed on June 19, 1996.[SENTMARKER]On June 19, 1996, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The appeal was denied on July 19, 1996.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Disability Rights Washington filed this class action on behalf of individuals with intellectual disabilities in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington in April 2014.[SENTMARKER]They sued the State healthcare authority and department of social services, alleging that budget cuts resulted in inadequate services in violation of the Nursing Home Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement one year later and the final settlement was approved in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is ongoing and under court supervision through September 30, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2014, a resident of a private nursing facility in Washington State filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Secretary of the Washington state Department of social and health services and the director of the state health care authority.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants did not have an adequate system in place for persons with intellectual disabilities and related conditions living in privately-operated nursing facilities to be screened, assessed and/or receive specialized services, in violation of the Medicaid Act and the nursing home reform act (NHRA).[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to implement a pre-Admission Screening and Resident Review (PASRR) system in order to protect residents from languishing in nursing facilities without needed services.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to post the 20 class notice on its website.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a petition for permission to appeal the district court's approval of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the petition for early termination of the agreement and dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 28, 2016.

gold_sents: Individuals with intellectual disabilities residing in the Wyoming State Training School filed this lawsuit in 1990 to challenge conditions at the School and a lack of community placement options.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed in 1991 to a settlement that was designed not only to improve conditions in the institution, but also to prevent unnecessary institutionalization and create options for community living for individuals with intellectual disabilities in Wyoming.[SENTMARKER]The court's jurisdiction was ended in 1994.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 3, 1990, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming against the Wyoming State Training School, the Wyoming Department of Education, and other Wyoming state agencies and officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the rights of individuals with developmental disabilities by failing to provide alternative services for them in their communities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Stipulation Agreement on April 24, 1990.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would engage in good faith negotiations to resolve this dispute.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, 1990, the court certified the class as a class, and the parties agreed to enter into a Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to provide adequate transportation and from school for individuals with disabilities, improve the facilities at the state training school, provide education and related services for those individuals, and create a program to educate other students about disabilities.[SENTMARKER]On October 12, 1994, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into an agreement with the plaintiffs in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered by the court on October 12, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties are currently in negotiations to determine whether the defendants should be released from terms of the consent decree.

gold_sents: These 2007 consolidated cases were brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona to challenge the "Legal Arizona Workers Act", which mandates investigation and prosecution of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens and requires the revocation of the licenses of employers found to have done so.[SENTMARKER]It also makes mandatory a previously voluntary verification process.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings, holding that the Act fell within ICRA's savings clause and thus was not expressly preempted by federal law.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2007, a group of business, labor, and civil rights organizations filed this lawsuit against the state of Arizona, the Arizona Attorney General, the Governor, and the Director of the Department of Revenue, alleging that the state's employment verification statutes were not preempted by federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the defendants for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, because the Attorney General lacked the authority to bring enforcement actions.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the district court's dismissal of the defendants on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a petition for a writ of certiorari to review the decision and judgment of the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On March 9, 2009, the court denied a timely petition for rehearing and rehearing en banc.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Supremacy Clause and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution against the state of Arizona and the Governor of Arizona in her official capacity in the U.S. District Court of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070, which contains several provisions designed to "discourage and deter the unlawful entry and presence of aliens" in Arizona, impermissibly infringes on the federal government's right to enact and enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, the district court issued a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the grant of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit, issued an opinion upholding the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted cert on December 12, 2011 and issued their opinion on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed in part and reversed in part, striking down most of the challenged provisions of S.B.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed this lawsuit in the District Court of Arizona against the State of Arizona and Arizona Governor Jan Brewer.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that Arizona's immigration laws violated the Constitution and the Immigration & Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the motion for injunctive relief, enjoining Arizona from enforcing certain provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070, and the district court issued a preliminary injunction preventing the four provisions at issue from taking effect.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2011, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district judge's dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held that Arizona’s licensing law was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals remanded the case to the lower court to reconsider its decision.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of organizations and individuals filed a lawsuit against the Sheriff and Attorney of each of the 15 counties in Arizona, in their official capacities, in the U.S. District Court of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by organizations such as the ACLU and the National Immigration Law Center along with private counsel, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 was a violation of the Supremacy Clause of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff contends that S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 conflicts with federal law and procedures and that local law enforcement agencies are ill equipped to deal with the complexities of immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction in February 2012, which the defendants appealed.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, Arizona v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of individuals and organizations filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Arizona against the State of Arizona, the City of Chandler, and the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office alleging that Arizona's Senate Bill 1070, as amended ("S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070"), a comprehensive set of state immigration laws, violated the First Amendment right to free speech.[SENTMARKER]On June 21, 2010, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction, arguing that the law violated their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]On September 16, 2011, the Ninth Circuit held that a Redondo Beach ordinance prohibiting solicitation of business, employment, and contributions on streets and highways was not narrowly tailored to achieve the city's interest in promoting traffic flow and safety.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2012, the district court entered a prelim inary injunction enjoining the enforcement of two provisions of the law, which make it unlawful for a motor vehicle occupant to hire or attempt to hire a person for work at another location from a stopped car that impedes traffic, or for a person to be hired in such a manner.[SENTMARKER]The district court correctly determined that plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the merits of their first amendment claim.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 8, 2015, three civil immigration detainees filed a class action suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Arizona alleging that the conditions of their detention at the Tucson Sector Border Patrol facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were exposed to any number of unsanitary and unhygienic practices.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction in part, but the district court denied the request for reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2018, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the entry of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, former Latino/a guests at Motel 6 locations in Arizona filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that Motel 6's policy of disclosing guests' information to DHS and ICE agents without requiring a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity violated the United States Constitution and federal and state law.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged Motel 6 conspired with DHS and ICE agents to violate guests’ Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, the parties agreed to class action settlement terms and the district court approved the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court retains jurisdiction over the matter for the duration of the consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2018, a group of Motel 6 guests filed a class-action lawsuit in the United States District Court in the Arizona District Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Motel 6's policy and/or practice of disclosing guest registration information, including personal information, to federal immigration agents violated federal and state law, in violation of the company's written assurances that it protects the privacy of its guests, and to assist DHS and ICE agents in unlawfully arresting or detaining guests.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, Motel 6 agreed to: (i) provide training to its employees that if they have 10 questions about this policy, they should call the 24-Hour Hotline; .[SENTMARKER](ii) allocate thirty-five percent 21 (35%) of the Cy Pres Fund to FIRRP; .[SENTMARKER](iii) allocate fifteen percent 11 (15%) to TheDream.US; and (iv) provide the following training: i.c.[SENTMARKER]the next $500,000 shall be returned to Defendants; .[SENTMARKER]the next half-million shall be deposited to The Dream.US.; .[SENTMARKER]), the next $100,000 shall be paid to Motel 6; .[SENTMARKER]and (c.)[SENTMARKER]a portion of the remaining $500,000 will be allocated to The DREAM Fund.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Following his arrest and confinement at the Coconino County Detention Facility (CCDF), plaintiff challenged the prolonged detention of inmates at CCDF triggered by detainer requests from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency (ICE).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff claimed this policy violated Article II, section 8 of the Arizona Constitution and the Fourth   and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]He sought class-wide declaratory and injunctive relief for all CCDF detainees subject to this prolonged detention policy despite their eligibility for pretrial release.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the district of Arizona denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, citing his inability to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of his claims.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff moved to dismiss the case thereafter, which was accepted by the court.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2018, a resident of Arizona filed this lawsuit against the CoConino County Sheriff's Office in the District Court of Arizona alleging that the County's policy of prolonging detention of inmates for whom it receives a detainer request from ICE is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the county's detention policy violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, which provides that no person shall be disturbed in his private when Plaintiff actually posts bond and ICE takes custody of him.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2018, the court denied Plaintiff's motion for a temporary restraining order and injunctive relief, and the case was dismissed on July 2, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In June 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity sued DHS and CBP, bringing challenges to the Trump Administration's proposed border wall (FOIA, environmental statutes, APA, IIRIRA).[SENTMARKER]After consolidation with several cases, on Feb.[SENTMARKER]2018, the Court granted the government's motion to dismiss (except for the FOIA claim) and denied plaintiffs' SJ cross-motions.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to dismiss the FOIA claim.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Lastly, the Supreme Court denied the plaintiff's petition for writ of certiorari regarding the constitutional issue of separation of powers in the IIRIRA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking declaratory and/or injunctive relief under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) for the San Diego and Calexico border barrier projects.[SENTMARKER]The Center's FOIA requests sought records related to the agencies' compliance with NEPA, the APA, and other laws in relation to the border wall prototype project.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the plaintiffs' non-constitutional challenges to the waiver determination for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted DHS summary judgment on the ultra vires claims, finding that the waivers of NEPA and the APA were precluded by the Secretary's waiver of the Coastal Zone Management Act (CZMA) and the Executive Order 13767.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, concluding that they had not violated the FOIA or the APA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed the decision, holding that it did not have jurisdiction to consider MCorp's challenge Id.[SENTMARKER]1995 and Organized Vill.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 23, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking records relating to contracts between ICE and private companies for access and use of automated license plate reader (ALPR) technology and related training material, privacy guidance, audit logs, and other documents relating to any use and sharing of ALPR data by ICE.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE wrongfully withheld the requested records in violation of FOIA and sought declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to the search, release and disclosure of requested agency records, as well as attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on July 20, 2018.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 25, 2017, community legal services in East Palo Alto, California filed a FOIA request in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California under the Freedom of information Act (FOIA) seeking records related to changes in immigration enforcement under President Donald Trump's executive orders.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to settle the case for $16,350.10 in full and complete satisfaction of plaintiffs' attorney's fees, costs, and litigation expenses under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]On January 26, 2017, President Trump signed an Executive Order, "Enhancing Public Safety in the Interior of the Interior," announcing an expansion in interior immigration enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The order did not provide for the release of any records responsive to plaintiffs' FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On March 2, 2017, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to respond to the FOIA request, and to search for and disclose the requested records, as well as other appropriate relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on May 2, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the parties to pay the plaintiffs’ attorney’s fees and costs, vacate the case-management fees, and provide the plaintiffs with a copy of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: In August 2018, California and San Francisco filed lawsuits challenging the Department of Justice's ("DOJ") authority to impose immigration-related conditions on federal law enforcement funding.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief that the conditions were unconstitutional violations of separation of powers and the spending clause of the United States Constitution and to enjoin the DOJ from enforcing the conditions.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ moved for partial dismissal or summary judgment, insisting that the nondisclosure and information 24 conditions are sufficiently related to the federal interests in the program to be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the DOJ's motion for summary judgment and granted the plaintiffs' motion for a permanent nationwide 14 injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the district court's 10 judgment in favor of San Francisco on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 28, 2020, a group of non-Mexican asylum seekers brought suit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of California against the Department of the Homeland Security (DHS) seeking a preliminary injunction against the government's new policy of forcing asylum seekers to return to Mexico while they await their removal proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the nonprofit organization Tahirih Justice Center, argued that the policy violated the 4 humanitarian protections to which they are entitled under United States and international law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, and the government appealed.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2020, the district court issued an injunction setting aside the DHS's policy, concluding that the plaintiffs had shown a likelihood of success on the merits of their claim that the return-to-Mexico requirement of the Migrant Protection Protocols is inconsistent with the 8 Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and  1225(b)(1) of the Immigration and Nationalization Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]The government appealed, and on April 11, 2020, the court granted a stay of the preliminary injunction pending its appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, pending the outcome of the appeal.

gold_sents: On June 16, 2019, plaintiffs--three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens who filed FOIA (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files (known as A-Files)--filed this class-action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, represented by the American Immigration Council and the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, sought declaratory relief that defendants’ failure to make timely determinations on plaintiffs’ and proposed classes’ A-File FOIA requests violates FOIA, and a nationwide injunction requiring defendants to make timely determinations.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief and ordered the defendants to provide quarterly reports on their compliance with the FOIA.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2019, three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens filed a class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the Northern district of California on behalf of individuals who filed Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files, also known as Alien 4 Registration Files (A-Files) or A-Files.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of failing to meet the statutory deadline with respect to A-File FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in 1992, in which the parties agreed to implement expedited processing of FOIA requests where the requester demonstrates that an individual’s life or personal safety would be jeopardized or that substantial due process rights would be impaired by the failure to process a request immediately.[SENTMARKER]On August 28, 2020, the Ninth Circuit reversed the settlement agreement and remanded on a separate issue.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2021, the parties filed a joint status report in which they agreed that the parties would implement a new system that would allow users to submit and track FOIA requests and receive documents digitally.[SENTMARKER]In May 2020, the parties entered a new settlement agreement with the ACLU, the American 21 immigration council, the Northwest Immigrant rights project, and the ACLU.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, the court granted preliminary injunctive relief to plaintiff organizations that serve low-income applicants for immigration benefits and stayed USCIS rule fee changes for immigration benefit requests.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2020 the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: This lawsuit was filed in response to a July 6, 2020 ICE directive that would effectively force out of the country many international students studying remotely during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The University of California filed suit claiming that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act. Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and an order vacating and setting aside the policy.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declarative relief and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]In a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, the plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 6, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, The Regents of the University of California filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the federal government violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by implementing a new rule that required international students on F-1 visas to attend classes in person if they wished to remain in this country.[SENTMARKER]The Regents alleged that the new rule was arbitrary, capricious, or otherwise not in accordance with law, and that it would cause, and will cause, irreparable harm to The Regents and its international students.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2020, the Regents served Defendants with the summons and complaint filed in this matter, as well as a Motion for Temporary Restraining Order and Order to Show Cause.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case, and the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On August 4, 2020, the defendants issued a press release announcing that each F-1 visa student attending a school that is adopting a hybrid model – that is, a mixture of online and in person classes – must by August 4, 2020 certify to SEVP for each student attending such school that, among other things, the student is not taking an entirely online course load for the fall 2020 semester, and is taking the minimum number of online classes required to make normal progress in their degree program.[SENTMARKER]The press release also stated that the students would be required to attend at least one in-person class per semester.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, and granted the motion for a temporary restraining order enjoining the defendants from implementing the July 6 Directive.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Seven unnamed individuals sued ICE and DHS over their new directive that would effectively force international students to take in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief prohibiting the enforcement of the directive and an order vacating the directive.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance, but the plaintiffs in this case filed an amended complaint that sought a formal declaration that the July 6 directive was improperly issued and an order that the government administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the students' claims were mooted by the rescission and granted the government's motion to dismiss on October 1, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 4, 2020, California Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state 4 of emergency in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]In response to the state emergency, California universities cancelled in-person classes in the fall semester if their students on F-1 visas were affected by the pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2020, Plaintiff filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Central district of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order enjoining the implementation of the July 6 policy change.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 20, 2019, the City of Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Unified School District filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Judge's Court for the District of Northern California alleging that the Census Bureau's 2020 Census count exclusion of undocumented immigrants was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, mandamus, and other relief to prevent Defendants from taking any action to exclude undocumented immigrants from the census count by adding a question to the 2020 Census questionnaire on citizenship status.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed and affirmed the vacatur of the Secretary of Commerce's decision to exclude 27 undocumented immigrants in his apportionment report to Congress issued under the Census Act.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] January 6, 2015 | Administrative Procedure Act | 5 U.S.C.  701 et seq. 10 | Department of Homeland Security | ICE | U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court | District of Columbia ||| January 7, 2015 | Class-action lawsuit filed in the United States District Court for the District of Washington, DC on January 6, 2015, on behalf of a group of individuals who were detained by ICE in the Dilley, Texas detention facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention resulted from an unlawful policy that DHS adopted in June 2014 in response to the immigration spike.[SENTMARKER]According to the plaintiffs, such detention violated the Fifth Amendment, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and the Due Process Clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctive and declaratory relief invalidating and setting aside the improper deterrence policy, as well as a preliminary injunction to prevent DHS from applying this policy until a final determination has been reached on the merits of this action.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently conferred and submitted a joint proposal for moving forward.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on January 7, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion to dismiss the case, which was denied on January 7.[SENTMARKER]On January 7, 2015, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2018, Muslim Advocates, a not-for-profit legal advocacy and educational organization, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice's (DOJ) National Security Division (NSD) and the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking documents related to the federal government's denaturalization efforts.[SENTMARKER]Muslim Advocates also sought a fee waiver pursuant to the FOIA because disclosure of the documents is in the public interest and because Muslim Advocates is a member of the news media.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the NSD issued a final determination on Muslim Advocates' FOIA request, and the parties agreed to file a joint status report on or before April 10, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the parties entered a judgment in favor of Muslim Advocates and against ICE, finding that the defendants' unlawful withholding of the records violated the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide the public with a copy of the parties' Joint Status Report, which will be published in the next few weeks.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 9, 2018, a group of noncitizens who entered the United States illegally and who wish to seek asylum filed a lawsuit in the Northern District Court of California challenging the government's categorical bar on asylum eligibility for individuals and families crossing the southern border outside designated ports of entry.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, President Trump signed a presidential proclamation that purports to suspend the entry of individuals who have entered the US from Mexico outside a port of entry after November 9, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, the ACLU filed a class action suit in the district court against the government on behalf of individuals and groups that provide legal and social services to immigrants and asylum seekers.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the government from implementing the categorical bar and ordered the government to return to the pre-Rule practices for processing asylum applications pending final disposition of the case.[SENTMARKER]On November 27, 2018, the government moved for an emergency stay and appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]On December 7, 2018, the court denied the Government's request for a stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2005, a class-wide settlement agreement was reached in litigation involving the Office of civil rights and civil liberties (CRCL) of the Department of homeland security (DHS).[SENTMARKER]The agreement required the government to provide certain rights to noncitizen parents and minor children detained in family residential centers (FRCs) during the removal process.[SENTMARKER]In March 2020, the parties filed this suit in the District of the Court for the Central District of California, alleging that the government failed to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2020, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On April 20, 2020, the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: On April 23, 2020, a group of transgender people in civil immigration detention filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction ordering supervised release of all transgender people in immigration detention in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, the court denied the plaintiff's motion for TRO and motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]After filing an amended complaint in August, 2020, the case was dismissed on January 6, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 20, 2020, a group of transgender immigrants filed a class-action lawsuit against ICE in the United States District Court for the District of Washington, alleging that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) violated their Fifth Amendment due process rights and the Administrative Contract Act (APA) by failing to adequately protect them from a global pandemic caused by the HIV/AIDS virus.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate medical care to transgender people in civil immigration detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were denied access to medically necessary, gender-affirming hormone therapy and other gendering affirming care.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) directing ICE to immediately release all transgender detainees across the country and to refrain from detaining any additional transgender detainees until the pandemic ends.[SENTMARKER]In May 2020, the court certified a class of all civil immigration detainees being held at one facility in the District.[SENTMARKER]The district court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: Three non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this class-action lawsuit against the Department of Defense in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Department was refusing to certify their honorable military service for purposes of expedited naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a preliminary injunction in October 2017, requiring the Department to certify honorable service within 2 days of a soldier’s request, without imposing additional procedural or substantive requirements.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the plaintiffs and the Department of Defense are in mediation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 24, 2017, ten individuals (the "Nio Plaintiffs"), who enlisted in the Army Reserve's Selected Reserve of the Ready Reserve and who are in the DTP, brought a class action suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Washington against the Departments of Defense ("DOD") and Homeland Security ("USCIS"), alleging that the military's refusal to issue them N-426 forms is unlawful under the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA") and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Nio plaintiffs also challenged the USCIS's decision to put their naturalization applications on hold pending DOD's completion of the enhanced security screening ("DHS/USCIS Security Screening Requirement") it now requires for MAVNI enlistees prior to initial entry training ("IET") or active-duty service.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2017, the plaintiffs filed a complaint in the District Court, challenging the defendants' refusal to complete and certify their honorable service in the Selected Reserve as unlawfully imposing extra-statutory requirements in violation of  1440.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also filed a motion for class certification, seeking to certify a class that would include MAVNIs, who had served honorably in the selected reserve but had not yet served in an active duty capacity, and those who have not received a completed Form N.426.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the class certification on September 1, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint status report for the case, which was submitted to the court on August 5, 2017, and the parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this lawsuit in May 2017, challenging policies of the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Defense that unlawfully delayed their naturalization applications.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class and granted a preliminary injunction against the agencies on October 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2019, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, ruling that the agencies’ policy of delaying naturalization applications was arbitrary and capricious, in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a permanent injunction on August 20, 2020, and retained jurisdiction to enforce the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 7, 2017, a group of enlisted non-citizens enlisted in the United States Army's Selected Reserve of the Ready Reserve filed a class action lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia against the Departments of Defense (DOD) and Homeland Security (DHS) under the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 (INA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants unlawfully placed their naturalization applications on hold pending the successful completion of specialized background investigations done by the military for DoD purposes (and not required by the laws governing naturalization).[SENTMARKER]The defendants' policies apply to certain MAVNI enlistees who have applied for – or are eligible to apply for – naturalization but have not yet been granted citizenship.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that they had not shown that they were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 21, 2020, a 15-year-old minor from Guatemala who entered the United States as an unaccompanied minor filed this lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Title 42 of the Public Health Service Act (PLS).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the APA by detaining the minor without any hearing, even where, as here, the minor has no symptoms of COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, 2020, the parties filed a document stating that the government had transferred the custody of the minor to the CDC.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2020, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case as moot, claiming that the plaintiff lacked constitutional standing.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for class certification on August 14, 2020, and the case was dismissed on August 20, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the district court's decision, and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed.

gold_sents: In 2020, immigrant detainees in three Florida detention centers filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The detainees alleged that their detention violated their Due Process rights because the detention centers were not adhering to CDC guidelines to protect them against COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The court partially granted a temporary restraining order on April 30, 2020, requiring the respondents to implement CDC guidelines for sanitation.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 6 and certified the class.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, the court appointed a Special Master to oversee compliance.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the southern district of Florida alleging that they were being held by the Miami field office of ICE and housed at three detention centers in Miami, Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention centers were ill-equipped to deal with the COVID19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to employ numerous safety measures to prevent the spread of COVID 19, as well as imposing extensive reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Eleventh Circuit, which granted a stay of the injunction pending an appeal by the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties have not been able to reach a mutually agreeable resolution as to the ongoing conditions at the facilities.[SENTMARKER]In a 2-1 published opinion with a written dissent, our Appellate Court in Swain granted a motion to stay the District Court’s preliminary injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the district court did not have jurisdiction over the case.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2011, three foreign residents of Indiana filed a class action lawsuit against the cities of Indianapolis and Franklin and the counties of Marion and Johnson, seeking to enjoin enforcement of Indiana's Senate Enrolled Act 590, which would allow local law enforcement officers to make warrantless arrests of people who were subject to a removal order issued by an immigration court or a detainer or notice of action issued by the Department of Homeland Security, or who had been indicted or convicted of an aggravated felony, and would make the use of consular identification cards for identification within the state a civil infraction punishable by fine.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2013, the District Court (Judge Barker) ruled in favor of plaintiffs, granting their motion for summary judgment, and permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 of SEA 590.[SENTMARKER]Because plaintiffs' suit was dependent upon enforcement of these sections, the matter was dismissed without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2011, two Mexican citizens filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern district of Indiana challenging the constitutionality of two sections of Indiana's new immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of a class of persons who regularly use their consular identification cards for identification purposes, including, among other things, when banking or interacting with consular officials.[SENTMARKER]On June 24, 2011, the Court entered a preliminary injunction enjoining the State of Indiana from enforcing the two challenged provisions of the Senate Enrolled Act 590 (SEA 590), which was passed by the Indiana General Assembly and scheduled to go into effect on July 1, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On December 21, 2011, the court entered a final injunction against the City, enjoining enforcement of Section 18 (currently codified at Indiana Code  34-288.2) and Section 20 ( codified at  35-33-1a) until further order from the court.[SENTMARKER]The final injunction also enjoined the State from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 until the Court's final determination on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]On January 12, 2012, the Supreme Court issued a ruling in favor of the State, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2017, an Iranian-born researcher and J-1 visa holder filed this lawsuit after being prevented from boarding a flight to the United States on both January 28, 2017 and January 30, 2017, pursuant to an executive order issued by President Donald Trump on January 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2017 the plaintiff filed an emergency motion seeking a Temporary Restraining Order against the defendants, but on February 3, 2017 the plaintiff requested that the hearing on the TRO be cancelled, as she was able to travel to the United States and clear customs.[SENTMARKER]On March 6, 2017, the President rescinded the January 27 Executive Order and replaced it with a narrower one.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, plaintiff filed a notice of voluntary dismissal without prejudice, mentioning the Fourth Circuit's injunction of the revised Executive Order in IRAP v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 29, 2017, Plaintiff Dr. Samira Asgari filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the District of the Massachusetts against the President of the United States, the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, and the Director of the Boston Field Office of Customs and Border Protection (CBP).[SENTMARKER]As part of the suit, Dr. Asgari alleged that the President's January 27, 2017 executive order barring entry into the United states by nationals of certain Muslim majority countries, including Iran, Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Libya, Somalia, and Yemen, violated the Constitution's due process and equal protection provisions of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2017, Judge Allison D. Burroughs granted the Plaintiff's motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining the President from enforcing the Executive Order until June 5.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants' response to the TRO was denied by Judge Burroughs and Judge Dein and the parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]In a separate action, the Plaintiff also filed a motion for an emergency injunction on January 29, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that President Trump's executive order violated the equal protection and due process guarantees of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff also alleged that his right to a fair and efficient resolution of the case was violated.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion to dismiss on May 31, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed without prejudice and that the parties would be required to file a joint response within 30 days of each other.

gold_sents: In February 2018, an undocumented immigrant who was married to a U.S. citizen filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that her unexpected arrest and detainment without notice or a hearing violated her due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]In April 2018, nine more plaintiffs were added, and they sought class certification, which was approved on May 17, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, the district court instructed the defendants to begin providing monthly reports to class counsel regarding class members.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a motion for immediate release of that class member because he was detained in a facility where an employee tested positive for COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, the parties filed a joint status report that altered the terms of release for the class member and the court lifted the stay on the class member's removal by ICE.[SENTMARKER]ICE imposed conditions of supervision pursuant to the parties' agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on November 18, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 8, 2018, two immigrant spouses filed a petition in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District court for the district of Massachusetts alleging that they were being detained by ICE in violation of the Constitution and laws of the United States, and seeking an order directing ICE to release them.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated to dismissal of the case on February 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered that the parties confer concerning whether they could reach an agreement to resolve this case.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2018, the parties reported that they had not agreed on a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The court found that ICE's attempts to remove the alien before they can and receive a decision on their applications for provisional waivers violated the Constitution, laws, or treaties.[SENTMARKER]On May 9, 2018, the court granted the defendants' motion for preliminary injunctions, granted their motion for a preliminary injunction, and granted their request for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 27, 2020, Haitian-Americans United, Inc., Brazilian Worker Center, Chelsea Collaborative, Inc. and Centro Presente filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District Of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Presidential Memorandum titled “Excluding Illegal Aliens from the Apportionment Base Following the 2020 Census” is unconstitutional and that any compliance violates §§ 706(2) of the APA because it is contrary to constitutional power, right, privilege, or immunity and in excess of statutory jurisdiction and authority, and without observance of procedure required by law.[SENTMARKER]The case has been approved for a three-judge court and is awaiting the defendants' answer.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2020, a group of non-profit organizations representing immigrants of color in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against Donald Trump, Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross, and the Census Bureau.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the defendants' plan to exclude undocumented immigrants from the congressional apportionment base for the first time in our nation's history is in violation of the Constitution and federal statutory law.[SENTMARKER]In addition to denying immigrants the political representation and census-linked federal funding to which they are entitled, the plaintiffs argue that the plaintiffs will be discriminated against because of their race, national origin, or alienage.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, enjoining the defendants from complying with the July 21 Memorandum and producing population tabulations excluding undocumented individuals for congressional apportionment.[SENTMARKER]The case will be heard by Judge Douglas P. Woodlock on July 21, 2020.

gold_sents: On Jan.[SENTMARKER]24, 2018, the NAACP sued the DHS over its Nov. 2017 revocation of Temporary Protected Status (first implemented after the Jan.[SENTMARKER]2017 revocation of Temporary Protected Status (first implemented after the Jan.[SENTMARKER]2010 Haitian earthquake) for Haitians living in the United States.[SENTMARKER]The NAACP alleged that DHS violated the 5th Amendment by relying on racially discriminatory stereotypes to deprive Haitians of rights and sought mandamus and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which was granted in part and denied in part by the court on March 12, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The court allowed the plaintiffs' 5th Amendment claims to move forward.[SENTMARKER]Due to ongoing parallel litigation over the revocation of TPS for Haitians, the defendants requested a stay in this case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the stay in March 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed this class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the district of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their right to due process under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution by putting them in extreme danger of exposure to COVID-19, a lethal virus with no vaccine or cure.[SENTMARKER]In a published order on March 23, 2020, the Ninth Circuit ordered the defendants to release an immigrant detainee because of the danger posed by the virus.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion for a temporary restraining order, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that they were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims that their continued detention violated their due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
