pegasus_output_sents: On July 17, 2006, the City of Valley Park, Missouri passed an ordinance that required landlords to provide the City with an array of immigration-status documents with their application for an occupancy permit, and the implicit admission that certain noncitizens with legal status would be denied residency in Valley Park.[SENTMARKER]On September 22, 2006, Windhover, Inc. and others filed suit in the Circuit Court for the County of St. Louis alleging that the ordinance violated the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C.  3601, et seq., and Missouri state law, as well as federal law.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2007, the plaintiffs filed a petition for summary judgment in the Missouri Court of Appeals for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]On August 3, 2007, the district court entered an order of dismissal, holding that there was no longer a case or controversy.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the City's motion to dismiss and the case was remanded to the circuit court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 2008, the case returned to the district courts.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the City agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into effect on November 2, 2008.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 1997, a group of foreign nationals filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Pennsylvania against a private detention center in Elizabeth, New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention center had violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) by denying them access to a law library and other legal materials, failing to provide them with personal property, and denying them the right to a private attorney.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was remanded to the district court for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]On June 2006, the plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]On August 2010, the court of appeals granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit held that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties in the case and remanded the case for further review.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 17, 2012.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 20, 2007, a group of Latino residents of the New York area filed a class action lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) alleging that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by unlawfully searching their homes and targeting Latinos for arrest.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to discriminatory treatment because their residences were identified and targeted for ICE operations because Latinos were believed to reside in them.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied a motion by the plaintiffs for a preliminary injunction, and granted the defendants’ motion for summary judgment on the pleadings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief along with back-pay and punitive damages, and sought, among other relief, a permanent injunction prohibiting blanket strip searches and body cavity inspections of an individual "absent a reasonable suspicion that such individual is concealing weapons or other contraband."[SENTMARKER]Without addressing standing, the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for judgment on pleadings dismissing the claims for injunctive and equitable relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss is due on May 19, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' counsel filed a motion for a stay, which was denied, and the case was dismissed on July 2, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations comprised of day laborers and/or predominately Latino immigrant workers filed a class action lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of New York under the First and Fourteenth Amendments against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and LatinoJustice PRLDEF, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs, claiming that the defendants, through the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of labor from the town's streets and sidewalks, unlawfully prohibited speech related to employment and had a discriminatory animus against predominately Latino immigrant day laborers.[SENTMARKER]After defeating the defendant's partial motion for summary judgment due to lack of standing, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment was successful.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the District Court enjoined the ordinance and declared it unconstitutional as it violated the first amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2017, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court assessed attorney fees against the defendants, and the case closed later that year.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations of Latino immigrant day laborers filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York, alleging that the town's law prohibiting day laborers from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles to solicit work violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]On May 20, 2010, the district court entered a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction on free speech grounds.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2013, the Second Circuit granted the Town's appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit held that the District Court's order did not violate the free speech rights of the day laborers.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 29, 2014, the American Immigration Council, the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild, and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its component agencies under the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request sought records related to the implementation of expedited removal at Artesia, a detention facility in New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants denied the Plaintiffs' request for expedited processing and denied the plaintiffs' fee waiver request.[SENTMARKER]On October 21, 2014, the court granted the Defendants' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the Defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of all documents responsive to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs a fee waiver.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 6, 2017, a group of individuals and a civil rights organization filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of homeland security (DHS) alleging that DHS violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by rescinding the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHS's policy regarding the use of DACA applicants' information for immigration-enforcement purposes was arbitrary and capricious under the APA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and denied defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the rescission was inadequately explained.[SENTMARKER]In a related appeal, the Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's preliminary injunction in favor of the Government.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 26, 2020, the State of California and the City and County of San Francisco filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District Of New York, alleging that the federal government's immigration-related conditions on the Byrne Program Criminal Justice Assistance grant funds were unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The conditions required the States and localities to (1) provide access to their correctional facilities for federal immigration enforcement agents (the "access condition"), and (2) enjoin the government from imposing these conditions on any Byrne JAG applicant in order to receive the funds.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied California's request for a preliminary injunction enjoining DOJ from enforcing the Section 1373 condition on the State and its subdivisions, finding that the record was insufficient at the motion to dismiss stage to 79.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court granted partial judgment in favor of plaintiffs, enjoining the enforcement of the challenged conditions as to them and mandating the release of 2017 Byrne grant funds to plaintiffs, and remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: In July 2020, several immigration advocacy and nonprofit organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that by excluding “undocumented immigrants from: (a) the tabulation of the total population of the states; .[SENTMARKER](b) the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state; and (c) the calculation and statement of the apportionment of the House of Representatives among the states” the federal government were violating the Enumeration and Apportionment clauses of the United States Constitution, Equal Protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Separation of Powers, the Census Act, and.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, this case was consolidated with State of New York v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]For additional information, on this case, please see State of New York v. Trump.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2020, a lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Departments of Commerce and Justice in the Southern District Of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution by excluding undocumented immigrants from the population count for purposes of apportioning congressional seats to states by issuing a presidential memorandum to the Secretary of Commerce on July 21, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, and/or mandamus relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment on July 28, 2020, and the parties agreed to a permanent injunction on August 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 1, 2008, the Tulsa Restaurant Association and the Oklahoma Hotel and Lodging Association filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Western district of Oklahoma against the State of Oklahoma, the Governor, the Attorney General, and the Tulsa Chamber.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Section 7(b), 7(c), and 9 of Oklahoma Act were preempted by federal law and thus unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory and injunctive relief from defendants, Oklahoma Governor Brad Henry, Oklahoma Attorney General W.A.[SENTMARKER]Per the district court's grant of a preliminary injunction, the defendants moved to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motions to dismiss and granted the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Tenth Circuit, where the case was settled in February 2010 and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed and the parties have no further comment.

gold_sents: In 2008, two detainees filed a habeas petition and class action suit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Warden of Allegheny County Jail challenging their continued detention pursuant to immigration detainers and alleging violations of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas relief and class certification.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2008, the district court (Judge David S. Cercone) denied the habeas petition as moot, dismissed the action, and denied the motion for class certification because ICE had assumed custody of both petitioners.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 23, 2008, Wilmer Urbina, Omar Romero-Villegas and others filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District Of Pennsylvania against the Allegheny County Sheriff's Office and the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Immigration and Customs Enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were detained in the county jail without due process and based solely on an immigration detainer which does not authorize their detention.[SENTMARKER]The class is so numerous that it is believed that there were as many as 76 individuals being improperly detained on immigration detainers.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 15, 2008 by Judge David S. gold_sents: On August 23, 2012, ICE Agents and the State of Mississippi filed claims alleging that deferred action Directive commands ICE officers to violate federal law, compels them to violate their oaths of office, violates the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"), unconstitutionally usurps and encroaches upon the legislative powers of Congress, as defined in Article I of the United States Constitution, and violates the obligation of the executive branch to faithfully execute the law, as required by Article II, Section 3, of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2013, the Court found that ICE Agent Plaintiffs had standing to proceed, but the State of Mississippi did not.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2013, the Court dismissed Plaintiff's claims without prejudice for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, finding that the dispute must be governed by the Civil Service Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the judgment of the District Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2012, a group of immigration and deportation officers and the State of Mississippi filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Texas, challenging the constitutional and statutory validity of DHS’s Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the program violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, but the case eventually made its way to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court upheld the district court's dismissal of the plaintiffs' claims, finding that the plaintiffs had not alleged a sufficient injury in fact to satisfy the requirements of constitutional standing.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]7, 2013, 16 Indian guestworkers filed a lawsuit in E.D.Tx.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme by Defendant Signal International.[SENTMARKER]As of July 5, 2018, 20 of the 21 plaintiffs had reached a settlement with the Burnett defendants; the remaining plaintiff's claim was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as to the Signal defendants and Dewan defendants.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2013, a group of African-American workers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against Signal International, LLC, J M Associate of Mississippi, Inc, and others under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) and the Civil Rights Act of 1866.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to an objectively hostile and abusive work environment on account of Plaintiffs’ race and alienage.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the defendants violated the applicable health and safety standards under the federal Occupational Health and Safety Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court and the parties agreed to a settlement plan.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on May 4, 2015, which provided for the plaintiffs to receive a safety bonus in addition to their regular hourly wage.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to transfer the case to the district court, and the case was dismissed on July 20, 2018.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2019, a group of immigrants filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Texas against Dallas County, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Dallas County violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by refusing to grant them immediate release on bond and by detaining them based on immigration holds after they were otherwise eligible for release.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were detained by Dallas County in connection with state criminal charges, while they were being held in detention by federal immigration detainers issued by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Form I-247.[SENTMARKER]In March 25, 2018, the district court granted a motion for a new trial.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of Dallas County on April 25, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment held that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' Fourth and 14th Amendments rights.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, and the case was dismissed on March 25, 2018.

gold_sents: This suit challenges Texas's "Sanctuary City" legislation, Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the other suits in this special collection, this suit does not challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]This case was quickly consolidated with the two other before Judge Orlando L. Garcia; please refer to El Cenizo v. Texas for further information and updates.[SENTMARKER]This case was administratively closed on Oct. 24, 2017 in light of the consolidation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the County of El Paso filed this lawsuit against the State of Texas, the Texas Attorney General, and the Director of the Texas Public Safety in the United States District Court for the Western district of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The County and its Sheriff, Richard Wiles, sought declaratory and injunctive relief for the following legal violations in connection with the enactment, administration, and prospective enforcement of Senate Bill 4 (SB 4), also known as the "Show Me Your Papers Bill"<n>El Paso County is over 80% Hispanic and over 25% of its residents are foreign born.[SENTMARKER]For instance, the County is under a federal court settlement agreement where it created a policy prohibiting the enforcement of civil immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, El Paso is prohibited from making inquiries into the citizenship or residency status for the purpose of determining whether an individual has violated civil immigration law or for the purposes of enforcing those laws.[SENTMARKER]El Paso’s current policies regarding federal immigration enforcement comply with state and federal law and do not violate SB 4.[SENTMARKER]In addition, this court has jurisdiction over these constitutional claims pursuant to 42 U. S.C.  1983 and the Declaratory Judgment Act.

gold_sents: An individual unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act for damages.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in November 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2017, the Plaintiff filed this lawsuit against Bexar County, Texas, the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Department of Justice, and other federal defendants, alleging that the defendants violated the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and the Administrative Procedures Act.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff was detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center (BCADC) from March 24, 2016 until June 8, 2016 without notice of any charges, without a warrant, notice to appear in removal proceedings, or an order of removal, and in violation of law.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE was liable under the FTCA for falsely imprisoning the Plaintiff pursuant to a detainer request issued by the ICE San Antonio Field Office.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, granted their motion for declaratory relief, and denied the Plaintiff's motion for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2011, a group of federal employees filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Utah challenging Utah's immigration enforcement law, House 4 Bill 497.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the law violated the Supremacy Clause, the Fourth Amendment, and the Right to Travel.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, but the Supreme Court held in Arizona v. Arizona on June 25, 2012 that the federal government could not enforce immigration laws that violate the Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated in the district court and the parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order and granted their Motion for Preliminary Injunction, as well as their motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in November 2011 and the case was dismissed in May 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court has not yet issued a decision on the case, but it is expected to do so in the near future.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 21, 2019, the ACLU of Vermont and Migrant Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the district of Vermont against the Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Vermont Motor Vehicles Department (DMV) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary damages against the United States.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE and DMV violated the rights of migrant farm workers by targeting and detaining them in violation of the federal immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' conduct has caused a number of Vermont-based farm owners to discourage their employees from participating in Migrant Justice activities for fear that their workers would be detained.[SENTMARKER]In April 2016, the Sheriffs Department settled 12 with the ACLU and the Human Rights Commission for nearly $30,000.[SENTMARKER]In November 2018, the ACLU filed a similar suit against the DMV in the same court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 31, 2018, two non-profit organizations and fifteen individuals filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Trump Administration's implementation of the waiver provision of the Travel Ban (Presidential Proclamation No. 9645), alleging that it violates the Administrative Procedure Act and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]After the Trump Administration concluded, President Biden revoked the Travel Ban and ordered that visa applications resume processing on January 20, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2018, a group of individuals and organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Washington, challenging the government's implementation of the waiver provision of President Trump's Proclamation No. 9645, "Enhancing Vetting Capabilities and Processes for Detecting Attempted Entry into The United States By Terrorists or Other Public-Safety Threats" ("Proclamation").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the government has failed to follow its own policies and procedures, and have "put in place a waiver process in which applicants are denied waivers without ever receiving notice or an opportunity to apply [and] applicants have been denied without having to have an interview."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also allege that there are no agency decisions subject to review under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties do not consent to or present discovery issues to a judge.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss on the ground that there was no agency decision to review.[SENTMARKER]The case was sent to the US District Court in the Northern district of California by electronic transfer 15 days from the date of this filing.[SENTMARKER]On March 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a putative class action in the federal district court in California.[SENTMARKER]The court granted in part and denied in part a motion to amend, finding that plaintiffs had plausibly stated a claim under the Accardi doctrine.[SENTMARKER]The third claim was dismissed on August 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties have not consented to or presented discovery issues, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: In March 2020, during the outbreak of COVID-19 in the Seattle area, persons critically vulnerable to the disease and held in an immigration detention facility near Seattle filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued ICE and its directors for violation of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that continued detention in the face of a potential outbreak in the detention facility would expose the plaintiffs to substantial harm and amount to punishment in violation of the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order seeking immediate release.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the plaintiffs' second motion for a temporary restraining order on April 8.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on April 30, which the court has not yet resolved.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus, seeking a writ of injunctive relief, and a motion to reopen their immigration cases in the United States District Court for the Western district of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' conditions of confinement subject them to heightened risk of serious illness or death if exposed to COVID-19, for which there is no vaccine, known treatment, or cure.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' appeal on December 2, 2019, and the case was closed on April 3, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This class-action case was brought challenging the Santa Cruz County Jail's practice of strip searching individuals held in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The case settled and was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2009, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Northern California against the County of Santa Cruz and the Santa Cruz Sheriff's Department.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments by subjecting detainees in their custody to strip and/or visual body cavity searches without reasonable suspicion that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The class included all persons who were subject to the searches before they were arraigned and who were not officially 24 participating in such searches.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that each class member suffered actual damages as a result of being 5 subjected to a strip search before arraignment 28 without having, and recording in writing, a reasonable suspect that the search would be fruitful.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in December 31, 2008, and the settlement was approved by Judge Richard Seeborg on January 29, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The settlement fund will be used for costs of claims administration, attorney's fees and costs for recovering the settlement fund, and payments to class members who were subjected to strip searches prior to arraignment.

gold_sents: A female arrestee filed this strip search case against the Humboldt County Jail and various officials challenging the jail's mandatory, blanket strip search policy.[SENTMARKER]The court found no pattern or practice.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff refiled, naming the deputy sheriff who conducted (and videotaped) the search, and the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 23, 2004, a woman arrested for allegedly driving under the influence of alcohol was taken to the Humboldt County Jail in Eureka, California, where she was forced to strip naked from the waist up in the presence of persons who were not part of the plaintiff's class.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant's strip search and visual body cavity search policies, practices, and customs violated her Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the defendant on May 23, 2006, and the case was closed on June 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff appealed to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendant is no longer required to pay the plaintiff.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2007, a man arrested in Solano County, California, filed a class action lawsuit against the Solano County Sheriff's Office, alleging that the sheriff's office had violated the Constitution by subjecting detainees to strip and visual body cavity searches without reasonable suspicion that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants' policy, practice, and custom of subjecting arrestees to strip searches before arraignment without having, and recording in writing, a reasonable suspicion of the searches' productiveness, violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 28, 2009, and the parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $12,500 to each of the plaintiff's class members.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.

gold_sents: In 2011, several inmates of the Fresno County Adult Detention Facilities filed a lawsuit against the County of Fresno, California, alleging that it violated prisoners' Constitutional rights by maintaining dangerous facilities and failing to provide basic health care.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement a remedial plan and to pay $900,000 in attorneys' fees and $40,000 per year for monitoring fees and expenses.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2011, two female prisoners filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of California against the Fresno County Sheriff's Office and the County of Fresno.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions of confinement in the jail violated the constitutional and statutory rights of all prisoners who were or will be incarcerated there.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently agreed to suspend discovery for the purpose of settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]In May 2015, the parties executed a consent decree, which required the County to provide timely access to health care for all prisoners, including those with serious health conditions.[SENTMARKER]The County also agreed to pay plaintiffs' counsel $40,000 per calendar year, or a pro-rated portion thereof, for all fees and expenses related to monitoring the implementation of the consent decree and the consent plan.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was approved by the Court on December 13, 2015, and the parties entered into a final judgment in December 2015.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to the Court's approval.

pegasus_output_sents: In March 1993, a group of inmates of the Merced County Jail filed a class action lawsuit against the County of Merced on behalf of all inmates in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county had violated the inmates' civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate housing, failing to adequately monitor the jail, and failing to release inmates when the jail was full.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief, and the case was dismissed on September 30, 2000.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2000, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement, which was approved by the court on October 10, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on March 4, 1993.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to post a copy of the settlement on every floor level of the jail facility and to provide the inmates with access to the settlement notice.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the county to pay the plaintiffs in full.[SENTMARKER]On March 4, 1993, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is still ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 17, 2013, the family of a pretrial detainee in the custody of the Alameda County Sheriff's Department filed this civil rights suit against the County and Corizon Health, Inc. under Title 42 of the United States Code, Sections 1983 and 1988, and the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the Defendant denied the Plaintiff access to appropriate, competent, and necessary care for serious medical and psychiatric needs.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant moved for summary judgment on all of the Plaintiff's claims.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Defendant's motion for partial summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a settlement conference.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the Plaintiff would be retained by the County for a period of two years.[SENTMARKER]The settlement conference was held on December 31, 2015, and the Plaintiff was awarded $20,000 in general damages.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted summary judgment against the Defendant in January 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit's decision in Lolli v. gold_sents: This putative class-action lawsuit, brought by inmates in Orange County Jail, argued that county and the sheriff violated the U.S. Constitution, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act in failing to provide adequate care amidst the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas corpus, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification and partially granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, which mandated more social distancing, providing for more PPE, and improved sanitation policies.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, and applied in both the district court and the Ninth Circuit to stay the case in the lower court until the appeals court had ruled.[SENTMARKER]Both denied these applications, however the Ninth Circuit remanded to the district court saying that the defendants could try to modify the injunction if there were any changed circumstances.[SENTMARKER]Defendants did so, but the district court denied any modifications once again.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, which likewise rejected the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the defendants went to the Supreme Court and asked them to stay the injunction while the Ninth Circuit heard the case on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court obliged on August 5, staying the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of February 17, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2020, ten inmates at the Orange County Jail filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the conditions of confinement at the jail violated their constitutional and other statutor rights.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2020, the District Court issued a preliminary injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the injunction to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which issued a stay of the injunction on June 2, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed an emergency appeal to the Fifth Circuit, which granted a stay on the injunction pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit granted the emergency appeal, and the district court issued a final injunction on May 26, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The district court's final injunction required the defendants to implement measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 within the jail.[SENTMARKER]In the appeal, the defendants alleged that the defendants had failed to take adequate measures to stop the spread, and that the plaintiffs had not presented any evidence of changed circumstances that would merit modification or termination of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' request for a writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for a temporary restraining order and a motion to implement protections against COVID, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendants have filed an appeal.

pegasus_output_sents: In September 2005, a group of inmates filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the district of Columbia against the District of Washington, DC, alleging that the District had a long history of overdetaining and strip searching its inmates past their release dates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were held too long after they were ordered released by a court or their sentences expired.[SENTMARKER]The District moved for summary judgment, the Court denied that motion, and shortly thereafter the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]In 2010, the District agreed to pay up to $2.9 million to a class of inmates.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the Court approved a settlement between the District and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2013, the parties entered into a proposed class action settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the district would pay a class member a sum of $370.00 for the first calendar day that the inmate was overdetained, plus $250 per day for each day that he or she was subjected to a strip search after they had been supposed to be released.[SENTMARKER]The district will also pay a third-party reviewer up to $75,000 for all claims made by the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement may affect the rights of certain people who were incarcerated at the District's jails.[SENTMARKER]The case is still pending.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the Department of Justice ("DOJ") filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of N.M.[SENTMARKER]against the County of Santa Fe, the Santa Fe Detention Center, and the County Board of County Commissioners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the detention center violated the constitutional rights of inmates by failing to provide them with a medically appropriate diet for inmates with conditions that require the inmates to receive special diets, inadequate prenatal care for pregnant inmates, and inadequate treatment, housing, and medical supervision for drug and alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was entered into on November 1, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following conditions: (1) the Detention Center would provide appropriate treatment for the identification, treatment, and control of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus ("MRSA"), (2) the County would implement timely and appropriate care for the pregnant women as medically indicated, including discharge planning, and (3) the County shall provide appropriate housing for inmates.[SENTMARKER]The agreement terminated two years from its effective date.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 7, 1997, a woman arrested in New York City for misdemeanors brought suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of the New York against the City, the NYPD, and the individual police officers involved in her arrest and search.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that she had been falsely arrested, that the police had employed excessive force during the arrest, and that her strip search violated the Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable search and seizure.[SENTMARKER]After a jury trial, the jury found in favor of the defendants on the claims of unlawful arrest, excessive force, and battery, and awarded her $5,000,000 in punitive damages, as well as $19,645 in compensatory damages.[SENTMARKER]The City appealed the award of punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2000, the court granted the City's motion for entry of judgment in accordance with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the court denied the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court has not yet issued an opinion on the case.
