pegasus_output_sents: On December 31, 2011, a group of female inmates of the Delaware County jail filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jailers would "bargain" with the female inmates to show their breasts in exchange for cigarettes, cupcakes, snacks, candy, personal items, and other things they could not obtain for themselves while in the jail.[SENTMARKER]In response to the retaliation, the women wrote a letter, which they all signed, begging for help from the outside.[SENTMARKER]The letter resulted in an investigation by the Sheriff, and the Sheriff found that the women were not being discriminated against.[SENTMARKER]The women filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by Judge James H. Payne on January 11, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents:
On April 21, 2005, a woman filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that the City of Philadelphia of had an unconstitutional practice of strip searching all pre-trial detainees, regardless of criminal charge or reasonable suspicion.[SENTMARKER]On February 20, 2009, the parties entered into a $5.9 million settlement.[SENTMARKER]
The Court entered final approval of the settlement on November 3, 2009.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the Philadelphia Prison System and the City of Philadelphia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of strip-searching all pretrial detainees upon admission to the prison system was unconstitutional and violated the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of $5,900,000 to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the Court on March 6, 2009 and is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The defendants have since changed their strip-search policy.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2007, the plaintiff filed suit against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that his constitutional rights were violated when he was strip searched in front of other inmates upon arrival at the Lancaster County Prison after being arrested for a parole violation.[SENTMARKER]He sought class action certification, declaratory judgment, a preliminary and permanent injunction, and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement with the court on July 29, 2009 that affirmed a new policy of not strip searching detainees arrested for minor offenses and created a fund to compensate those who had been strip searched.[SENTMARKER]The case ended on April 9, 2010 when the court certified the class and granted final approval to the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2007, a man charged with a nonfelony offense filed a class action lawsuit against the County of Lancaster and the County Prison Board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his Fourth Amendment rights by conducting a strip search in violation of his rights against unreasonable searches guaranteed by the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case on July 28, 2009, with a settlement fund that provided for an initial contribution of $1,946,860.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2009, the parties filed an amended complaint, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, seeking to change the policies and procedures of the county and the prison board.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2009, Judge Paul Diamond granted the parties' motion for approval of the settlement agreement and conditionally certified the class.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on March 23, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The defendants are each responsible for the damages of the Plaintiff and members of the Class.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a county jail inmate who suffered scarring and isolation from multiple MRSA infections was successful in obtaining a settlement against county defendants for their alleged failure to implement appropriate quarantine protocols and correct medical care, and for maintaining unsanitary conditions at the jail.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 19, 2009, an inmate at the Northampton County prison in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the county and its private contractor, Prime Care Medical, Inc., alleging violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Civil Rights Act of 1866.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the prison and its medical unit had a history of inhumane and unsanitary conditions, creating a breeding ground for diseases such as MRSA.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate and necessary medical treatment to inmates, failed to generate, maintain, and/or preserve accurate medical records, and denied Plaintiff his right to be free from deliberate indifference to his medical needs and well-being.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that they had not violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This class action case was brought by prisoners of the Dauphin County Prison against the County of Dauphin, PA, seeking monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief for conducting unconstitutional and unnecessary strip searches upon all persons placed in the Dauphin County Prison, as of September 16, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2009, resulting in monetary and injunctive relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Middle district of Pennsylvania on behalf of individuals charged with misdemeanor offenses, violations of probation or parole or intermediate punishment, or other minor offenses upon their admission to the Dauphin County Prison.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Dauphin County and its Corrections Officers unlawfully strip-searched everyone admitted into the prison, in violation of their rights against unreasonable searches under the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 26, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay a total of $2, 160,500.00 to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The settlement fund will be used to pay for the claims of the class members, the administrative costs of the settlement, an incentive award to the named plaintiffs, and the attorneys' fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in March 2010 against the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered by Judge Thomas I. Vanaskie of the district court.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: The ACLU of Pennsylvania filed this class action suit on behalf of pretrial detainees in a PA jail with subclasses of those who were at a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions in the jail failed to meet CDC recommendations and amounted to a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on April 9, 2020 seeking immediate release from ACJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties then began working on a consent order to implement public health measures to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 in the jail, which was approved by the court on May 27.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was extended on August 24 and the plaintiffs habeas and ADA claims remain in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2020, three individuals held at the Allegheny County Sheriff's Office in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Pennsylvania alleging violations of their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights by failing to protect them from constitutionally deficient conditions that place them at a substantial risk of severe injury or death from COVID-19 while at the jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a consent decree in April 2020 that required the defendants to implement measures to protect inmates and employees from the virus.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree did not resolve the plaintiffs' claims that the jail violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a motion for preliminary injunctive relief, and the parties reached an agreement to clarify and/or supplement existing policies informed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Philadelphia Department of Prisons (PDO) in an effort to protect the plaintiffs and reduce the spread of the virus within the ACJ.[SENTMARKER]On April 7, 2020, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement the consent decree and to provide the plaintiffs with adequate medical care.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment did not address the plaintiffs’ claims that they were denied their right to be released from the jail because of their medical condition.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 6, 2010, the Prison Legal News filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for South Carolina under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Berkeley County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as damages, claiming that the defendants' unlawfully censored and excluded the plaintiff's books and magazines protected by the 1st and 14th Amendments, which are sent to individual subscribers in custody at the Berkeley County Detention Center (BCDC).[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2011, the United States filed a Complaint in intervention pursuant to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, 42 U.S.C. § 14141, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized 42 Persons Act of 2000, U.S.C. § 2000cc.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2012, Judge Sol Blatt, Jr., issued the consent injunction requiring the defendants to implement new policies regarding incoming mail and access to religious materials.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2015, the Human Rights Defense Center (HRD Center) and Prison Legal News (PLN) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that the detention center's policy of banning all publications sent by mail to detainees violated the First and 14th Amendment rights of prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, without notice to senders, the Detention Center routinely refused to deliver these expressive works to detainees.[SENTMARKER]In the past two years, the defendants have denied numerous prisoner requests for expressive material, including educational materials required by a correspondence education course, other books, magazines, and legal newsletters.[SENTMARKER]As one example, Defendants denied access to pamphlets, newsletters, and other Christian publications sought by an inmate incarcerated at the center for much of the last two years.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to allow detainees to receive publications and religious material in accordance with the First Amendment and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Act of 1994 (RLUIPA).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a program to provide inmates with access to non-Christian religious texts.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide detainees with a library to access to reading materials, including books and magazines.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: This 2017 class action lawsuit was brought by a former inmate of the Davidson County Jail in the U.S. District for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments in failing to prevent the spread of scabies in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff has not yet filed a motion to certify class.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2017, a former inmate of the Davidson County Detention Facility filed this class action lawsuit against CoreCivic, LLC, a private company that owns and operates the detention facility in Nashville, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff and other inmates were exposed to Sarcoptes scabiei (hereafter "Scabies"), caused by the spread ofparasitic mites, while in the custody of the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant failed to adequately screen those entering its facility, respond to inmate requests for medical attention, treat those infested with the parasite, quarantine the infected individuals in its care, or to take any other precautions to prevent the spreading of scabies outside the facility.[SENTMARKER]The class is defined as all male inmates exposed to and infested with scabies, who are, who have been, or who in the future may become, housed at the Defendant's facility in Davidson County.[SENTMARKER]In response to the Plaintiff's complaints, the Defendant retaliated against other inmates, including inmate J.N., for requesting medical treatment and threatened him with disciplinary action.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff and the class members.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A deaf prisoner of the El Paso County jails sued the County in the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas for their failure to accommodate his disability.[SENTMARKER]He was held for eleven days without access to an attorney or an interpreter, in violation of the Americans With disabilities Act ans Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. A private settlement was reached in July 2012 which, according to reports, required installation of videophones in the County jails.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 9, 2012, a deaf man filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the County of El Paso, Texas, seeking injunctive and declaratory relief, actual damages, attorneys' fees, litigation expenses, and costs as redress from the County for their unlawful discrimination based on his disability.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Jose Luis Rodriguez, was in custody awaiting trial on a criminal charge when he was denied access to the County's Downtown Detention Facility and the Annex Jail because he had a hearing impairment that substantially limits major life activities.[SENTMARKER]He repeatedly requested that the County provide him with videophone devices, interpreters, or access to closed captioning during his arraignment and during his court appearance.[SENTMARKER]The officers at the annex jail refused to provide Mr. Rodriguez with an interpreter.[SENTMARKER]He was handcuffed and put in a cell, and the officers ignored his requests.[SENTMARKER]The judge asked him if he was a US citizen and he replied that he was not a citizen.[SENTMARKER]The court denied his request, and he was taken to the jail, where the officers refused to give him access to a videophone device, interpreter, or closed captioning.[SENTMARKER]The officer at the jail then refused his request for a copy of the judge's order and refused to allow him to use a cell phone to call his attorney.[SENTMARKER]After being handcuffed and placed in the cell, the judge refused to grant his request to be able to use the cell phone.[SENTMARKER]The defendant refused to make its facilities accessible to the plaintiff and denied his requests for a closed captioning device and interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by the court on January 10, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss the case, and ordered the defendant to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees, costs, and expenses.

gold_sents: On March 15, 2012, a group of juvenile prisoners filed a lawsuit in the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Jail, claiming violations of their physical and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Preliminary injunction was denied.[SENTMARKER]Class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]A bench trial was held on from November 18, 2013 to December 18, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, 2015, Judge Merryday issued an opinion denying relief to the plaintiffs, holding that plaintiffs failed to show defendants' violations of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] April 2013 | Central County Jail | Florida | Southern Poverty Law Center ||| May 2014 | U.S. District Court | Middle District of Florida ||| August 2014 ||| Florida Sheriff's Association ||| Corizon Health, Inc.<n>On April 23, 2013, a group of inmates at the Central County jail in Bartow, Florida, filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights under the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them access to food, medical care, education, recreation, and communication with their families.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment for the defendants, but the district court denied the officers' claim of qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the Fifth Circuit and remanded the case for trial.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, and the case was settled in August 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three minors represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center, Florida Justice Institute, Inc., and Florida Legal Services, filed suit on September 4, 2019 in the Northern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought class action certification to represent children subject to solitary confinement in DJJ-run detention centers.[SENTMARKER]The defendant's summary judgment motion on the merits was denied on December 6, 2019, and the case is in ongoing mediation talks.
pegasus_output_sents: July 24, 2017 | Florida | U.S. District Court | Northern District of Florida ||| American Disabilities Act ||| Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) ||| July 24, 2018 ||| August 31, 2018 | ||| January 31, 2019 ||| June 30, 2019 | July 24, 2019 | August 31, 2020 ||| September 30, 2020 | July 31, 2021 | August 30, 2021 | September 30, 2021 .<n>On July 24, 2017, a group of children with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Florida Department Of Juvenile Justice (DJJ) was violating their rights under the Americans With Disabilities Act by placing them in solitary confinement when they engage in nonconforming behaviors due to their disabilities, instead of housing them in settings where they can receive treatment and services that they need to live safely and with others.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that DJJ was subjecting children diagnosed with serious mental illness, trauma, learning disabilities, intellectual disabilities, and who had engaged in acts of self-injury or attempted suicide to a risk of harm.[SENTMARKER]In August 31, 2018, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: DOJ's investigation of the conditions at the Hawaii Youth Correctional Facility ("HYCF") in August 2004 concluded that the facility lacked policies to protect the detained youth from abuse or suicide risks.[SENTMARKER]DOJ recommended reforms at the HYCF through a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) that was executed by the parties.[SENTMARKER]This case was brought to retain jurisdiction of the district court of Hawaii's jurisdiction over the case until a final order is entered to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2004, the United States Attorney's Office for the District of Hawaii filed this lawsuit in the United District Court for the district of Hawaii against the State of Hawaii and the Hawaii Department of Education alleging violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 (CRIPA) and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the State failed to provide access to medical and mental health care, adequate special education instruction, and supervision for youth at the Hawaii Youth correctional facility in Kailua, Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that there was a lack of harm protection measures in place at the facility.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2006, the parties entered a memorandum of agreement, which was approved by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the DOJ would have the right to conduct unannounced visits to the facility in the event that the Department was required to access youth or records there.[SENTMARKER]The memorandum also stated that the parties would have no remedy or action available for the State's alleged breach of this Agreement other than the reinstatement of the complaint that this Agreement settled.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on February 9, 2006.

gold_sents: The Attorney General filed suit against the state of Ohio, its governor, the director of youth services, and the superintendents of its juvenile correctional facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 for an alleged pattern or practice of violating the rights of juvenile detainees under the 14th Amendment, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that Ohio failed to protect the youth at its facilities from harm and undue risk of harm, failed to meet their medical and mental health needs, and failed to provide adequate special education services.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed as a result of Department of Justice (DOJ) investigations into the conditions of confinement at the Scioto and Marion centers that began in 2005.[SENTMARKER]The Marion facility closed soon after the first injunction in this case.[SENTMARKER]Ohio achieved substantial compliance in 2015, and the consent decree was terminated on December 3, 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) notified the State of Ohio of its intent to investigate conditions of confinement at the Scioto Juvenile Correctional Facility (Scioto) in Delaware, Ohio, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C.  1997, and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 (Violent Crime Act)  14141.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, the Cohen Report addressed issues regarding protection from harm, medical care, mental health care, and special education at Scioto.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2008, the Justice Department and the State signed a stipulation for injunctive relief (the Stipulation) concerning conditions atScioto.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement on the resolution of the plaintiffs’ claims, which the Court approved on March 29, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree with the State to remedy conditions at all DYS facilities, which was approved on June 24, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The parties have since amended their agreement twice, and the parties have agreed to withdraw without prejudice its motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by Kelly Dedel and One in 37 Research, Inc.

gold_sents: The juvenile plaintiff brought suit against the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center, challenging the center's policy of strip-searching all juveniles admitted to the Detention Center, without any reasonable suspicion that the juveniles were concealing weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit overturned the District Court's ruling, holding that the search of the named plaintiff did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the parties reached a monetary settlement before having to relitigate the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2000, a former juvenile detainee filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of S. Dakota alleging that her civil rights were violated when she was strip searched and questioned about her religious beliefs at the Minnehaha county juvenile detention center in Sioux Falls, South Dakota.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the detention center had a policy of conducting strip searches of all minors regardless of the type of offense they were arrested for or whether there was reason to believe that the minors had weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified two classes of plaintiffs, one for injunctive relief and one for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 1999, the district court denied the defendants' motions for summary judgment and remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with its August 9, 2006 opinion in NG v. Connecticut, 382 F.3d 225 (2d Cir.[SENTMARKER]2004), which held that the JDC's written search policy in effect in August 1999 was unconstitutional and that the subsequent changes to the policy did not cure the constitutional defects.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2004, the court granted partial summary judgment for the plaintiffs on the Fourth Amendment claim.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to reconsider, which was denied by the Eighth Circuit, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice in accordance with the tenus of the settlement agreement, and to pay the plaintiffs' costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 27, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The parties then entered into an agreement to settle the case in which the defendants agreed not to conduct strip searches or question the religious beliefs or practices of any of the plaintiffs for three years.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on August 9, 2004 and was subject to review by the Ninth Circuit in August 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit reversed its decision, and sent the case back to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]On February 4, 2009, the case was remanded to the lower court for further hearings.

gold_sents: This suit was filed May 7, 2004.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs were individuals who had been involuntarily civilly confined pursuant to Sexually Violent Predator Act into the custody of the Florida Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Children and Families in the Florida Civil Commitment Center (FCCC).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs argued that the State failed to provide adequate rehabilitive treatment necessary for their eventual recovery and release.[SENTMARKER]In November 2009, after five years of discovery and motions practice, the case settled, with the State agreeing to implement policies that addressed all the plaintiffs' allegations.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2004, a group of sex offenders who were civilly detained at the Florida Civil commitment center filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by failing to provide adequate treatment, mental health services, and on-site medical services to the residents confined at the facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a class-action settlement in June 2009, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In June 2009, the parties filed a final action plan, which was approved by the district court, and the parties entered into a contract monitoring agreement with GEO Group, Inc. in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the motion, removed the case from the trial calendar, and gave the parties 60 days to file a motion seeking approval of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2009, the court entered a final order dismissing the case with prejudice, finding that the settlement was fair, reasonable and adequate.

gold_sents: On February 27, 2002, four individuals involuntarily detained by the Illinois Department of Human Services ("DHS") pursuant to the Sexually Violent Persons Commitment Act (“SVP Act”) on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for Northern Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants failed to provide adequate and meaningful health treatment to the plaintiffs and those similarly situated and the treatment and care that was given was punitive and Constitutionally inadequate.[SENTMARKER]In 2005, Judge Leinenweber granted the plaintiffs’ demand for declaratory relief concerning the previous Special or Secure Management Status (“SMS”) used at the Joliet Treatment and Detention Facility (the “TDF”) stating that it was unconstitutional; however all of the plaintiffs’ remaining claims were denied including the claim of inadequate treatment.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2003, a group of individuals who had been civilly committed to the custody of the Illinois department of human services filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the conditions of confinement at the Joliet facility were impermissibly punitive and that the treatment they received there was constitutionally inadequate.[SENTMARKER]The court entered judgment in favor of the defendants on all claims except one, and granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice and without costs with leave to move to reinstate on or before October 13, 2009.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014, a number of prisoners in Louisiana filed a class action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 claiming that the state violated the ADA, Rehabilitation Act, and their 14th Amendment due process rights by keeping them incarcerated despite their being found not guilty by reason of insanity and committed by the court to the state's mental health facility.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2016, the Court dismissed the case without prejudice to the right to reopen it within sixty days if the parties did not settle.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently settled, agreeing to send individuals found not guilty due to insanity to mental health institutions.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2016, the Advocacy Center filed this class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Departments of Health & Hospitals and the Department of Mental Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, Title II, the American Disabilities Act, and Section 504, of the Rehabiitation Act of 1973, by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care to individuals who have been found not guilty by reason of insanity (NGRI) by the courts.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs' reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]In the event that the parties cannot resolve a future claim for attorneys' fees or costs, the parties agreed to submit a report to the court on the first working day of each month beginning November 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the court would have thirty (30) days from the date of the settlement to come into or establish compliance with this settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 16, 2016.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2001, a group of Medicaid-eligible children, acting through their parents or guardians, filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Massachusetts Medicaid program failed to provide home-based mental health services to children suffering from serious emotional disturbances (SED) by failing to provide early and periodic screening, diagnostic, and treatment services (EPSDT) and by not requiring a primary care visit or EPSDT screening as a prerequisite for an eligible child to receive MassHealth behavioral health services.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint remedial plan, which was largely adopted by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed and the case was remanded to the First Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit remanded the case to the District Court, holding that the defendants had failed to demonstrate substantial compliance with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The U.S. sued the State of Mississippi under the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. alleged that the State knowingly failed to provide adequate mental health programs for adults with mental illness and segregated adults with disabilities in their State-run hospitals.[SENTMARKER]After a four-week bench trial, the court found that the health system violated the ADA and required a special master to determine and oversee the remedial process.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2016, the United States filed this lawsuit against the State of Mississippi in the Southern District of Mississippi, alleging that the State was violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by unnecessarily requiring thousands of Mississippi residents with mental illness to receive services in state-run psychiatric hospitals instead of community-based services.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the state was violating Title II of the ADA by failing to provide services to qualified individuals with disabilities in the most integrated settings appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the State filed two motions for summary judgment, one of which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in January 2019, and the case was dismissed in March 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, and the State is required to comply with the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a student at Hunter College of the City University of New York, brought this action against the College and its administrators on August 20, 2004, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff, who was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, brought claims under the Fair Housing Act, the ADA, and Section 504 after the College forced her to leave its dormitory following her suicide attempt in June 2004.[SENTMARKER]The case eventually settled, with defendants paying plaintiff attorneys' fees and damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 7, 2004, a student with a disability filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the New York against Hunter College, the owner and manager of Brookdale Residence Hall, a dormitory, and two employees of Hunter College.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged intentional discrimination and disparate impact under the Fair Housing Act; failure to provide a reasonable accommodation under the FHAA; and failure to make a reasonable accommodations under the Rehab Act.[SENTMARKER]In view of the seriousness of the harm inflicted in prior episodes, the district court granted the plaintiff’s application for a preliminary injunction, finding that an additional year’s delay in her medical studies would irreparably harm her, while he concluded that NYU would suffer no hardships.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit reversed the grant of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that by signing the agreement, the plaintiff did not waive any rights under the ADA, Rehabilitation Act or the Fair housing Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 15, 1996, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, against the State of Tennessee, the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation (DMH/MR) and the Memphis Mental Health Institute (MMHI), in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Memphis Division.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 1996, the same day as the complaint was filed, the parties submitted a joint motion for entry of a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement the defendants agreed to implement all policies, systems, procedures and rules currently in place, to provide quarterly status reports, provide the government access to the facilities, records, patients, and employees of MMHI, and to confer in good faith on the provisions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 1997, the Court entered judgment in accordance with the consent decree and terminated the case, retaining jurisdiction for necessary enforcement of the decree.[SENTMARKER]And, on September 18, 1998, the District Court (Judge Gibbons) granted the parties' joint motion for a stipulation and order, effectuating the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On June 21, 2005, the District Court (Judge Bernice B. Donald) granted the parties' joint motion for an order partially terminating the consent decree and approved the parties' stipulation for supplemental relief.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 15, 1996, the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District Of Tennessee against the Memphis Mental health Institute (MMHI) in Memphis, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act of 1990, MMHI violated the constitutional rights of its patients by failing to provide adequate, professional nursing care to its patients.[SENTMARKER]In September 18, 1998, the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required that the practice of restraining patients and then placing patients in a locked-door room must cease immediately.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required that MMHI provide its patients with a sufficient number of registered nurses.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that, until the consent decree was in effect, there would be no further violations of the rights of MMHI patients.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on September 18, 1998.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the decree is in effect.

gold_sents: On February 17, 2004 the United States filed a complaint against Breathitt County, Kentucky, and Breathitt County Geriatric Corporation for violating CRIPA, 42 U.S.C. §1997, after the county failed to take action to remedy the violations laid out after the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") conducted an investigation of conditions at the Nim Henson.[SENTMARKER]On February 19, 2004, a settlement agreement was entered with the cour, and two years after the settlement agreement, the government found that the Nim Henson Nursing Home had been complying with all the terms of the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Kentucky filed this civil rights lawsuit against Breathitt County, Kentucky and the Nim Henson Geriatric Center (Nim Henson) under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and implementing regulations.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide adequate medical, nursing, nutritional, wound, restorative, and psychiatric care and services to Nim Henson residents and to otherwise protect them from harm.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants failed to provide the residents with adequate functional furniture, such as dining room chairs and recliners, as well as adequate weight monitoring and the use of thiothixine (Navane), an antipsychotic medication, without justification.[SENTMARKER]On March 6, 2003, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into a consent decree with the Attorney General in which they agreed not to violate the ADA or implement any regulations for the next five years.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the County to pay the residents of Nim Henson a total of $325,000 in civil penalties.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: On January 31, 2006, subscribers to or customers of telephone or internet services that AT&T provided filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against AT&T Corp. and AT&T Inc., claiming that the defendants' participation in the federal government's program to monitor and collect Americans' telephone and internet communications was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The United States quickly intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was dismissed based upon retroactive legislation.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal and the Supreme Court declined to hear the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 2001, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the National Security Agency (NSA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants participated in a government program to intercept and analyze vast quantities of Americans' telephone and Internet communications without the authorization of a court and in violation of the First and Fourth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, an injunction enjoining the defendants from participating in the government's surveillance program, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the district court dismissed the case on April 28, 2006.[SENTMARKER]On August 2007, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]On June 2007, the parties agreed that the plaintiffs had standing to sue the defendants under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) and that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to dismiss the plaintiffs’ claims for lack of standing.

gold_sents: In March 2018, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Transportation Security Administration violated the Freedom of Information Act for wrongfully withholding its records about electronic device searches.[SENTMARKER]The TSA ultimately provided a letter stating it does not conduct device searches, and the ACLU agreed to dismiss the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) seeking information about the federal government's searches of electronic devices at airports.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU-NC is a non-profit civil rights organization that has its principal place of business in the district.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request sought records about TSA's policies, procedures, and protocols regarding the search of airplane passengers' 21 electronic devices; training of relevant personnel related to the search or examination of 22 electronic devices, and equipment used to search, examine, or extract data from electronic 23 devices.[SENTMARKER]As of the date of the filing of this action, Plaintiff has not received a 10 determination from TSA of whether TSA will comply with the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On August 23, 2018, the court entered a final judgment in favor of TSA, finding that TSA had wrongfully withheld the requested records from Plaintiff and had failed to comply with its statutory time for the processing of FOIA 21 requests.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment also found that Plaintiff had exhausted the applicable administrative remedies with respect to the release and disclosure of 25 of the requested documents because TSA continued to improperly withhold agency 26 records in violation of FOIA.[SENTMARKER]As part of the final judgment, the court awarded Plaintiff its litigation costs and reasonable attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint, filed on June 27, 2017, seeks to enhance knowledge about discriminatory immigration policy regarding Muslims, Latinos, and other members of groups disfavored by the Department of State (DOS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the FOIA requests sought greater understanding of the administration's immigration enforcement policies out of a concern that the defendants have targeted individuals on the basis of actual or perceived religion, ethnicity, race, or national origin in enforcing their immigration policies.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought "disclosure of agency policies, communications, and statistics related to visa processing and visa issuances for individuals applying abroad; to adjudication of entry document applications; and to screening and searching of individuals arriving at U.S. ports of entry."[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2017, the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) and the Muslim American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF) filed this FOIA request in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Eastern District of New York, seeking the release of records related to the detention, screening, and processing of individuals by Customs and Border Protection (CBP) at ports of entry and preclearance locations, as well as the processing of visa petitions and applications for various immigration benefits.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought expedited processing and waiver of fees on multiple grounds.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on November 15, 2019, in which the parties agreed to comply with the terms of the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, requiring the defendants to produce the requested records within six weeks of the date of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 13, 2010, the ACLU filed a FOIA request to the Departments of Defense, Justice, the Department of State, and the CIA seeking records relating to the use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) by the CIA and the Armed Forces for the purpose of targeting and killing individuals since September 11, 2001.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU's complaint alleged that the DOD, DOJ, and DOJ had not provided any basis for withholding responsive records.[SENTMARKER]On September 9, 2011, the district court granted the CIA's motion for summary judgment in favor of the agency.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the CIA was entitled to summary judgment, reasoning that the agency's response was independently justified under FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3 of the FOIA Act. On October 26, 2011, the parties voluntarily dismissed the remaining defendants from the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 21, 2013, the Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Security Agency (NSA) alleging that the NSA violated the FOIA by failing to disclose agency records that were responsive to EPIC's FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]EPIC sought information related to the Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative (CNCI), an initiative established by former President George W. Bush to ensure the security of the nation's online infrastructure.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the records were properly classified and non-segregable under Exemption 1 of the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted summary judgment to the defendants in part and denied their appeal.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the issue raised in the case is moot now that the defendants have released the record at issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: When the FBI received in 2004 a “FISA Alert Report Form” seeking information on the plaintiff in this case, it was assumed to be related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, when it was in fact merely from a private company called Financial Institutions Security Association.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the misunderstanding, the plaintiff’s name was erroneously placed on government watchlists, and she was fired from her job as a nurse working at the Federal Reserve Board.[SENTMARKER]After unsuccessfully filing a Freedom of Information Act request seeking records relating to the error, she brought this lawsuit against several federal agencies, seeking to force the agencies to produce the requested records.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2005, a woman filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request with the FBI, seeking all records pertaining to her, including the FISA Alert.[SENTMARKER]The FBI refused her request because the records were classified as "Confidential," and the FBI conducted a search for responsive records once additional information was provided.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on November 8, 2011, by stipulation.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2012, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, alleging that the FBI failed to comply with FOIA and the Privacy Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, finding that the defendants had violated the privacy provisions of the FOIA by denying the plaintiffs their right to seek amendment of her records.[SENTMARKER]The court also found that the plaintiffs had violated Executive Order 12958, as amended, by retroactively classifying information without the personal participation or under the direction of the agency head, the deputy agency head or the AAG-Admin.

pegasus_output_sents: In December 2005, the ACLU filed FOIA requests under FOIA seeking the release of records related to the National Security Agency’s secret surveillance program to intercept, without prior judicial authorization, the telephone and Internet communications of people inside the United States.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2001, the Department of Justice (DOJ) issued a secret memo regarding the government’s legal authority for surveillance activity, wiretapping, eavesdropping, and other signals intelligence operations directed at communications to or from US citizens.[SENTMARKER]On December 16, 2005, the plaintiffs filed a FOIA request with the DOJ seeking expedited processing and release of agency records regarding the Bush Administration’s policy of conducting surveillance of domestic communications without the prior authorization of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ Office of Information and Privacy and the Office of Legal Counsel granted the ACLU’s request for expedited processing, but the plaintiffs moved for consolidation with another FOIA case before the district court.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Mar.[SENTMARKER]3, 2017, plaintiffs The James Madison Project and the news website The Daily Beast's executive editor sued various federal agencies under FOIA, seeking disclosure of agency records related to the implementation of President Trump's Jan.[SENTMARKER]27, 2017 Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]Production is ongoing as of June 6.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 3, 2017, The James Madison Project (JMP) and The Daily Beast's Executive Editor, Noah Shachtman, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice (DOJ), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) alleging that the defendants improperly withheld documents related to an immigration executive order (Executive Order) in violation of the FOIA Act.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA Act is a federal law that provides for the release of certain government records to the public in the course of a FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the Defendants failed to comply with FOIA requests submitted to the DOJ's Office of Legal Counsel (OLC), DHS, and the four components of DHS (USCIS, CBP, TSA, and ICE) under the Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the Defendants' initial search located several thousand pages of records, which require de-duplication and further review to determine how many are actually responsive.[SENTMARKER]ICE's search located approximately 3,500 pages of potentially responsive records.[SENTMARKER]The Complaint further alleges that CBP is making rolling productions and uploading records relating to Executive Order to its online FOIA library.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court entered a final judgment in favor of the Defendants on May 2, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the Defendants to provide the Plaintiffs with a copy of all documents withheld under FOIA, including any documents that were not responsive to FOIA requests.

gold_sents: Muslim Advocates filed this suit against DHS under FOIA, seeking information regarding the government's border searches of electronic devices in the possession of persons from the seven Muslim-majority countries covered by President Trump's Jan.[SENTMARKER]27 and Mar.[SENTMARKER]6 Executive Orders, as well as by all persons whom CBP agents "perceived to be Muslim."
pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2017, a Muslim advocacy group filed a FOIA request in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia (D.C.) seeking documents and information relating to the government's border searches of electronic devices in the possession of persons from seven Muslim-majority countries covered by President Donald Trump's executive order.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the government violated FOIA by failing to determine whether to comply with the request within 30 business days, failing to immediately thereafter notify Plaintiff of such determination and the reasons therefor, and failing to provide reasonable costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the request for expedited processing and a civil waiver fee, and the parties filed a joint status report on January 19, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On January 19, 2017, the court entered an order requiring the parties to file additional joint status reports at subsequent intervals of 45 days.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that they would continue to work together to determine the scope of the government’s obligation under the FOIA, and that CBP would search its complaint management system for complaints containing the terms "iPad," "twitter," "password," "cell," and "cell."[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to make the requested referral to the Office of Public Affairs.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2017, CBP conducted a search within the complaint for the complaint group.[SENTMARKER]On March 7, 2017, the parties agreed to consider the request, and CBP agreed to conduct a search in the complaint management group for complaint groups containing the term "cell"

gold_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Protect Democracy Project sued DOJ under FOIA seeking records on whether DOJ was consulted regarding the travel ban EO.[SENTMARKER]This case has been consolidated into and continues at NS-DC-0112.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 4, 2018, a civil rights group filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Washington, DC, against the Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking access to records related to an executive order issued by the DOJ on January 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request was filed under 5 U.s.C.  552(a)(4)(B) and  552(a)(1).[SENTMARKER]The DOJ responded to the FOIA request on February 27, 2017, stating that it would not respond to the request within the required time limit and would be unable to comply with the statutory deadline for responding.[SENTMARKER]On March 27, 2017, the DOJ sent a letter from its Executive Office for Immigration Review stating that no responsive records were located and closing the review.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2018, the DOJ's Office of Legal Counsel wrote to Plaintiff to acknowledge receipt of the request and assign it a tracking number.[SENTMARKER]The following day, Plaintiff sent a FOIA request to the DOJ seeking the following records: Any and all records created between January 20, 2017 and the present date indicating that the Executive Order was reviewed prior to the Order’s issuance; any and all non-exempt records or portions of records responsive to Plaintiff’s request; and a Vaughn index of any records due to a claim of exemption; and, in the case of an adverse determination, an award of attorney fees and other reasonable litigation costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted Plaintiff's request for a fee waiver.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Chief Judge Beryl A. Howell of the District Court on May 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2018, the court granted the motion for summary judgment in favor of the DOJ, granted the request for an order requiring the DOJ to produce the requested records within 20 business days of receipt, and granted the parties to file a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a motion for partial summary judgment, which was granted by Judge Howell on May 6, 2018.

gold_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Protect Democracy Project sued OMB under FOIA to compel disclosure of records about federal agencies consulted prior and subsequent to the implementation of President Trump's Jan.[SENTMARKER]27 travel ban Executive Order 13769.[SENTMARKER]After consolidation with another suit against DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a rolling production with monthly status reports.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2019 the parties filed a joint stipulation of voluntary dismissal with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2017, The Protect Democracy Project, Inc. brought this action against the Office ofManagement and Budget (OMB) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) under the Freedom of information Act (FOIA) seeking the release of certain records regarding Executive Order 13769, "Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States" (Executive Order).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint status report, which determined that none of the material withheld from the request was appropriate for discretionary release.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the case would be consolidated in the District Court, which is the subject of the above-referenced matter.[SENTMARKER]Since the parties’ last joint status reports, OMB has completed its processing of Plaintiff’s FOIA request, and the parties have agreed that neither party will bear its own attorneys’ fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on behalf of an American citizen being detained by the United States military in Iraq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the Secretary of Defense under the federal habeas corpus statute, 28 U.S.C. §2241, the Non-Detention Act of 1971, and 18 U.S.C. § 4001(a) for injunctive relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Defense Department had detained the plaintiff since on or around September 14, 2017, after Syrian forces transferred him to U.S.[SENTMARKER]Custody.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2018, the Defense Department released the plaintiff and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2018, the court dismissed this case with prejudice and order each party to bear its own costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]In April 2019, the plaintiff sought to unseal the documents relating to the government’s proposed forcible transfer of the plaintiff into Syria.[SENTMARKER]The court reissued an unredacted version of the opinion on June 28, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2017, the ACLU filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Washington, DC, on behalf of an American citizen detained in Iraq by the Department of Defense.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU alleged that the detainee was being held without charge, without access to a court, or other meaningful opportunity to challenge his detention before a neutral decisionmaker.[SENTMARKER]The Defense Department moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, arguing that the ACLU had no standing to bring the action on the detainee's behalf.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the ACLU's motion for a preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court vacated the district court's decision and the preliminary injunction itself.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in principle that will resolve the case without the need for further litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal the decision.

gold_sents: On November 27, 2020, an informal foreign policy advisor to the Trump 2016 presidential campaign filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and various former DOJ and FBI officials that sought the warrant against him in their personal capacity violated his right to be free of unreasonable searches and seizures in connection with Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrants issued against him during the 2016 campaign.[SENTMARKER]He sought $75 million in compensatory damages, punitive damages, injunctive relief, and attorneys' fees for this case and a related Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) case used to gain information for this litigation under FISA, Bivens, the Federal Tort Claims Act, and the Privacy Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 26, 2019, the Plaintiff filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District court for the District of Columbia against the Departments of Justice (DOJ) and FBI (FBI) alleging that the defendants violated his constitutional rights under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) and the Privacy Act (Privacy Act) by targeting him because of his lawful association with the 2016 presidential campaign of Donald Trump.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff's complaint alleged that the DOJ and FBI targeted him because he was a source for the CIA.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants' unlawful actions allowed them to illegally spy (domestically and internationally) on Dr.[SENTMARKER]Page, a patriotic American citizen.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, January 2017, and April 2017, he was dismissed by the President of the United States on May 9, 2017.[SENTMARKER]In March 2018, he filed this suit against the DOJ in the District Court for the district of Columbia for violation of his rights under both the FISA and Privacy Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff is entitled to damages, including punitive damages, for violations of his right to privacy under the Constitution.

gold_sents: On September 5, 2012, an individual U.S. citizen residing in Illinois and two organizations that sought to advocate for that individual filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the U.S. Department of Treasury, seeking a declaration that the Defendants' designation of the individual plaintiff as a "specially designated terrorist" was unlawful and an injunction against its continued application.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the lawsuit after the federal government removed the individual Plaintiff's name from the Specially Designated Terror List.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2012, a civil rights group and a Quaker organization filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois on behalf of a man living in Bridgeview, Illinois, who was designated a "Specially Designated Terrorist" by the Department of the Treasury in August 1995 for his alleged involvement with Hamas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Salah's First Amendment rights to freedom of speech and association, and his right to due process.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2012, the government initiated criminal prosecution of Adel Daoud in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The government charged Daoud with attempting to damage and destroy a building by means of explosion.[SENTMARKER]In 2013, the government added the charge of soliciting a crime of violence, murder for hire, and witness tampering.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit addressed the tension between the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and the evidentiary investigation required by the test laid out in Franks v. Delaware, 438 U.S. 154 (1978), for determining the legality of a warrant.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit reversed the order on June 16, 2014; the defendant appealed the decision to the Supreme Court but cert was denied on February 23, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The underlying criminal case continues.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 29, 2014, the defendant filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, alleging that the government violated his Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) by failing to disclose classified information to his defense counsel.[SENTMARKER]The district court's order required the government to disclose to defense counsel highly sensitive classified information based on Section 106 of FISA.[SENTMARKER]The defendant's motion was granted in part and denied in part without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the Supreme Court in 2013 for lack of Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit reversed that decision in June 2014, holding that the district court did not abuse its discretion by ordering the disclosure of classified information.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a hearing on the matter, which was scheduled for November 26, 2014.[SENTMARKER]On November 26, 2014, the parties agreed that the defendant was competent to stand trial.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the government's request to dismiss the case without prejudice, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On October 17, 2013, the ACLU filed a lawsuit requesting an injunction forcing the DOJ to comply with a FOIA request regarding their policy on giving notice to criminal defendants against whom it intends to use evidence obtained from warrantless surveillance, including information obtained under surveillance orders authorized by the FISA Amendments Act § 702.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2105, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, and issued an order requiring the DOJ to conduct a further search for responsive documents, and disclose any that were not subject to FOIA exemptions.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, ruling that the DOJ's searches were adequate, and that all but one of the documents found by the DOJ were protected by FOIA's Exemption 5.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2017, the Court granted DOJ's renewed motion for summary judgment, finding that the remaining documents were properly withheld under FOIA Exemption 5.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2013, the ACLU filed this FOIA request under the Freedom of information Act (FOIA) seeking records related to the government’s use of evidence derived from warrantless surveillance in criminal prosecutions.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU challenged both the adequacy of the search and the applicability of Exemption 5 to the withheld documents, and the parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment on these two issues.[SENTMARKER]On October 17, 2013, the court granted the ACLU’s summary judgment motion in part, finding that the DOJ had improperly limited its search under part 3 of its request by reading the word “added” into the request where it had not been written, and ordered DOJ to conduct a new search without the improperly-governing term and release any responsive records not entitled to be searched under Exemption 5.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the Court granted the DOJ’s motion for summary judgement on the issue of segregability with respect to the documents withheld by the DOJ, with the Court concluding that the documents are protected by the exemption and do not contain segregable information components.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for an injunction, seeking to enjoin the government from assessing fees for the processing of the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted an injunction on October 17, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the matter in part on September 27, 2016.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 4, 2016, the U.S. Department of Justice sent letters to North Carolina public officials and agencies informing them that, by complying with Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Violence Against Women Act of 2013, they were engaging in a pattern or practice of discrimination in violation of three federal civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, the leaders of both chambers of the North Carolina General Assembly, and the American Civil Liberties Union of North Carolina, filed this declaratory judgment action in the United States District Court for the Middle District of the Carolinas.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to intervene on June 6, 2016, and the case was dismissed on June 10, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the plaintiffs would be required to comply with the provisions of Title VII, Title IX, and VAWA.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the case would be dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: In June 2014, a same-sex couple who had been lawfully married outside the State of Alabama filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that Alabama's refusal to recognize the marriages of same-sex couples validly entered into outside of the State violated the Due Process Clause and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent to the Obergefell decision in June 2015 by the Supreme Court, Judge R. pegasus_output_sents: Plaintiffs were a same-sex couple who were lawfully married outside the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]They brought this action to challenge the constitutionality of Section 36.03 of the Alabama Constitution and Alabama Code  30-1-19 (the "Alabama Marriage Prohibitions"), which prohibit the State from recognizing the marriages of samesex couples entered into in other jurisdictions.[SENTMARKER]The couple sought a declaration that Alabama's refusal to recognize their marriage violated their rights under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, and the defendants moved to dismiss this case as moot in light of Obergefell.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2015, the parties filed a Joint Status Report indicating that Defendants had effectuated all of the specific injunctive relief Plaintiffs sought in this case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed this case on December 8, 2015 without prejudice, concluding that the Aaron-Brushes were not prevailing parties.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 2004, a group of Medicaid providers and beneficiaries filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Health Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to prevent the State from implementing a five percent cutback in reimbursement rates for non-institutional services that was mandated by the California Legislature and scheduled to take effect on January 1, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the rate reduction violated the Medicaid statute, particularly the quality of care and equal access provisions, and they sought a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, and the case was dismissed on the basis of 11th Amendment immunity.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 30, 2010, entities that represented Medicaid service providers filed this lawsuit in federal court against the California Department of Health Care Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented intermediate care facilities for the developmentally disabled and other facilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctions preventing California from implementing legislation that would freeze Medicaid reimbursement rates for these facilities.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs sought relief under the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted a preliminary injunction, which was vacated and remanded following the defendants’ appeal.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2014, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The next day, Judge Snyder dismissed the consolidated case and ordered each party to bear its own attorney’s fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This lawsuit arose out of the funding provisions for elementary and secondary schools in the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) of 2020.[SENTMARKER]Filed by eight states (California, Michigan, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin), Washington D.C., and four school districts (Chicago, Cleveland, New York City, and San Francisco), the lawsuit challenged a July 1, 2020 interim final rule from the Department of Education about how the funds may be distributed between private and public schools.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting enforcement of the interim final rule.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, the court approved a permanent injunction that prevented the defendants from implementing the April 30 guidance and July 1 rule and from taking any action inconsistent with the proportional share formula in Section 1117 or other restrictions or penalties on the use of CARES Act funds.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction over the case for enforcement purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2020, the Department of Education (ED) issued an interim final rule (the Rule) to implement the CARES Act.[SENTMARKER]The Rule conflicts with the Plain Language of the Act and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and is arbitrary and capricious in several respects.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the District Court granted a preliminary injunction barring the Department from implementing or enforcing against the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the State of New Mexico, the Cleveland Municipal School District Board of Education, the City of Chicago, the Oakland Unified School District, and the Catholic Conference of the United States in North America.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department's interpretation of the Rule severely impacts the use of the emergency emergency ESSER/GEER funds for public-school students affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and other 17 relief pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment Act, and set aside the Rule and all versions of the Guidance Document.[SENTMARKER]The final rule was published in the Federal Register on July 1, 2020.
