gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2020, two private health-care facilities that provide services to LGBTQ people filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the District of Washington, alleging discrimination under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) on the basis of an individual's sexual orientation or gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for preliminary injunction, granted their motion for summary judgment, and granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2020, the Supreme Court of the United States (SCOTUS) held that discrimination on the based of a person's transgender status or sexual orientation is discrimination on a basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The Court's decision held that the 2016 Final Rule did not violate the ACA because it did not include gender identity or gender stereotyping.[SENTMARKER]In a parallel case, the Eastern District of New York (EDNY) recently issued a similar ruling, which enjoined HHS from enforcing its definition of sex discrimination insofar as it included "gender identity" (but not sex stereotyping) and required HHS to set aside the final rule.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 15, 2008, a group of Medicaid-eligible adults with disabilities that were confined to a nursing-home facility filed a class action in U.S. District Court against Florida's Health Care Administration and Department of Elder Affairs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state discriminated against them by failing to offer services that would enable them to live in a community setting.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, the court entered judgment for one of the named plaintiffs and decertified the class that he had previously approved.[SENTMARKER]In part because of recent legislation that greatly improved the state's efficiency at moving eligible persons from nursing homes to community living, the court determined that the conditions allowing for the class no longer existed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2010, a group of Medicaid beneficiaries filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Florida, alleging that the state of Florida was unnecessarily requiring Medicaid beneficiaries to enter or remain in nursing homes in order to receive care they could and should have received in the community.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the state to provide Medicaid coverage for a certified nursing assistant.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss, and the plaintiffs moved to certify a class of similarly situated individuals in Florida.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss and the case was dismissed as moot.[SENTMARKER]On January 3, 2012, the district court vacated the class certification order and dismissed the claims of the other named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 6, 2011, a resident of Florida and applicant for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) assistance filed this 42 U.S.C. § 1983 class action against the Florida Department of Children and Families in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida, Orlando Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that Florida's TANF application requirement that all applicants undergo suspicionless drug testing in order to be considered for assistance constituted an unreasonable search under the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction and has certified the class action; an appeal of the injunction to the Eleventh Circuit is pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2011, a Florida resident, Luis W. Lebron, filed this lawsuit against the Florida Departments of Children & Families, alleging that Florida’s mandatory drug-testing requirement for all Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA) applicants was a violation of his and all other applicants’ Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction against the enforcement of the drug testing statute against Lebron and the State agreed to discontinue its drug testing regime as to all TANF applicants until this litigation was fully resolved.[SENTMARKER]On October 24, 2011, the district court denied the State’s motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed, and the case was settled on September 6, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On September 6, 2011, the District Court granted final summary judgment to Lebron, declared  414.0652, and permanently enjoined its enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The District Court found that the State had established a substantial likelihood of success on the merits of this action.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were a lesbian couple who filed a complaint on July 20, 2004 challenging the Federal Defense of Marriage Act, as well as Florida's implementation of the statute, as violating the Full Faith and Credit Clause, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Privileges and Immunities Clause, and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution, and sought declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]On January 19, 2005, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida held that DOMA falls within Congress' power under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, the right to same-sex marriage is not a fundamental right under the Constitution, and that DOMA passes the rational basis review test and does not violate the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 2004, two same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle district of Florida, alleging that the federal government's refusal to recognize their marriage in Massachusetts violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the denial of recognition of their marriage was impermissible under the 14th Amendment because the couples were of the same gender.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed on August 10, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the defendants in Baker v. Nelson, holding that the right to marry is not a fundamental right that is protected by the Constitution, and that there was no reason to deny the plaintiffs their right to do so.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were individuals with quadriplegia who did not receive adequate in-home care services via Florida Medicaid and who were on the waitlist for the state's spinal cord injury waiver services.[SENTMARKER]After arguing that this was a violation of the ADA and Section 504, the plaintiffs received a preliminary injunction in 2010 and the state initiated waiver services soon after.[SENTMARKER]The case finally settled in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2010, two individuals with spinal cord injuries filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Department of Health and the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA) alleging that the state violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (R&A) by failing to provide them with in-home personal care assistance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide sufficient community-based services so that Medicaid-eligible individuals who are at risk of institutionalization may be served in the "most integrated setting appropriate to their needs."[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, holding that the State had violated the ADA and R&A, and rejected the State's defense that inadequate funding, rather than discrimination, was the reason for retaining the plaintiffs in an institution.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2011, the case was transferred to this court and the parties agreed to a declaratory and injunctive order requiring the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with services under the TBI/SCI waiver program.[SENTMARKER]The parties disagree as to the nature of the relief sought, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In September of 2011, one eighteen-year-old and four minor residents of Georgia with significant medical issues sued the agency responsible for administering Medicaid in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the agency's decisions to deny or reduce hours of in-home, private nursing care violated the Medicaid act, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]Two of the Plaintiffs settled and some of the Medicare, as well as the Fifth an Fourteenth Amendment Allegations were dismissed on summary Judgment, however, the District Court found for the Defendants on the remaining allegations.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed this decision and the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The district court also awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiff, which was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.
pegasus_output_sents: In February 2010, four Medicaid-eligible children with significant medical needs filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Georgia's Pediatric Program (GAPP) violated the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by denying them private duty nursing services when they were medically necessary to correct or ameliorate their medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]On June 19, 2012, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief and a declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the defendants had violated the ADA by denying the plaintiffs their due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for partial summary judgment, arguing that all of the claims related to the GAPP policy should be dismissed with the exception of the plaintiff's claim that the defendant had discriminated against them in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]On August 2, 2012, the Court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs had not established the numerosity requirement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2010, plaintiffs, minors with serious disabilities who were Medicaid recipients, filed this class-action lawsuit was filed in federal court against the Secretary of the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) and Director of the Office of Medicaid Policy and Planning of FSSA.[SENTMARKER]They all had been receiving medically necessary therapies paid for by the State's Medicaid program, administered by the FSAA, for several years.[SENTMARKER]These therapies were necessary to ensure the plaintiffs' conditions would not deteriorate and that they would not lose functional ability.[SENTMARKER]The FSSA had denied the named plaintiffs and others similarly situated continuing access to these therapies, citing two provisions of the Indiana Administrative Code.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2011, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiffs, issuing a permanent injunction preventing the Defendants and their successors from limiting or denying coverage for prescribed physical, occupational, or respiratory therapy, and/or speech pathology, for any person under 21 enrolled in the State's Medicaid program when such denial or limitation was based upon the two disputed provisions.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2010, a group of seriously disabled Medicaid recipients filed a class action lawsuit against the Indiana Family & Social Services Agency (FSSA) alleging violations of the federal Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that FSSA's policy and practice of denying or limiting coverage for therapies prescribed by a Medicaid recipient's physician, refusing to cover maintenance therapy, and/or denying treatment for more than two years without a significant change in medical condition violated federal Medicaid law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and a permanent injunction, finding that the defendants' standing policy of refusing to provide long-term residential treatment for patients for whom such treatment had been found necessary by an EPSDT had been violated.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed the district court's decision in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 28, 2018, the NAACP and Prince George’s County, Maryland filed a claim against the U.S. Census Bureau and President Donald Trump for neglecting their constitutional duty to administer a fair and accurate census of the US population.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that underfunding and the flawed design of the 2020 Census might lead to undercounts of the US population in violation of the Enumeration Clause and to the detriment of minority populations, as the census count is tied to both public funding and governmental representation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction to require the US to develop a plan to ensure a fair and accurate count.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claim for injunctive relief as unripe because census preparations were ongoing, but allowed the claim on underfunding to continue.[SENTMARKER]The court also allowed the plaintiffs to add two claims under the Administrative Procedure Act. On April 16, 2020, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss; the case is closed.

Trump, and the Department of Commerce.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by failing to adequately prepare for the 2020 Census.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they violated the Constitution's Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the plaintiffs' claims for failure to state a claim and for lack of justiciability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the defendants filed a renewed motion to dismiss, seeking dismissal of the remaining APA claims.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs appealed the district court's dismissal of their claims on jurisdictional grounds.[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2019, the plaintiffs filed a motion to remand, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the plaintiffs have agreed to dismiss their claims.

gold_sents: On December 18, 2009 three young adult residents of Maine who were Medicaid recipients and who were diagnosed with cerebral palsy, filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services in her official capacity.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maine.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS had violated Title II of the ADA and other federal laws.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that the State had failed to accommodate Plaintiffs' disabilities and to provide medically necessary treatment in the most integrated setting possible, instead forcing them into nursing homes where they were functionally segregated from the outside world.[SENTMARKER]In August, 2010, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint reframing the case as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated Maine residents.[SENTMARKER]The parties began settlement discussions shortly thereafter.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2012, the Court (Judge Nancy Torresen) approved the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the State to establish a Medicaid Home and Community Based Waiver (HCBW) program, which would provide a limited number of qualifying class-members the opportunity to live in community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2009, three individuals with developmental disabilities filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine against the Commissioner of the Department of Health and Human Services for the State of Maine and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Amendments to the federal Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide the plaintiffs with medically necessary services with reasonable promptness, prevented the unnecessary segregation and institutionalization of plaintiffs and class members, and provided community-based services that could enable the plaintiffs to live in the community.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a declaratory judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendant had violated the defendants' obligations to provide specialized services, prevent unnecessary segregation, and prevent the unnecessary institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendant to provide services to the plaintiffs in the most integrated setting possible, and to provide them with a one-time notice to all nursing facilities in Maine regarding the terms of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On April 14, 2014, several same-sex couples married in Michigan on March 22, 2014 filed this § 1983 civil rights action against the State in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union and private counsel, asked the court to declare that the same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional when applied to Michigan's same-sex couples, to enjoin the State of Michigan from refusing to recognize those marriages, and to award attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On January 15, 2015, the District Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: This case was brought by individuals in Nebraska who were eligible for and had applied for or attempted to apply for home and community-based developmental disability services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs brought the case against the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services Finance and Support seeking declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting Defendants from violating the ADA and various Medicaid laws and requiring them to adopt practices aimed at providing eligible persons with developmental disability services in home and community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also sought litigation expenses, costs, and attorney's fees.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2003, a group of developmentally disabled Nebraska residents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nebraska alleging violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504), and Medicaid laws and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to properly allocate funding to individuals with developmental disabilities who are eligible for home and community-based Medicaid-funded services.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice, holding that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties and denied their application for attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on various grounds, including that they were not entitled to attorneys' fees under the ADA, Section 504, and Medicaid regulations.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss with prejudice and granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 20, 2003, a group of individuals with mental disabilities filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District Of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504) by failing to reasonably accommodate plaintiffs and class members in residential treatment programs for mental illness and substance addiction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the single ground that the plaintiffs had failed to exhaust administrative remedies as required by the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to intervene, which was granted by the district court on October 20, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed that the parties would work together to develop a plan of action to address the issues raised in the case.

gold_sents: On March 29, 2018, four transgender persons filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Director of the Ohio Department of Health under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief as well as attorneys’ fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs summary judgment on December 16, 2020, following a failed attempt by the government to have the case dismissed for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]On February 1, 2021, the plaintiffs filed a motion for attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, the court stayed this motion pending a joint status report detailing the discussions between the parties on the attorney fees motion and the government's compliance with the December 16 order.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered that a joint status report be submitted no later than July 26, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2018, four transgender individuals, Stacie Ray, Basil Argento, Ashley Breda, and Jane Doe (collectively "Plaintiffs"), filed this lawsuit against the Ohio Departments of Health ("ODH") and the Office of Vital Statistics ("OVS"), alleging that the State of Ohio's policy prohibiting transgender persons from correcting the gender marker on their birth certificates to match their gender identity violates their constitutional rights to equal protection, due process, and freedom of speech.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2021, the Court granted the Defendants' motion to dismiss the case for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' emergency motion to stay the case pending further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: Planned Parenthood and its predecessors filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio on March 10, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Ohio's Senate Bill 23 (S.B.[SENTMARKER]23) was a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2020, the Ohio of Heruth and Veterans Services issued a Joint Directors' Order to limit access to Ohio nursing homes and similar facilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the Director's Order amounts to a ban on abortion for all patients who are more than ten weeks pregnant (as well as a ban of abortion at earlier gestational points among patients for whom medication abortion cannot appropriately be used).[SENTMARKER]The complaint sought a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction enjoining the enforcement of S.B, as well as discovery and an evidentiary hearing.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that there was no need for discovery or a hearing, and the case was dismissed as moot.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit denied the appeal and the parties agreed to dismiss the case.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 14, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit against the State of Oregon, the County of Multnomah County, and the County's Office of Marriage and Family Services in the United States District Court for the district of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief for the violation of Plaintiffs' rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United Nations Constitution caused by the exclusion of the couples from the freedom to marry under Oregon's laws of the state.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that the State's refusal to register the marriage licenses did not violate the Plaintiffs' right to equal protection and due process.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On May 15, 2014, the Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed because the parties had not been able to come to an agreement on the issue of whether the state's marriage statute was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted summary judgment to the defendants on the question of whether they had a right to discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation.

gold_sents: Polk Center and White Haven Center were Pennsylvania state facilities that cared for individuals with severe mental and disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The centers represented a type of care facility that function by providing intense care for their residents in isolation from the rest of society.[SENTMARKER]In August of 2019, Pennsylvania Governor Thomas Wolf announced a plan to move residents from these two centers to "community" residences, which are not isolated and whose treatment is not as intense.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit alleged that this switch was in violation of the residents' rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, the Medicaid Act, and that the switch violated residents' substantive due process rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 22, 2014, six same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Dakota seeking the right to marry in South Dakota and for South Dakota to recognize their valid out-of-state marriages.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that South Dakota's prohibition of gay marriage and refusal to recognize valid marriages violated their constitutional rights to equal protection, due process, and travel.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the plaintiffs and issued a permanent injunction, but stayed it pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States later dismissed the case for want of a substantial federal question.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, 2015, the Eighth Circuit held that Obergefell did not render the case moot, and that the district court's decision to grant summary judgment was based on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Institutionalized adults with developmental disabilities filed this challenge to policies in Texas they alleged promoted the unnecessary institutionalization of people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The United States (DOJ) has intervened in the case, and the Court eventually granted class certification for a class of: All Medicaid-eligible persons over twenty-one years of age with intellectual or developmental disabilities or a related condition in Texas who currently or will in the future reside in nursing facilities, or who are being, will be, or should be screened for admission to nursing facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1396r(e)(7) and 42 C.F.R. § 483.112 et seq. A bench trial was held in late 2018, and as of August 12, 2020, the litigation is ongoing as the parties await the court's decision.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2010, a group of individuals with developmental disabilities and their families filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Texas against the State of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Texas state officials violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Amendments Act (NHRA) by failing to provide them access to the community-based services and supports they need to live safely in the community.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the defendants violated Title II's integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to abate and stayed all proceedings in the case.[SENTMARKER]In November 2015, the State moved to dismiss the case in intervention, but the court denied the State's motion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2016, the Franciscan Alliance, a Catholic organization that provides medical services to women who have miscarried babies, filed this suit in the District Court for the Northern District of Texas, challenging the legality of the Affordable Care Act's new nondiscrimination in health programs provision (the "Rule") and the Department of Justice's enforcement of the Rule.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Rule violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights under Title VII and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act ("RFRA"), as well as their religious and conscientious objections to performing medical transition procedures.[SENTMARKER]On October 21, 2016, the plaintiffs moved for partial summary judgment, or in the alternative, a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2016, the district court granted the plaintiffs’ motions for an injunction, finding they were likely to succeed on their APA and RFRA claims.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2017, after a hearing, the Court granted the parties’ requests to lift the stay and set a briefing schedule for the parties, lifting the stay, and allowing the parties to intervene in the case.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, and the parties have agreed not to file any further litigation.

gold_sents: This case litigated by the ACLU in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California dealt with sanitation, classification, legal access and other conditions at the California Institute for Men (Chino).[SENTMARKER]In 1988, the prison and the plaintiffs entered a settlement agreement, which provided for various improvements and compliance monitoring that ended in 1993.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1988, the ACLU filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California on behalf of inmates at the California Institute for Men in the Chino Reception Guidance Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution by intentionally inflicting mental stress upon the prisoners in the gym area.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed on August 31, 1989.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs $22,000 in compensation for each day of barbarous and unconstitutional confinement in the 14 gym area of the Chino reception center.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with adequate access to the 15 courts.

gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 2006, a prisoner at High Desert state prison filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California, alleging that the prison's Race-Based Lockdown Policy violated the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial and a jury found in favor of the prisoner, finding that defendants violated his Eighth Amendment right to outdoor exercise and his right to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which the court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]In May 2008, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on August 15, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a modified program and lockdown policy.[SENTMARKER]In July 2013, the court denied the defendants' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]In August 2015, the court approved the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In October 2018, the parties filed an appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeal was denied on February 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 16, 2020, five individuals filed a class action against Lompoc, a low-security prison facing one of the largest outbreaks of COVID-19 among U.S federal prisons, for immediate relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs proposed a class of all current and future people in post-conviction custody at Lompoc, and sought enlargement of custody to include home confinement, and if the conditions of confinement violated constitutional rights, for prisoners to be released.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO (temporary restraining order), and a preliminary injunction requiring Lompoc to undertake health and safety measures, and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss the case and on October 8, the court granted plaintiff's motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In January 2021, the plaintiffs filed another motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 14, 2020, a group of inmates filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the Bureau of prison's response to the COVID-19 pandemic was inadequate.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the BOP had failed to respond effectively to the pandemic and that the conditions at the prison were extremely unsanitary.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment on May 27, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On May 27, 2020, the court denied the defendants' motion to de-classify the class, and the case was closed on July 14.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed a second suit against the Parole Commission on July 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2020, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be closed and the parties would work together to improve the conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 22, 1980, inmates filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated and named lead case with five other cases filed against the defendant in 1981 and 1982.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were represented by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and Legal Assistance to Prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the plaintiff's rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments were violated because the facility was overcrowded, unsanitary, lacking in security, and unable to provide adequately the basics of general human living needs.[SENTMARKER]Judgments were reached that required screening of all admitted inmates, individualized health care summaries for HIV-positive inmates, routine health examinations, and the use of drug therapies for HIV-positive inmates; as well as requiring that the prison not increase its inmate population, continue operating as a medium security facility, and allow plaintiffs' lawyers access to the facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 1988, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Department of Corrections alleging overcrowding and unconstitutional conditions of confinement at the Connecticut correctional institution at Somers.[SENTMARKER]The class was certified as all present and future inmates confined at Somers in July 1986.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 1994, which was approved by the court in May 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a general agreement in May 1994 concerning terms under which the pending litigation could be resolved.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would provide additional personnel for counseling and support services for counseling personnel, provide access to medical care for inmates with HIV-infection, and provide a minimum of one hour of training annually on HIV-related subjects.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed that they would cooperate with any state agency conducting a study to determine the Skilled Nursing Facility and/or hospice bed needs of HIV-infected persons in the State of Connecticut.

gold_sents: In 1986, the prisoners at the Occoquan Facilites of the District of Columbia's Lorton Correctional Complex filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District of Columbia government officials' overcrowding of the facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the defendants had violated the constitution, and required that the prison minimize its population.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: In the wake of a prison riot, inmates at the District of Columbia's facilities in Occoquan, Virginia, brought suit in federal district court under 42 U.S.C.  1983 alleging that conditions at the prison violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted plaintiffs' motions for class certification and a preliminary injunction imposing a limit on the number of prisoners who could be housed at the facility.[SENTMARKER]In September, the District court found that the District had deliberately failed to obey its orders concerning overcrowding at the jail and held the District in civil contempt.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the population cap was too broad a remedy and remanded the case to the District Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

On August 6, 2006, Prison Legal News (PLN) submitted a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking documents related to litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]They asked the BOP to waive all search and duplication fees under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]BOP refused to grant the fee waiver and PLN appealed the decision to the Department of Justice.

The DOJ upheld the denial of the request, so on September 13, 2005, PLN filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]After several years of litigation, the parties settled in 2017.[SENTMARKER]The BOP produced the requested documents and agreed to pay $420,000 in attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2005, a non-profit legal journal filed this FOIA lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Columbia against the Federal Bureau Of Prisons (BOP) and the Department of Justice (DOJ).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief and an order compelling the defendants to provide it with all documents responsive to its FOIA requests without any cost.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also challenged the Bureau's search for responsive records and its utilization of the FOIA exemptions to withhold the redacted information and other documents that it claims have not been produced at all.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2003, the plaintiff submitted a FOIA request to the Bureau seeking a copy of "all documents showing all money paid by the Bureau... for lawsuits and claims against it... between January 1, 1996.... and... July 31, 2003."[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the plaintiff requested a waiver of all fees associated with processing its request and provided it with copies of the relevant documents.[SENTMARKER]The Bureau denied the waiver request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and ordered the Bureau to conduct the search without costs to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]On January 1, 1996, the Bureau provided the plaintiff with over 10,000 pages of responsive records in response to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]In six separate releases, the Bureau did not produce any of the requested documents.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2003, the court granted summary judgment to the plaintiffs on the adequacy of the search and its use of the exemptions.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a fee waiver request, and the Bureau agreed to pay the plaintiff no costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case without further litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Four overdetained former Delaware prisoners, represented by private counsel, filed this § 1983 action against the Delaware Department of Corrections (DDOC) and Central Offender Records (COR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that inadequate staff, training, discipline, and hours of operation, along with a host of other policies, caused dysfunction and frequent over-detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought suit individually and as a class on behalf of all those incarcerated in a DDOC facility as of October 1, 2008 or later who were not or will not be released within 12 hours of the expiration of their sentence or the forwarding of a court order for release.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment because the plaintiffs' failed to demonstrate that the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the overdetention problem.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 23, 2012, the United States District Court for the district of Idaho entered a final judgment in the case brought by a deaf inmate under the Americans with disabilities Act of 1990 and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment found that the ADA does not require state-of-the-art technology as a method of reasonable accommodation.[SENTMARKER]The ADA requires that inmates be provided the opportunity to effectively communicate with persons outside the prison that is equal to that provided to hearing inmates.[SENTMARKER]In light of this, the inmate requested that the IDOC provide him with the use of a videophone, which would allow him to communicate with an increased number of people using his primary language.[SENTMARKER]In a response dated November 3, 2009, the inmate was told: "You have a relay service option or writing letters."[SENTMARKER]He requested it due to the changing technology and the using of videophones.[SENTMARKER]In response to DRI's request, Deputy Attorney General William Loomis stated: "The ADA does [not] require state of the art technology as an accommodation.[SENTMARKER]In trying to secure a video phone for his use, Plaintiff has exhausted the available administrative remedies utilizing IDOC's grievance procedure."[SENTMARKER]The court granted Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on January 23, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to a settlement conference on October 31, 2012 to be held in Courtroom #1 on the order of Judge Lynn Winmill.

gold_sents: In 2016, a group of prisoners of the Illinois Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to extreme isolation in violation of the Eight and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2017, a group of inmates in the Illinois Department Of Corrections (IDOC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Southern District Of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the IDOC's policies and customs, which place every individual incarcerated in Illinois at risk of being subjected to extraordinarily long and severely harmful extreme isolation, violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were denied access to educational programs, the law library, and religious services, and they were provided with smaller meal portions, exposed to bugs, rodents, and other vermin, and exposed to harsh temperatures.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that their placement in segregation violated their due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now on appeal.

gold_sents: In 2009, a group of Muslim prisoners filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the warden of the Federal Correctional Institute, alleging that the prison's allowance of only one hour of group prayer per week violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.[SENTMARKER]The court ultimately issued a permanent injunction against the Federal Correctional Institute in 2013, holding that the prison's policy violated RFRA and, upon further clarification, ordered that the warden "is to allow group prayer during every Muslim prayer time for which the inmates are not confined to their cell."
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2009, a group of Muslim inmates at the federal correctional institution in Terre Haute, Indiana, filed a lawsuit against the warden of the prison alleging that the warden's policy on group prayer violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA) and the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 2000 (PLCPA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a permanent injunction, but denied their motion to certify a class.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2007, the Disability Law Center filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act against the Massachusetts Department of Correction.[SENTMARKER]The DLC claimed that the DOC failed to take into account mental illness when subjecting prisoners to long periods of disciplinary and other forms of isolation and segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in 2011, and the defendants agreed to make sure that mentally ill prisoners were not placed in isolation or segregation without a full evaluation and determination that such placement would not cause further injury; they also agreed to pay attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in 2015 as no one had requested to reopen the case since the settlement monitoring date ended.[SENTMARKER]In 2016 one of the prisoners tried to reopen the case since prison officials were violating the settlement agreement, but the judge refused to reopen the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 8, 2007, Disability Law Centre, Inc (DLC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts (D.C.) against the Massachusetts Department (DOC) alleging that the DOC violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide adequate mental health care to inmates with mental illness in the custody of the DOC.[SENTMARKER]In August 2010, the parties reached a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on May 20, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the settlement agreement in June 2016, and the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case in September 2018.[SENTMARKER]On April 2020, the court dismissed the case, finding that the parties had failed to comply with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]On June 2016, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants, concluding that the settlement was fair and reasonable.[SENTMARKER]On July 2020, the parties agreed to enter into a new settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that there shall be no more than three site visits in each year that the Settlement Agreement is in effect.[SENTMARKER]The Court shall be the sole forum for the enforcement of this Settlement Agreement.

gold_sents: In November 2015, plaintiff inmates with hearing disabilities sued the Massachusetts Department of Correction and the Massachusetts Partnership for Correctional Healthcare under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the Constitution of the United States.[SENTMARKER]After mediation, the parties settled in 2019.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the settlement remains in effect for a period of three years.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2014, the Massachusetts Department Of Correction (DOC) and its contracted provider of healthcare services (MPCH) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts on behalf of deaf and hard-of-hearing inmates in the custody of the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to comply with federal laws protecting the rights of the plaintiffs and similarly situated individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' requests for videophone services, visual alert and notification systems, and by denying their requests for interpreter services, individual hearing devices, and other auxiliary aids and services.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants also failed to give consideration to the plaintiffs’ reasonable requests for accommodations by denying them videophones and visual alert systems.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that they discriminated against the plaintiffs in work assignments.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with videophone technology at each of its facilities to those inmates who have been identified as deaf or Hard of Hearing and whose primary language is sign language.[SENTMARKER]The settlement will be subject to the Final Approval of the Court.[SENTMARKER]The court will be the sole forum for the enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The agreement will be made available by request under the Massachusetts Public Records Law, Mass Gen.

gold_sents: COVID-vulnerable inmates of the Maine Department of Corrections, seeking to represent a class of medically vulnerable and disabled inmates, brought this habeas action in an effort to force the Department to de-densify its prisons by releasing prisoners.[SENTMARKER]Filed May 15, 2020 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine, the complaint alleged that the Department had refused to grant medical furlough or home confinement to inmates; they alleged that this was in violation of the Eighth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The action was assigned to Judge John A. Woodcock, Jr.[SENTMARKER]Although the Department reported its first case of COVID in May 2020, the court dismissed the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunctive relief in June 2020.[SENTMARKER]Motions to dismiss the case and to convert the case to a different form of habeas were pending as of July 28, 2020.

Liberty, the commissioner of the MDOC, on behalf of themselves and a putative class of inmates with medical conditions associated with an increased risk from COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2020, the Petitioners filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) or preliminary injunction, as ordered by the Court on May 20, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On June 8, 2020, the Court denied the motion for TRO.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report on June 20, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered that all inmates have access to 70% alcohol-based hand sanitizer.[SENTMARKER]Inmates at Mountain View have been informed that they can be disciplined for not wearing masks where required.[SENTMARKER]The Court also ordered that no non-essential vendors, volunteers, or tours can be allowed into the facility.

gold_sents: On October 30, 2007, a state prison inmate filed a §1983 lawsuit against the Chief Medical Officer of the Michigan Department of Corrections' Bureau of Health Care Services and three unnamed individual members of the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, who originally filed pro se but was later represented by the University of Michigan Law School General Clinic, sought declarative, monetary, and injunctive relief, claiming that the defendants acted with deliberate indifference to the plaintiff's serious medical needs when they repeatedly denied his request for cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2012, following a reversal by the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals, the district court entered an order granting summary judgment in favor of one of the defendants based on qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]As of November 18, 2014, the case is ongoing against the remaining defendants.

gold_sents: This 2013 lawsuit was brought by several Muslim inmates of  the Lakeland Correctional Facility in the U.S. District for the Western District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, in failing to provide adequate nutrition to prisoners observing Ramadan, the defendants, several agents of the Michigan Department of Corrections, had violated the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments as well as the RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan, a group of Muslim prisoners filed a lawsuit in April 2013 alleging that the defendants violated their rights under the First and Eighth Amendments and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) by failing to provide them adequate nutrition during the Islamic month of Ramadan, which lasts for 29 to 30 days.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, claiming that the plaintiffs could only obtain adequate nutrition by violating their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants qualified immunity, concluding that they had a clearly established right to receive 2,900 calories per day during Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]The court found the defendants in contempt of court and awarded the plaintiffs compensation.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the district court in April 2014 and the case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2016, a transgender prisoner of the Missouri Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the “freeze-frame” policy of refraining from providing transgender prisoners necessary medical care for gender dysphoria unless they previously received such services violated the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, the court declared that the policy violated the Eighth Amendment’s Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause and issued a permanent injunction against the policy.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to provide the medical care necessary for the plaintiff’s gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the court awarded the plaintiff attorney’s fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2016, a transgender woman filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Missouri, alleging that the state of Missouri violated her Eighth Amendment rights by denying her hormone therapy to treat her gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief on August 28, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On August 28, 2018, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiff, finding that the defendants had violated the Eighth Amendment by denying Ms. Hicklin medically necessary care.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment also granted the plaintiffs' motion for a permanent injunction, requiring the defendants to provide hormone therapy for all transgender inmates, including those who were not receiving hormone therapy before entering the state prison system.[SENTMARKER]In a separate case, the court granted a temporary injunction against the defendants in August 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted a motion for summary judgment on August 28 for the defendants.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2003, an Oklahoma Department of Corrections prisoner filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that his Constitutional rights under the Free Exercise Clause were being violated by the Oklahoma Department of Corrections' refusal to provide him with a Kosher diet.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated to include the complaints of two other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners won both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief requiring the Oklahoma Department of Corrections to provide them a Kosher diet at no personal cost.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction, issued February 8, 2006, ordered the Director of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections 'to immediately provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost, [while complying with nutritional requirements currently applicable to all other ODOC prisoners].'[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2012 the Court found that the judgment entered in this case only applies to the claims pursued by the three named plaintiffs, and the permanent injunction relief does not apply to all Oklahoma Department of Corrections inmates.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, three inmates filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging a constitutional right to receive a kosher diet in accordance with Orthodox Jewish law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their rights guaranteed by the First Amendment's free exercise clause had been violated by the Oklahoma department's failure to provide them free of cost with kosher meals consistent with their Orthodox Jewish faith.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the district court entered a preliminary injunction ordering the Colorado department to provide kosher meals to the inmate-plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the inmates were sufficiently sincere in their religious beliefs and that the cost-sharing program was constitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case was then re-referred to United States Magistrate Judge Gary M. pegasus_output_sents: On August 26, 2013, a state prisoner in Oklahoma filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that her gender identity disorder (GID) violated her constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that she was incarcerated at the Oklahoma State Reformatory (OSR) in 1986, after undergoing surgery to transform from male to female.[SENTMARKER]She also alleged that the OSR denied her request to be allowed to purchase female undergarments, such as bras and panties, and that she has failed to provide the proper level of hormone treatment.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2014, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, dismissed the complaint for failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted, and denied Plaintiff's request for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On May 15, 2013, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to pay the plaintiff $500,000 in compensatory damages in the amount of $500,000 per defendant, and to provide her with one-on-one counseling for her gender issues.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendant's motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff appealed the final judgment to the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In September 2005, a group of inmates at the federal prison complex in Beaumont, Texas filed a lawsuit under the Federal Tort claims Act (FTCA) alleging that the federal government violated the FLSA by failing to provide them with adequate quarters, safekeeping, care and subsistence in the aftermath of Hurricane Rita.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work overtime in a building that contained hazardous vapors; failed to provide safety apparel; housing them in a condemned building; made them drink contaminated water and take cold showers; and allowed them less than an hour for their personal needs.[SENTMARKER]They also claimed that the Eighth Amendment was violated because there was an absence of hygiene and that there was a lack of medical care.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the government's motion for summary judgment on the negligence claim, and the case was dismissed on October 2012 and January 2013.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. Davis (2:14-cv-13) and Cobb v. Morris (2:14-cv-22) with this case, as the two cases also were brought by Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit and involved RLUIPA grooming policy claims moving towards trial.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, Judge Ramos granted plaintiffs’ request for injunctive relief permitting them to grow their hair long, consistent with their Native American religious beliefs and entered a final judgment on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed, but moved to dismiss the appeal shortly after.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit granted the motion to dismiss the appeal on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] Texas Department of Criminal Justice ||| Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA), 42 U.S.C.  2000cc, et seq., as well as his First Amendment Right to practice his Native American faith (D.E.[SENTMARKER])<n>On April 13, 1995, a Native American of Ojibwe heritage who was confined at a TDCJ unit in Gatesville, Texas, filed suit for injunctive relief in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, seeking, inter alia, that TDCJ be required to provide sacred pipe ceremonies to Native American adherents confined within the TDCJ.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the suit as frivolous, but the case was appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed in part and reversed in part the district court's grant of summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the defendants violated RLUIPA and the First Amendment by denying the plaintiffs the right to participate in pipe ceremonies and smudging rituals in violation of their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2006, a Muslim inmate at the Keen Mountain correctional center filed a complaint in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the district of Virginia alleging that he was deprived of adequate nutrition and calories during Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants deprived him of the Eid prayer service in three separate ways following Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the defendant allegedly served the Eid meal on the evening of November 25, 2003, the final day of Ramadan and after Couch and the other Muslims had fasted throughout the day.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly denied him access to hot meals during a lockdown period that coincided with part of Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the defendants agreed to pay $450,000 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The court held that such a payment was insufficient to cover the plaintiff's legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 22, 2006.

gold_sents: On May 6, 2019, twelve prisoners who had been held in solitary confinement in two Virginia supermax prisons for at least two years filed this putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that each prison had violated their Fourteenth and Eighth Amendment rights by continuing to implement a program that intentionally held prisoners in solitary confinement without the possibility of re-entering the general population.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that this program also violated an earlier settlement agreement, the Rehabilitation Act, and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, the Virginia Department of Corrections, its employees, and the wardens of each prison, filed two motions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]District Judge Robert E. pegasus_output_sents: In August 1981, prisoners represented by the ACLU's National Prison Project sued the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia for violating their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights to due process and freedom from cruel and unusual punishment by placing them in long-term solitary confinement at Red Onion State Prison and Wallens Ridge State Prison.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners alleged that, through the VDOC's Phase Program and Special Management Unit (SMU), VDOC violated their constitutional rights by subjecting them to solitary confinement that serves no legitimate penological purpose and that results in serious deprivations of basic human needs, significant mental and physical harms, and substantial risk of such harms.[SENTMARKER]In the wake of the 1984 Mecklenburg Study Committee Report, VDOC entered into a Settlement Agreement with the ACLU, which was approved by the Court on April 5, 1985.[SENTMARKER]The parties submitted the Settlement Agreement to the Court, which issued a consent decree in April 1985 that prohibited VDOC from using any version of solitary confinement similar to the SMU.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to dismiss the case in October 1985, and the case was transferred to the United States Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit for the 5th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, the plaintiff filed a pro se complaint in the District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the Virginia Department of Corrections alleging that their policies for beards, halal food, and television access for religious services for inmates in solitary confinement violated the Free Exercise Clause and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act. Judge John P. Jones denied the plaintiff's request for injunctive relief in 2017 and initially granted summary judgment in favor of VDOC in 2018, but the Fourth Circuit overturned him on appeal in late 2019, saying that VDOC's use of access to television for religious services as an incentive program unduly burdens the plaintiff's rights to practice a bona fide religious belief.[SENTMARKER]The panel stated that religious practice should be a right, not a privilege that can be taken away through an incentive program.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2017, an inmate at Virginia's Red Onion State Prison filed this civil rights action under 42 U.N.C.[SENTMARKER]1983 and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) against the state of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that prison officials were burdening his right to free exercise of his Islamic religious beliefs under the First Amendment and RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied his request for preliminary injunctive relief, but the case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals remanded the case for further consideration of his contention that the court should order prison officials to allow him to participate in Jum’ah, the Islamic Friday congregational service.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, and the court granted summary judgment for the defendants on the tray box claim and on all claims for monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2020, Judge Rebecca Beach Smith in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia approved a settlement between the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) Civil Rights Division and Hampton Roads Regional Jail Authority.[SENTMARKER]The agreement resolved the DOJ’s claims alleging unlawful conditions at the Hampton Roads Regional Jail (HRRJ) in violation of CRIPA and the ADA.[SENTMARKER]Under the agreement, HRRJ will develop and implement policies, procedures, and training regarding adequate medical and mental health care and appropriate housing for prisoners with serious mental illness.[SENTMARKER]These measures include specialized mental health housing units, increased training for medical, mental health, and security personnel, proper screening and assessment for medical and mental health concerns, adequate treatment planning and suicide prevention measures, and a quality assurance program.[SENTMARKER]Per the agreement, the parties jointly appointed a monitor to assess and assist with compliance with the agreement.[SENTMARKER]HRRJ must come into substantial compliance with the agreement within five years.[SENTMARKER]The agreement can be terminated by court order.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2016, the United States filed this civil rights suit in the District Court for the Eastern district of Virginia against the Hampton Roads regional jail authority (HRRJ) alleging violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the HRRJ violated the rights of prisoners with serious mental illness by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care, its use of restrictive housing for prisoners who had mental illnesses, and its provision of access to services, programs, and activities to prisoners with mental health disabilities.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants also violated the constitutional rights of inmates who have mental illnesses by secluding them in isolation for prolonged time periods, and the ADA rights of those prisoners by denying them access to programs and activities by reason of their disability.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an agreement in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the agreement, including providing constitutionally adequate medical, mental health, and suicide prevention care to prisoners, as well as a monitor to oversee compliance with the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The agreement is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The United States and HRRJ will terminate the agreement in five years, or as outlined in 167, by order of the court.

gold_sents: On June 25, 2009 the plaintiff, a former female prisoner, filed suit against the State of Washington, the Washington State Department of Corrections, the Washington Corrections Center for Women, and several correctional officers in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleged violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Washington State Constitution based on the treatment of her while she was giving birth.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2010 the court denied the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case came to a close on May 7, 2010 after the parties reached a settlement on the remaining claims.[SENTMARKER]The details of the settlement are not known.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2009, a female inmate at the Washington Corrections Center for Women (WCCW) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that the Defendants violated her Eighth Amendment rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by shackling her in her individual and official capacity in violation of her right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]She also alleged that she was not "incarcerated or detained" at the time the suit was filed.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted summary dismissal of the suit, finding that she had not exhausted her administrative remedies under the PLRA and the doctrine of laches bars.[SENTMARKER]The district court also granted the defendants' motion for declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held in 2010 that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment when they shackled an inmate to a hitching post during labor and delivery.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal, and the case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In April 2018, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against King County and the Kent School District on behalf of children held in solitary confinement at the King County Jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that King County's pervasive policy of holding children who have not been convicted of any crime in long term solitary confinement and denying them an adequate education violated their constitutional rights and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act of 1983 (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants denied their children access to special education and related services.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 2018 and the case was dismissed in August 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to negotiate a settlement that will be finalized by the end of the year.
