gold_sents: Two non-profit organizations, the Colorado Criminal Defense Bar and the Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition brought this lawsuit under 28 U.S.C. § 2201(a) against Colorado on December 2, 2010 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by pro bono private counsel, sought a declaratory judgment that a Colorado statute was unconstitutional, violating the Sixth Amendment and Fourteenth Amendments by deferring the appointment of counsel to indigent defendants until after the prosecuting attorney has spoken with the defendant.[SENTMARKER]This case was voluntarily dismissed after the Colorado legislature passed a new statute that removed the requirement and subsequently allocated significant new funding to provide attorneys at initial appearances.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2013, a Colorado criminal justice reform group filed a lawsuit against the Colorado Attorney general and the state's attorney general in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado seeking a declaration that Colorado's practice of deferring the appointment of counsel for certain indigent criminal defendants was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were denied their right to counsel until after they engaged in discussions with the prosecuting attorney regarding potential plea offers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the Attorney General agreed that he would no longer conduct plea discussions with uncounseled indigent defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice in January 2013 and the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss with prejudice.

gold_sents: Individuals who were eligible to be assigned a public defender in New Orleans, but were placed on a waiting list due to budgetary shortages, sued the city (OPD) and Louisiana state public defender's offices for violating their Constitutional rights to counsel, due process, and equal protection.[SENTMARKER]They seek attorney's fees and a declaratory judgment that their rights were violated.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2016 the parties filed a joint motion for judgment granting final declaratory and partial injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On October 27, 2016 the court sua sponte raised the issue of subject matter jurisdiction, giving both parties a chance to submit briefs addressing the issue.[SENTMARKER]On January 31, 2017 the court (Judge James Brady) dismissed the case, citing grounds of federalism and comity.[SENTMARKER]On September 25, 2017 plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On October 4, 2018 the Fifth Circuit dismissed the case as moot because it found that since the appeal was filed, Louisiana lawmakers had reallocated funding for appointed counsel sufficient to render the waitlists for non-capital defendants nonexistent.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2012, a sex offender and his wife filed this civil rights suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Alabama against the E towah County Sheriff's Office and two officers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sheriff's office violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by conducting random, suspicionless searches of their homes without their consent and by threatening to arrest them if they refused to cooperate with the searches.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the searches violated their rights under the Fourth and 14th Amendments to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures and to not be deprived of liberty without due process of law.[SENTMARKER]The district court also granted a permanent injunction against future compliance inspections without suspicion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 26, 2003, two separate suits were filed against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and related defendants, in federal court.[SENTMARKER]The suits were filed in response to the OPD's actions on April 7 at a peaceful antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland.[SENTMARKER]The Police, without giving sufficient notice to disperse and without provocation, barraged demonstrators with a variety of "less-lethal" munitions, while blocking the main exit routes.[SENTMARKER]Police pursued demonstrators and others present when they attempted to disperse, while continuing to fire at them and intentionally strike them with motorcycles.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2003, the Court ordered that the cases be officially related and heard before the same judge.[SENTMARKER]One of the two cases, Local 10 ILWU v. City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]In both cases, Plaintiffs sought compensatory, exemplary, and punitive damages, as well as to recover legal costs.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declaratory judgments holding the Defendants' actions to be unlawful violations of the Plaintiffs' rights under the Constitutions of the U.S. and of California and of statutory law.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctions that among other things would prohibit the Defendants from unlawfully interference with the constitutional and statutory rights of participants in public demonstrations and protests.[SENTMARKER]On December 24, 2004, the parties entered a court-approved partial settlement addressing the Plaintiffs' claims for injunctive relief to the extent that those claims related to the Defendants' crowd control policies.[SENTMARKER]Oakland adopted a new official Crowd Control Policy that forbade the police from dispersing crowds that had not behaved illegally or that did not pose a clear and present danger of imminent violence.[SENTMARKER]It also forbade the indiscriminate use of less-lethal weapons directly against crowds, even when specific individuals in the group were violent.[SENTMARKER]The remaining issues eventually settled, with awards of damages and attorneys' fees well in excess of $1,000,000.

gold_sents: Six named plaintiffs filed a class-action lawsuit against the city of Pittsburgh and various elected officials and police officials alleging that actions taken against non-violent protestors constituted violations of their First and Fourth Amendment rights.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 20, 2020, a group of peaceful protesters gathered in downtown Pittsburgh to protest the city's decision to close businesses due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The protesters were not dressed in paramilitary outfits and were engaged in constitutionally protected speech.[SENTMARKER]The city responded by escalating a peaceful protest into a scene of pandemonium, panic, violence and bloodshed.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' conduct violated their First Amendment rights to freedom of speech and assembly, their Fourth Amendment rights, and their right to be free from discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia County.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania reversed the lower court decision in June of 1969 and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the case to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit upheld the district court's summary judgment and dismissed the appeal of the case.[SENTMARKER]In April 2020, the plaintiffs brought a class action suit against the city of Pittsburgh and the city’s police department, alleging that the city violated the First and Fourth Amendments by using excessive force against peaceful protesters.[SENTMARKER]The class action was permitted to proceed as class actions, with the individual respondents representing all residents of Philadelphia and an "included" class of all black residents of that city.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the issue of counsel fees and disbursements and costs in the sum of $39,417.58 against "the defendants."[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's appeal is pending.

pegasus_output_sents: In September 2006, a group of Hispanic high school soccer players filed a lawsuit against the Town of Coventry and its police officers in the District Court for the District of Providence, Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Coventry police conducted a mass search of the Central Falls soccer team in front of a crowd of unruly spectators at a game on September 28, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants violated their civil rights under the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution, as well as their rights to due process and equal protection pursuant to the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants on all counts.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then moved to suppress the search on the ground that their consent to the search was invalid.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that there was no evidence that the plaintiffs were treated differently than others similarly situated based upon their race.[SENTMARKER]On June 2013, the defendants moved to dismiss the case on the grounds of a qualified immunity defense.[SENTMARKER]On July 2014, the court granted the defendants summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 1978, the ACLU of Tennessee filed a lawsuit against the City of Memphis and several city officials in the United States District Court for the Western district of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment rights of residents of Memphis by using software that surveils social media for the purpose of political intelligence.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered an Order, Judgment and Decree in September 1978 with the consent of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The decree prohibited the use of social media and required the defendants to consult with the Federal Bureau of Investigation regarding national social media policies.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, 2018, the district court granted the ACLU's Motion for Summary Judgment in part and denied the City's motion for summary judgment in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree that required the City to modify or vacate its use of the software.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the Memphis Police Department to create social media accounts for the purposes of First Amendment-related intelligence.[SENTMARKER]In part, the consent decree prohibited harassment and intimidation of persons exercising First Amendment right to freedom of expression.[SENTMARKER]The District Court also ordered the appointment of an independent monitor to oversee the City’s compliance with the decree.[SENTMARKER]The Court also found the City in contempt of the decree in several respects and issued sanctions.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court denied the defendants' appeal, and the case was settled in part on August 10.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 1, 2018, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) issued a proposed rule that would overhaul the longstanding Title X family planning regulations in numerous respects.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, including several states and private Title X grantees, brought various suits against HHS in three district courts seeking preliminary in relief.[SENTMARKER]The district courts granted plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions on nearly identical grounds, and the district courts separately determined that the Final Rule conflicts with the Affordable Care Act’s nondirective pregnancy counseling mandate.[SENTMARKER]On March 4, 2019, HHS issued a final rule that substantially reverts back to the 1988 Title X regulations.[SENTMARKER]The final rule also requires that family planning options be "acceptable and effective," rather than also "medically approved," and requires that Title X providers steer women toward childbirth.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States (SCOTUS) granted HHS's motion to stay the injunctions pending a decision on the merits of its appeals.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 30, 1964, a group of African-American students in Jefferson Parish, Louisiana filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Louisiana alleging discrimination in the school system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought class certification and an injunction to desegregate the public schools of Jefferson Parish and to eliminate the vestiges of the prior dual school system, including the compulsory bi-racial education system.[SENTMARKER]In August 1971, the district court granted the school board's motion to intervene and entered a Final Judgment and Order dismissing the lawsuit with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in August 1971.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to continue their affirmative efforts, in recruiting and outreach, to encourage applications for instructional and administrative positions from qualified Black applicants, and to make application to the Department of Education for the use of magnet programs as a voluntary desegregation methodology.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment and order dismissing the suit with prejudice on July 10, 1971.[SENTMARKER]The school board appealed the final judgment on August 10.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit denied the appeal, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 1997, a white woman filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan alleging discrimination in the law school's admissions process because of her race.[SENTMARKER]In March 2001, the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and punitive damages and enjoined the Law School from using race as a factor in its admissions decisions pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Supreme Court upheld the lower court's ruling, and the case was remanded for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In September 2009, the Court of appeals ruled that the use of race in the admissions process was narrowly tailored to serve the School's compelling interest in achieving a diverse student body, and therefore its policy was valid.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and no further litigation is pending.

gold_sents: This suit was brought on May 19, 2020, by two non-profit organizations and three voter plaintiffs against the state of Louisiana to challenge Louisiana’s Excuse Requirement, Witness Requirement, and Cure Prohibition.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining the defendants from enforcing the Excuse and Witness Requirement, as well as provide absentee voters with notice and opportunity to cure defects in their absentee ballots for all elections in 2020 held in Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In a case before the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, plaintiffs were challenging the signature gathering requirement of Ohio’s ballot-initiative laws in response to the global pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In a second case, a group of African-American voters filed suit against the secretary of state of Georgia for failing to protect the voting rights of Florida citizens who, due to Hurricane Matthew, cannot register to vote by the upcoming October 11 registration deadline.[SENTMARKER]The Georgia NAACP filed a motion to dismiss the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction (standing), and the case was remanded with instructions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case without prejudice, and the parties agreed to a settlement.

gold_sents: On April 22, four individuals facing a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19 and the Family Unit, a non-profit organization, filed an action against the enforcement of South Carolina’s witness requirement applied to absentee voters, and the excuse requirement applied in order to vote by an absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On May 12, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified South Carolina voters to vote by absentee ballot for the June primaries.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, the court granted the plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions in part, pertaining to the witness requirement.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the Witness Requirement was enjoined for the November 2020 General Election in a separate case, and the district court stayed the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2020, two plaintiffs filed a lawsuit in the District Court for the District of South Carolina alleging that South Carolina’s absentee ballot witness requirement violated Section 201 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 (VRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs are African-American and are disabled, and they are eligible to vote by absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the lower court to examine the statute in its analysis.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, 2020, the case was re-opened and the court ruled that the witness requirement did not violate the VRA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in the district court on July 31, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to enjoin the defendants from enforcing South Carolina law that establishes categories of "persons qualified to vote" (the excuse requirement) and requires a witness signature on the absentee ballot (the witness requirement).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the parties agreed that the plaintiffs would be required to submit a report to the court detailing the impact of the witness signature requirement on their ability to vote.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to enforce the excuse requirement for the November 2020 general election.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] March 2012 | U.S. District Court | Eastern District of Wisconsin ||| Wisconsin Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) ||| 2011 Wisconsin Act 23 (the "photo ID law"), which requires voters in Wisconsin to present photo ID in order to cast their votes either in person at a polling place or by absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]In March 2012, two separate Wisconsin circuit courts enjoined the photo ID law on state constitutional grounds.[SENTMARKER]The district court's injunction allowed any registered voter to check a box stating a reason why reasonable effort would not produce a qualifying photo ID, but the defendants will not allow the plaintiffs to use their veteran's ID for voting purposes.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court granted the defendants' motion to vacate the injunction and remanded with instructions to enter an injunction limited to Act 23.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit reversed, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1989, a group of abused and neglected children brought a class action suit in the United States District Court for the district of Columbia on behalf of children in the District's foster care system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the children's constitutional rights, including the right to be known to the Department by virtue of abuse or neglect.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a consent decree, which required the defendants to implement a number of corrective measures.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, claiming that the district court lacked jurisdiction under the Eleventh Amendment to implement the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the defendants' appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On 2017, foster parents and three states filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (the "ICWA").[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege the ICWA violates the Equal Protection Clause and anti-commandeering principles.[SENTMARKER]The district court held the ICWA is unconstitutional which was partially affirmed in a fractured en banc opinion by the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2018, a Native American couple filed this suit in the Northern District Court of Texas, alleging that the Indian Child welfare Act (ICWA) and the accompanying regulations (the Final Rule) violated the equal protection and nondelegation doctrines and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by denying them the ability to adopt A.L.M., a 23-month-old girl who was being placed with the Navajo Nation.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, but the district court denied the motion, concluding, as relevant to this appeal, that Plaintiffs had Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted Plaintiffs summary judgment in part, finding that ICWA and the Final Rule violated equal protection, the Tenth Amendment, the non delegation doctrine, and the APA.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted Plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on all their claims, which the court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The District Court then granted an emergency stay and remanded the case to the District Court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending before the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: California recipients of Adult Day Health Care services brought this class action to enjoin California from reducing or eliminating the ADHC program, which would put the plaintiffs at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the plaintiff class a preliminary injunction in September 2009, forbidding California to modify it's adult Day Health Care program until an appropriate alternative could be provided to prevent institutionalization of individuals in the plaintiffs' class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved a settlement agreement that created a new program which will help to prevent the institutionalization of ADHC beneficiaries.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2009, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of elderly persons and adults with disabilities who were receiving Medi-Cal services through the Adult Day Health Care program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by cutting the maximum number of days that ADHC services could be provided.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the State on the basis that the plaintiffs were requesting new services which were not required by the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit reversed the district court's decision and held that the cap on prescriptions 16 could violate the ADA's integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]On January 25, 2012, the parties reached a settlement agreement to end the lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to provide services to replace the ADHC program with a new program that would not place the plaintiffs at risk of unnecessary institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the parties to develop a plan to ensure that people who qualify for the program will be covered by the new program.

gold_sents: Two individuals who use wheelchairs for mobility sued the City of Steamboat Springs, for having inaccessible public transportation and facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree requiring the city to make its services and facilities accessible, pay attorneys' fees and costs, and pay $12,250 to the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2000, two individuals with disabilities filed this suit in the District Court for the District of Denver against the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City had violated the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs and by denying the benefits of its services, programs, and activities, as more fully set forth above.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in July 2000.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was final and binding on all parties, including all principals, agents, and employees of the City.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the City to comply with the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The City also agreed to provide training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics, as well as timely refresher training for any operator or mechanic who demonstrates a lack of knowledge of proper wheelchair lift operation, maintenance, and repair.[SENTMARKER]On or before September 3, 2001, the City shall ramp or otherwise provide access to the restrooms at the Alpine Slide/stables area on the east side of the rodeo grounds.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were disabled individuals who sued the Colorado Rockies baseball club after it removed accessible seats in Coors Field and raised prices on others.[SENTMARKER]There was a trial held, after which the court dismissed all claims by stipulation.[SENTMARKER]It is unclear, however, whether the parties settled.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2004, a group of individuals with disabilities brought this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Colorado against the Denver Metropolitan Major League baseball stadium district and the Colorado Rockies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disability Act by failing to provide wheelchair-accessible seating in the lower level of Coors Field.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for partial summary judgment on a single issue, stating that the only seats in the back of the stadium were required to be clustered in front of those seats for non-disabled patrons to sit near the infield.[SENTMARKER]In March 2004, the district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees, including litigation expenses, and costs.[SENTMARKER]In May 2004, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2020, a group of deaf individuals filed this class action suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York County and Governor Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by failing to provide an in-frame American sign language (ASL) interpreter at every meeting held to discuss emergency decontamination in the plaintiffs’ community.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, holding in part that the ADA and RA did not require the county to provide the county with an ASL interpreter because based on the interpretation services that were provided, the relevant information to the plaintiffs at the large-group meetings was effectively communicated.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court’s grant of summary judgment for the county, holding that the plaintiffs had no standing to assert the rights of other deaf individuals.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on April 23, 2020.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island entered into an Interim Settlement Agreement with Rhode Island and the City of Providence after finding the State and City in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581.[SENTMARKER]The Agreement provided relief to approximately 200 Rhode Islanders with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) who received services from a sheltered workshop and day program provider, and a special education program which ran a segregated sheltered workshop inside a Providence public high school.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly determined that a court ordered remedial action plan would facilitate compliance with the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2014, the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE), the Office of Rehabilitative Services (ORS), and the Providence Public Schools Department (PPSD) issued a Consent Decree Update on July 26, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a contract agreement with the Paul V. Sherlock Center on Disabilities to offer training to individuals with I/DD in a demonstration project focusing on three components: (a) Family Employment Awareness Training (FEAT), (b) self-determination and (c) discovery/employment.[SENTMARKER]RIDE, ORS, andPPSD are providing or ensuring the provision of a significant number of training opportunities.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the State on September 30, 2016, requiring the State to comply with the terms and conditions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Former students and an employee of Rhinebeck Central High School filed suit against the School District and the former principal alleging that the District had violated Title IX of the Education Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to rectify allegations that the principal had sexually harassed the female students.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a Consent Decree in which the District agreed to implement anti-discrimination procedures.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 9, 2003, a group of private plaintiffs filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Southern New York, alleging that the District and Thomas Mawhinney, then the Principal of the Rhinebeck High School, were in violation of Title IX.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they and other female students at the High School were subjected to severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]The District's deliberate indifference to known sexual harassment to which the plaintiffs were subjected created a hostile educational environment.[SENTMARKER]In August 29, 2003, the District entered into a consent decree with the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the District to revise its written policy prohibiting harassment and discrimination on the basis of sex, provide concrete examples of sexual harassment, and implement a training program for its employees.[SENTMARKER]The district also required the district to inform students and their parents, through a minimum of annual meetings with all students, an annual distribution of notices to parents or guardians, and inclusion in student and parent handbooks, of the district's policies prohibiting harassment or discrimination in the administration or provision of educational services, programs, opportunities or benefits, including the policies prohibiting retaliation against any student who reports an incident of discrimination or discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the consent decree would remain in effect for three (3) years from the date of entry or ninety (90) calendar days after the last report under Section 14(a) of the Constitution.

gold_sents: A 16-year old transgender male student sued Kenosha Unified School District No. 1 (Kenosha) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on July 19, 2016, arguing that the school violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title IX by denying Plaintiff access to the boys’ restrooms.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff a preliminary injunction to use the boys' restroom throughout his senior year, which the Seventh Circuit upheld on May 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on January 22, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The settlement required Defendant to pay Plaintiff $800,000, enjoined Defendant from prohibiting Plaintiff from using the boys’ restroom, and required the Defendant to notify all staff about the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 16, 2016, a transgender student filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the school district for violating Title IX by denying him full and equal access to student restrooms and overnight accommodations during school-sponsored trips offered to other male students.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the treatment he received after he started his female-to-male transition violated Title IX and the Equal Protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss because it found that there were several avenues by which the plaintiff might obtain relief.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2018, the parties filed a joint motion asking the court to approve and enter a consent judgment in which the parties agreed to pay the plaintiff $800,000 in compensatory damages and reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On February 2019, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties have not yet filed a petition for writ of certiorari.

gold_sents: On August 11, 2005 a group of African-Americans filed a consolidated amended complaint Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in United States District Court of the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart discriminated against African-Americans in hiring of over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2007, the court certified a class of African Americans who had not been hired or had been deterred from applying for these jobs.[SENTMARKER]Discovery continued in preparation for trial and on January 13, 2009 the court denied the defendant's motions for decertification and summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties thereafter reached a settlement that was approved by the court on March 5, 2009.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement Wal-Mart agreed to damages in the amount of $17,500,000 to be distributed to the named representatives, class members, and their attorneys.[SENTMARKER]It also agreed to provide EEO training, actively recruit minorities, impose benchmarks for hiring minority drivers, make specific job opportunities open to minorities, and engage in recordkeeping and reporting.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2005, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas on behalf of African American over-the-road (OTR) truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants recruited new truck drivers by having its current drivers pass out cards with a 1-800 number to call for an application.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that this practice was discriminatory because it reflected in the body of current drivers being predominantly white and that the practice was therefore discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2004, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would resolve the case by September 24, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs in September 2006.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to pay a total of $17, $500,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]After the final judgment was entered, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2005, a female employee of Smith Barney filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California alleging that Smith Barney discriminated against her on the basis of gender with respect to business opportunities, compensation, professional support, and other terms and conditions of employment in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that she was subjected to a hostile work environment after she complained about unfair, discriminatory treatment to the highest levels of 8 the company, including to the Director of Human Resources.[SENTMARKER]Instead, Smith Barney disclosed the fact that she had complained to her male coworkers and retaliated against her for making such complaints.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and entered a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The Settlement Agreement required Smith Barney to establish a Settlement Fund and to implement changes to its policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]It also required the Company to provide its Human Resources staff with appropriate training regarding compliance with state, federal, and local Equal Employment Opportunity laws; Smith Barney’s anti-discrimination and harassment policies; and the best practices for complaint investigation and resolution.[SENTMARKER]The Company also agreed to maintain its commitment to its female broker networking 26 meetings.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff on May 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The Court denied the Plaintiff’s motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on October 31, 2006, and the case was closed on March 31, 2006.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2008, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of the Colorado against the owner and operator of a car dealership in the Denver area.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the owner of Kids Automotive engaged in a pattern or practice of sexual harassment and retaliation against two female employees of the dealership.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, more than 30 days prior to the institution of this lawsuit, the female employees filed charges of discrimination with the EEOC alleging violations of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The female employees alleged that they were subjected to sexual harassment in the workplace, by subjecting them to sexually harassment and a hostile work environment, by failing to take prompt remedial action intended to eliminate the sexual harassment, and by retaliating against Wayne and Castanon for complaining about the work environment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to pay the EEOC a total of $70,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Edward W. gold_sents: This case was brought by ten black current and former special agents of the United States Secret Service against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Treasury and the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief including back pay, front pay, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and an injunction, alleging that the Secret Service discriminated against them on the basis of race in promotions as well as in transfers, assignments, testing, hiring, and disciplinary practices.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a settlement agreement that awarded $24 million in damages, $8 million in attorney's fees, and $860,000 in costs.[SENTMARKER]The agreement will remain in place until 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2000, ten African-American Special Agents of the U.S. Secret Service filed this employment discrimination action against the Secret Service under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 U. S.C.  2000e, and the Civil rights Act of 1991, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were discriminated against because they were not promoted on the first bid list on which they bid, and that the agency retaliated against them for their complaints.[SENTMARKER]The parties ultimately settled the case in 1996 and the parties are now before the Court disputing the implementation of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denied review of the district court's certification order, in In re Johnson, 760 F.3d 66 (D.C Cir.[SENTMARKER]2015), in which the court found that the plaintiffs' claims were identical to those of the Library of Congress, and dismissed their claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals reversed that decision, holding that the plaintiff's claims were not identical.

gold_sents: This case was brought by eight Hispanic Special Agents against the U.S. Department of Treasury's United States Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief, alleging there was a pattern and practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin by the U.S. Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Defendant's Motion for Summary Judgment on March 20, 2007, thereby terminating the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2004, the EEOC filed a class action complaint in the District Court for the District of Washington, DC, alleging discrimination on the basis of national origin in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Customs Service had discriminated against Hispanic special agents by administering an exam known as the Special Agent OS-14 (SA-14) test.[SENTMARKER]This constituted further retaliation against Gonzalez for actively prosecuting this class action case in the EEOC administrative process.[SENTMARKER]The parties ultimately settled the case, and this Court approved that settlement in 1996; the parties are now before the Court for implementation of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]On September 21, 2004, the Court denied plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the ground that plaintiffs failed to exhaust their administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]On October 22, 1999, after a series of appeals through the EEOC, the case was remanded to the agency for class processing.[SENTMARKER]On May 10, 2002, the EEOC certified the class, and on May 11, 1998, the EEOC vacated the Department of Treasury’s final agency decision.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC found that the suspension was imposed because of the complainant’s national origin.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed as moot on February 15, 1995, and no appeal was taken.[SENTMARKER]On March 20, 2003, the EEOC denied plaintiffs’ motion for reconsideration of the class certification and remanded the case to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]On August 21, 2005, the EEOC granted plaintiffs’ request for further discovery on the hostile work environment and foreign language award claims, and the case proceeded for several years until it was settled.[SENTMARKER]In August 2004, the court dismissed plaintiffs’ administrative complaint on September 18, 2004, due to the complainant's failure to state a claim and supervisory teclmiques used.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit against Yellow Transportation, Inc., and YRC, Inc., for discriminatory employment practices on behalf of 14 current or former black employees and the class of similarly situated black employees.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Yellow Transportation (later merged into YRC) had violated §703(a) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(a) by subjecting black employees to greater scrutiny, more frequent and greater discipline, lower paying and less favorable job assignments, more difficult and time-consuming work, and a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief, including economic and noneconomic harm to the employees, punitive damages, development of policies and programs to provide equal employment opportunity and eradicate the effects of its past discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC also sought to recover its costs.[SENTMARKER]The charging parties later intervened as plaintiffs on their own behalf, adding claims for retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree resolved this case and the related case Brown v. Yellow Transportation, Inc. , linked below (Clearinghouse code: EE-IL-0329).[SENTMARKER]The decree awarded a total of $11 million ($1.1 million in attorney's fees) and no significant injunctive relief because of a consent decree in other litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is technically open but effectively closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 23, 2003, the EEOC filed this suit in the District Court for the Kansas City District against Sprint/United Management Company (Sprint) alleging age discrimination in connection with the company's reduction-in-force (RIF) policy.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sprint discriminated against plaintiffs and opt-ins on the basis of their age by treating younger employees more favorably than older employees in implementing the RIF.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed her claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On August 12, 2005, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which provided $57 million in monetary relief to a class of allegedly similarly situated former employees of Sprint.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the district court and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an amended complaint in October 2005, adding an additional claim that Defendant's Alpha LINK performance management system had a disparate impact upon employees age 40 and older.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the amended complaint for failure to exhaust administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]The second amended complaint was filed on August 12, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the parties to file briefs on the issue of whether the settlement agreement was fair and honestly negotiated.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and no further litigation is pending.

gold_sents: On April 26, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on behalf of a black female applicant, filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Advancemed Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant refused to hire the complainant because of her race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $22, 000.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 4, 2004, the EEOC filed this suit against AdvanceMed Corp. in the United States District Court for the District of the Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that AdvanceMed refused to hire a black female employee because of her race, and that the defendant continued to solicit and hire a similarly or less qualified applicant outside of the employee's protected class.[SENTMARKER]On March 2004, the parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by Judge Charles B.[SENTMARKER]Day of the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires AdvanceMed to provide a minimum of two hours equal employment opportunity training to all personnel involved in the screening, selection, and hire of employees at its Bethesda, Maryland facility, specifically with regard to making race-neutral employment decisions as it relates to the defendant's obligations under Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The decree also requires the defendant to pay a total of $22,000, less applicable taxes and other deductions to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement conference on November 4, 2004 where the consent decree was approved.

gold_sents: This is a race discrimination class action brought by black police officers in Baltimore, alleging discriminatory discipline and hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in December 2004, and settled in June 2009 for $2.5 million in damages to the 15 named plaintiffs and injunctive relief for the class.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 4, 2004, the Baltimore Police Department ("BCPD") and the City of Baltimore entered into a settlement agreement to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by African-American police officers in connection with the administration of the disciplinary system for Baltimore police officers.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement, which was entered into in federal court in the District of Maryland, was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement remain in effect until the end of the term of the agreement, including any extension of the deadline.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the City agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Pontiac and the local firefighters' union.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the collective bargaining agreements entered by the Pontiac Fire Department and the local firefighters' union discriminated on the basis of sex and race by explicitly creating and maintaining a dual system for hire and promotion requiring that one out of every thee hires or promotions be given to a minority.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the DOJ and the City of Pontiac reached a settlement that required the City of Pontiac to not engage in any act or practice that discriminated on the basis of race or sex in violation of Title VII in relation to hiring or promotion in the Pontiac Fire Department and to provide remedial relief to those employees and applicants denied hire or promotion as a result of the dual system for hire and promotion.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in October 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 15, 2005, the United States filed this lawsuit in the United State's District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan against the City of Pontiac in connection with the city's use of a dual hiring and promotional system based on race and sex.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that the City violated Title VII by maintaining a pattern or practice of discrimination against applicants or employees on the basis of race or sex.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the U.N.[SENTMARKER]alleged that Pontiac required one out of every three hires to be given a "minority" promotion.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the City agreed to pay a total of $12,200 in monetary relief to two white males who were not hired by the Pontiac Fire Department.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge George Caram Steeh on August 16, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the city would not enforce the dual hiring or promotional system in the future and would not unlawfully discriminate based on sex in the hiring or promotion process.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the consent decree required the City to create a non-discriminatory hiring and promotion policy for all future hires.[SENTMARKER]The decree was approved by Judge Steeh and the parties entered a final judgment in favor of the City on August 17, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on August 24, 2006.

gold_sents: On August 29, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit in the Albuquerque U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Bell Gas, Inc. and related corporations on behalf of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the companies had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.) by subjecting the employee to a sexually hostile work environment created by verbal and physical harassment from her immediate supervisor, including sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which provided the employee received a total of $180,000; $60,000 up front and monthly payments of $2,000 for 60 months-and subjected Defendants to an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2004, the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit against Bell Gas Inc., Cortez Gas Co., and A- X Propane Inc. alleging that the defendants violated Title VII by creating a hostile work environment for a 20-year-old female gas station cashier by subjecting her to verbal and physical sexual harassment because of her sex, including a sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed until August 18, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of $180,000 to the complainant.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to provide training on sex discrimination and harassment to each new employee hired for the duration of this decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to dismiss the case with prej udice if the complainant did not comply with the terms of the consent decree.

gold_sents: In 2006, the EEOC sued Consolidated Reports in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada alleging violations of Title VII's prohibition on sex discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged and employee of the defendant sexually harassed the charging party and created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the case settled when the parties agreed to a 1 year consent decree requiring the defendant to pay $55,000 to the charging party, to adopt anti-discrimination policies, provide training to employees, and comply with other requirements.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 7, 2006, the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") filed this suit in the United States District Court for the 13 District of Nevada against Consolidated Resorts, Inc., a Las Vegas-based resort company, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant engaged in unlawful employment practices in violation of Title VII in the form of sexual harassment and sex-based harassment of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The defendant alleged that if any of its supervisors or other employees engaged in 12 sexual conduct with the female employee, the conduct was not unwelcome.[SENTMARKER]In its second suit, the EEOC alleged that 3 Consolidated Realty discriminated against another female employee by terminating her because of her sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which requires the defendant to implement and monitor its compliance with Title VII and the provisions of this Decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also requires the defendants to provide annual training to its managerial employees regarding employee rights and responsibilities under the EEOC's policies and procedures and to provide periodic reports to the EEOC regarding its compliance.

gold_sents: On July 12, 2005, three U.S. farm works from Yakima Valley who were illegally denied or terminated from agricultural employment brought this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington against Global Horizons, Green Acre Farms, and Valley Fruit Orchards under the Migrants and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act, 29 U.S.C. §§ 1801, the Farm Labor Contractors Act, 42 U.S.C § 1981 and the Washington Law Against Discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to go to trial, and after years of litigation the plaintiffs received a judgment in their favor under FLCA, as well as attorneys fees, for both trial and appellate legal work.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for incentive payments.[SENTMARKER]There has been no further movement in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 27, 2001, a group of farm workers filed this class action lawsuit against Global Horizons Inc. and its owner, Mordechai Orian, alleging that they were discriminated against on the basis of race and national origin in violation of the Farm Labor Contractors Act, Section 1981, and the Washington Law Against Discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the terms and conditions of employment by failing to disclose two production standards for pruning, thinning, harvesting and other activities, failing to provide adequate written pay statements to members of the Green Acre subclass, and discharging them from employment based on national origin and race.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, 2007, the District Court for the Eastern District of Maryland entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that Global had violated the federal and state laws.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' request for injunctive relief and denied their request for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on May 25, 2007 and the parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $237,000 in damages to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to discriminate against each other based on race or national origin.

gold_sents: On December 3, 2013, a non-profit organization filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the First Amendment, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Alliance Defending Freedom, asked the court to rule that the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) contraception insurance mandate, even with the accommodation for non-profit religious organizations, is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2014, the plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in Hobby Lobby, the plaintiff stipulated to dismissal of the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 13, 2013, four employees of a Colorado non-profit religious organization filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado, alleging that the federal government's contraceptive coverage mandate violated their religious rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 2010 (RFRA) and the First and Fifth Amendments to the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the mandate required them to provide health insurance coverage that included education and counseling regarding contraceptives and abortifacients, and forced them to speak in a manner contrary to their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On April 29, 2014, the court granted a preliminary injunction against the defendants' mandate, and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs would not be required to provide contraceptive coverage to their employees, and that the defendants would not require the plaintiffs to pay for contraceptive services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on April 29, 2015, and the case was dismissed on June 11, 2015.

gold_sents: On September 5, 2013, the voting stockholders of a Michigan for-profit corporation filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia asking the court to issue a preliminary and permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage to employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]In light of the ruling in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby the Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on October 24, 2014 permanently enjoining the defendants from enforcing compliance with the contraception coverage under the ACA.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2014, the United States District Court for the District of Columbia entered a final judgment in a lawsuit brought by a group of employees against the federal government and a private company for violating the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First and Fifth Amendments to the United Nations by denying them health insurance coverage for abortion-inducing drugs and related education and counseling for all women with reproductive capacity.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, permanently enjoined the defendants from enforcing against plaintiffs, their employee health insurance issuers, and/or third-party administrators with respect to such plan(s), and required the defendants to comply with the HHS Mandate.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on the basis that the plaintiffs had failed to show that the defendants had violated their religious rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This is a case about President Trump's executive order that prohibits racial sensitivity training in federal agencies, contractors, and grant recipients.[SENTMARKER]On October 29, 2020, the National Urban League and National Fair Housing Alliance filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia against the President, the Secretary of Labor, and the Department of Labor, seeking an injunction, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that the executive order violated freedom of speech under the First Amendment by denying benefits to private entities that express ideas the Trump Administration doesn't like.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also argued that the executive order violated the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause because the order was too vague and created with an intent to discriminate on the basis of race, national origin, sex, and/or gender.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2020, a group of private, nonprofit fair housing organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the White House, the Department of Labor, and the federal government for violating the First Amendment rights of their members by prohibiting them from discussing race and sex discrimination in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that federal contractors and their subcontractors and vendors and federal grant recipients were violating Title VII by prohibiting the use of, or instruction on, certain defined "divisive concepts" by, inter alia, private entities and their employees or organizations by deeming such subjects "interactive" and "inculcates" in their workplaces.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that the government's actions were not in compliance with Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on October 2, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the parties would not have to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On April 22, 2010, homecare providers who did not wish to support the designated labor union filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois seeking an injunction against enforcement of the agency-fee provision of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (PLRA) and a declaration that the law violated the personal assistants' fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]On June 30, 2014, the Supreme Court held that the clearest case on point, Abood v. Detroit Bd.[SENTMARKER]431 U. pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2014, a group of home care providers filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, alleging that the State of Illinois violated their First Amendment rights by requiring them to pay union dues and initiation fees to a union representative for purposes of collective bargaining.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because they lacked standing and their claims were not ripe.[SENTMARKER]The court remanded the case to the district court with instructions to dismiss the claims of the Rehabilitation Program plaintiffs without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed in part, concluding that the First Amendment prohibits the collection of an agency fee from personal assistants who do not want to join or support the union.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 8, 2018, several Texas organizations filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that HUD suspended a provision of the Fair Housing Act that would require cities to report incidents of housing discrimination and that that this suspension violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was granted, and the plaintiffs filed to reopen the case and amend their complaint.[SENTMARKER]This motion was denied on August 26, 2019.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2006, two Hispanic residents of Florida filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, monetary damages, and attorneys' fees for discrimination in the sale of housing on the basis of national origin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant condominium association for the condominium complex refused to approve their purchase of a home because they were of Hispanic origin.[SENTMARKER]On information and belief, none of the board members of the defendant association are of Hispanic national origin, and the condominium association does not use the same management company.[SENTMARKER]On April 19, 2007, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that the association's conduct was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the grounds that they had not shown that they were harmed by the defendant's actions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2010, the United States filed this civil action against Loki Properties, LLC and its owner, Robert Ryan, in the District Court for the District of Minnesota.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Loki Properties and Ryan engaged in housing discrimination on the basis of race and sex, in violation of Sections 804(a), and 810(b), and that the defendants refused to rent an apartment to John Peet in Red Wing, Minnesota, because of his race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which Loki Properties agreed to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires Loki Properties to: (i) conduct background checks on its renters; .[SENTMARKER](ii) provide training to its employees and agents on the use of fair housing; .[SENTMARKER](iii) pay a civil penalty to Mr. Peet; .[SENTMARKER](iv) provide housing assistance to the Red Wing housing authority; .[SENTMARKER](v) post a notice on its website; and (vi) promote the fair housing logo on all billboards, signs, pamphlets, and other promotional literature.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to pay a total of $2,100 to the housing authority.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The terms of this consent decree are subject to court approval.

Turk) entered a stipulated order, under which the defendants agreed to make numerous improvements to the subject properties.[SENTMARKER]Following the settlement agreement, claims concerning the liability of an architecture firm lingered, but were ultimately resolved by a stipulated dismissal on January 14, 2014.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the District Court retained jurisdiction to resolve disputes between the parties until October 2015.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no docket activity after 2014, the case is presumed closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 17, 2011, the National Fair Housing Alliance and Paralyzed Veterans of America filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia against HHHunt Corporation, a private, nonprofit, fair housing organization, alleging that the builder, designer, manager and current owners of multifamily apartment complexes violated the Fair Housing Act by failing to comply with the required elements of accessible and adaptable design in violation of Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 (the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief, as well as a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on October 26, 2012 with a final judgment entered in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to provide all of their executives with supervisory responsibility for the design and/or construction of covered multifamily dwellings and on-site management employees with supervision responsibility for all such alterations.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to post a conspicuous sign in the sales or rental locations of the apartment complexes to indicate that all dwellings are available for rental on a nondiscriminatory basis.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of the FairHousing Act Design Manual, which was amended in August 1996 to reflect the requirements of Section 504 of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

gold_sents: In 2011, the plaintiff, an individual with intellectual disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued then Director for the Agency for Persons with Disabilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 1938 & 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was involuntarily committed to residential services pursuant to Florida statute but never received any periodic review of his continued need for involuntary confinement to residential services.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Defendant's motion for summary judgment on the basis that the Agency's scheme of review satisfied the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On October 20, 2015, the US Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit reversed this decision and remanded the case to the lower court.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 28, 2013, a group of developmentally disabled residents of the Illinois Department of Human Services (DHS) filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Illinois against the DHS, the State of Illinois, and the Director of the Division of Developmental Disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 by failing to provide adequate levels of medically necessary care and services to the residents of two state-operated developmental centers (SODCs) for the developmentally disabled.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they were deprived of their equal protection rights under the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on August 9, 2013, and the case was closed on October 8, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2013, the district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the alleged violations of the ADA and Rehabilitation Act did not exist.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice, for the reasons stated below.
