gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, a group of nonprofit organizations representing asylum seekers filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Northern California against the Department of Justice and the Departments of Homeland Security and Customs and Border Protection.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government violated the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) by failing to provide notice and opportunity to comment in a timely manner.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on July 24, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On September 9, 2019, the court granted a nationwide injunction against the government's enforcement of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On July 24, 2019, the parties filed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court denied the appeal, and the parties agreed to stay the injunction pending the outcome of the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the injunction will remain in effect until the appeal is resolved.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: This case involves a challenge to the implementation of DHS's new definition of the term "public charge" on the basis that it is racially disparate.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs are represented by the Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County, the Central American Legal Center of Los Angeles, the San Francisco Immigrant Rights Coalition, and the Virginia Interfaith Center for Public Policy.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and stayed discovery until resolution of the defendants' motion to dismiss.

gold_sents: In May of 2019, asylum seekers detained under the jurisdiction of the New Orleans ICE Field Office filed a class action lawsuit against DHS, ICE, and the New Orleans ICE Field Office, alleging that they were giving blanket parole denials without individualized reviews.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, the court granted preliminary injunction, enjoining defendants from continuing to detain asylum seekers without individualized consideration.[SENTMARKER]In March 30, 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for preliminary injunction, seeking immediate reviews of class members still detained.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed a motion for order to show cause why the defendants should not be held in contempt for violating the 2019 preliminary injunction order, expedited discovery, and the appointment of a special master.[SENTMARKER]The court granted limited discovery.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2019, a group of asylum seekers detained at the New Orleans ICE Field Office filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of the Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and N.E.[SENTMARKER]ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' failure to follow the Parole Directive of 2009 and their unlawful failure to provide individualized determinations of flight risk and danger violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief setting aside NOLA ICE's blanket parole denial policy.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction in part and denied the motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint status report (Dkt.)[SENTMARKER]on October 2.[SENTMARKER]2019, which detailed the conditions of detention at the base.[SENTMARKER]The report found that the plaintiffs had been detained for longer than six months due to potential and actual exposure to the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).[SENTMARKER]In response to the COVID-19, ICE has decided to further limit detainees' access to medical/health supplies including soap, towels, and disinfectant.[SENTMARKER]In the past week, the parties have also used force against individuals confined inside the base, including five individuals who had engaged in a hunger strike and had been subjected to solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations-Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the United States Citizenship Immigration Services (USCIS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking the release of records concerning a policy called the Controlled Application Review Resolution Program (CARRP), which imposes extra-statutory rules and criteria to delay and deny immigration benefits to which applicants are entitled.[SENTMARKER]CAIR-Chicago and its litigation partners have previously filed lawsuits against USCIS to challenge, inordinate delays due to the CARRP's program impact on Muslim applicants for immigration benefits, including those seeking to naturalize as American citizens.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2017, CAIR- Chicago submitted an electronic FOIA request to the USCIS National Records Center FOIA/PA Office seeking information on all individuals who have applied for naturalization, change of status, and asylum through forms N-400, I-589, and I-485 since April 11, 2008, when USCIS instituted CARRP.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request was denied, and the Defendants failed to make any determination concerning the requested records within the statutory time period, violating FOIA and is impeding the public's efforts to educate the public about important government activities.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive and declaratory relief, granted their request for expedited processing, and granted their reasonable costs and fees incurred in this action, finding that the defendants had violated the FOIA by failing to produce in a timely manner records that respond to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted relief to the plaintiffs in the form of injunctive relief with respect to the release and disclosure of the requested documents.

gold_sents: In September 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center sued U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services and President Trump.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged defendants illegally terminated an immigration relief program that granted "deferred action" to seriously ill individuals and their families.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiff sought injunctive and declaratory relief for violations of Equal Protection and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a joint motion to stay the case on October 31, 2019, so parties could seek a nonjudicial resolution.[SENTMARKER]This followed a USCUS announcement that the deferred action program would return but requests would only be granted “based on compelling facts and circumstances.”[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice on June 15, 2021.

United States, 132 S Ct. 2492, issued an opinion that found the Act to be preempted by federal immigration law and regulations, largely on preemption grounds.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining sections of the Act, finding those sections preempted.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision, which was subsequently affirmed by a panel of the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari to decide whether Medicaid providers and recipients may maintain a cause of action under the Supremacy Clause to enforce a federal Medicaid law.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2012, the defendants filed a motion to re-enforce the injunction, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened on January 9, 2012 and the parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the defendants.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2007, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District Of Texas on behalf of all persons legally authorized to be employed in the United States who have been employed at the Swift processing plants as hourly wage earners.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants engaged in a long-term pattern and practice of violating the Immigration Reform and Control Act and the Immigration and Nationality Act, which prohibits the employment of unauthorized immigrants.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction, for failure to join necessary and indispensable parties, for lack standing, and for failing to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]In part, the parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs' costs and attorney's fees in the amount of $2 million.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in part because the plaintiffs failed to show that they were harmed by the defendants' conspiracy to depress the wages paid to its workers by knowingly hiring a workforce substantially com posed of illegal aliens.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed not to enforce the immigration and citizenship laws of the country.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2006, the ACLU of Colorado and the ACLU National Prison Project filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado on behalf of inmates at the El Paso county jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail violated the Eighth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment by using excessive force against inmates with mental health problems.[SENTMARKER]The jail's use-of-force policy allowed officers to use pepper spray against prisoners who were exhibiting signs of mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, but denied their motion for declaratory and/or injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2007, the district court again denied class certification.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the plaintiffs filed a motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 26, 2008, and the parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on October 31, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the jail to improve its mental health and suicide prevention measures.

pegasus_output_sents: In April 2008, the Department of Justice's Office for the Civil Rights of the mentally ill filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District Of Florida on behalf of inmates at Miami-DADE County Corrections and Rehabilitation Department (MDCR) facilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the inmates were deprived of medical and mental health care due to poor conditions in the facilities.[SENTMARKER]In May 2013, the parties entered into a Consent Agreement, ECF No. [5-2] ("Consent Agreement"), that addressed alleged constitutional violations regarding the provision of health care at the facilities operated by MDCR.[SENTMARKER]On April 20, 2016, the Court held a status conference during which the parties noted that the County was not in full compliance with the Consent Agreement.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2013, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the County and entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the County to provide adequate medical care to all inmates, including those with mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The County also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the case a total of $1 million in compensation.[SENTMARKER]The Court also ordered the defendants to make improvements to the facilities, including the construction of a new detention center and the creation of a mental health unit for inmates with mental illnesses.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was effective on April 30, 2013 and the final judgment was entered on May 22, 2013.

pegasus_output_sents: In October 2008, a female nurse working at Johns Hopkins Hospital filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the City of Baltimore, the Baltimore Police Department ( BPD), and two of its officers alleging that they violated her Fourth Amendment right to be free of an unreasonable search by implementing and maintaining a policy of strip searches and visual body cavity searches of all persons who were admitted to the Baltimore Central Booking and Intake Facility (CBIF), regardless of the charges filed against, or the circumstances surrounding the arrest of, the individual.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which was denied by the court, and the case was transferred to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that there was no basis to state a claim pursuant to Fed.R.Civ.P.[SENTMARKER]42  1983 and that the alleged actions of the police, even if they were agents of the City, cannot be the basis of a Section 1983 action against the city.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Fourth Circuit remanded the case to the lower court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case for $5 million in punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]In a separate appeal, the defendants appealed the decision to the United States Supreme Court.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 7, 2011, Disability Rights Mississippi (DRMS) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against Forrest County, Mississippi seeking to enforce its access rights to the Forrest County Juvenile Detention Center (FCJDC) pursuant to the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness Act of 1986 (PAlMI Act) and the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 (DD Act).[SENTMARKER]On April 12, 2011, the parties agreed to a temporary plan of access until the parties could further investigate this case and attempt to negotiate a permanent resolution or obtain a ruling from the Court on any disputed issues.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the FCJDC and its personnel would allow DRMS to conduct confidential visits with any eligible resident who would like to speak with DRMS and/or its contractor, and that DRMS would make monthly reports to the Board Attorney for Forrest County regarding its monitoring and investigating activities in the detention center.[SENTMARKER]On April 14, 2011, the court granted the parties' motion to stay enforcement of several orders that limited DRMS's access rights, and the parties entered a final judgment in favor of DRMS.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment enjoined the County from enforcing or complying with any state court orders that interfere with, contradict, or conflict with the Agreed Order entered in the above captioned matter, and enjoined DRMS from providing protection and advocacy services to the children imprisoned at the detention facility.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the County's motion to dismiss the case.

pegasus_output_sents: In October 2007, a same-sex couple who jointly parent their child as legal parents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the State of Louisiana, seeking a declaration that the state's refusal to issue a birth certificate based on an out-of-state adoption decree violated the Full Faith and Credit Clause (the "Clause") and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on their full faith and credit claim.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the amended statute was unconstitutional because it violated the FF&C Clause, and the court ordered Louisiana to issue an amended birth certificate to one of the couples.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed and the Louisiana Supreme Court upheld the district court's summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, a same-sex married couple filed this Civil Rights Act of 1871 complaint in the District Court of South Carolina (Columbia Division).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming violations of their fundamental right to marry and other protected liberties related to the differential treatment of birth records for children with same-sex married parents.[SENTMARKER]Summary Judgment was granted in favor of the Plaintiffs and a consent decree entered ordering South Carolina to make changes to the policies of their birth-record keeping, as well as the issuance of corrected birth certificates to the Plaintiffs and all who qualified under the new policies and requested such a correction.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an undisclosed settlement for attorney’s fees and the case closed in June 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, a married couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against DHEC, alleging that DHEC's denial of accurate birth certificates for the children of same-sex spouses is unconstitutional under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, Casy and Jacqueline Carson, were denied birth certificates because DHEC refused to issue them on the same terms as those issued to married, different-Sex spouses.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, granted their motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, and issued a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires DHEC to issue two-parent birth certificates to married couples of the same sex, and to use the same protocols for the issuance of birth certificates as those for married couples.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to work out the details of the consent decree, which is subject to court approval.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2019, a transgender inmate filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois alleging that she was discriminated against on the basis of her gender dysphoria disability and that her placement in segregation was cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Deon Hampton, was transferred to a women's prison in retaliation for filing a complaint against officers who sexually assaulted her and forced her to have sex with her cellmate for their entertainment.[SENTMARKER]In her amended complaint, Hampton alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Illinois Hate Crimes Act by failing to provide her with reasonable accommodations for her mental disability.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2019, a prisoner in Illinois's prison system filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Illinois, alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA) by denying him medical and mental health care that caused him physical and psychological harm.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Anthony Gay was imprisoned for a variety of violations of the ADA and the RA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants refused to provide treatment for his mental illness.[SENTMARKER]Instead, they placed him in extended solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]Instead they allowed him to remain isolated in solitary confinement and did not do so.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the Defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide a reasonable accommodation for Anthony's disability.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court and the parties settled out of court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the Plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to provide mental health services to all prisoners within the IDOC.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted a motion for summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiff, and the case was dismissed by the Court of Appeals.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2006, the ACLU and other civil rights groups filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Southern district of Indiana on behalf of inmates at the federal prison facility in Terre Haute, Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the prison's "Limited Communication for Terrorist Inmates" (CMU) policy violated the Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment and the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.)[SENTMARKER]by imposing severe restrictions on inmates' communications and other liberties.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed on April 29, 2012.[SENTMARKER]On April 29, 2012, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2019, a group of current and former prisoners filed a complaint against the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for violating their rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and Maryland State Law.[SENTMARKER]A similar case was consolidated with this one in January 2020, and a motion to dismiss the complaint is pending in federal court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 30, 2018, two inmates of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS) filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were denied the opportunity to participate in pre-release programming, including home detention, work release, and "outside detail" because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the defendants failed to engage competent medical service providers to oversee and administer the healthcare needs of prisoners committed to the custody of DPSCS.[SENTMARKER]In August 2016, the defendants filed a motion for summary judgment in the Fourth Circuit, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]On October 24, 2019, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, with leave to renew the motion, and denied their appeal.[SENTMARKER]On August 27, 2016, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The amended complaint alleged violations of the Rehabilitation Act of 1974 and the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants alleged that, among other things, they failed to make reasonable modifications to the DRCF facility to accommodate wheelchair-bound individuals and individuals with other disabilities.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants denied the plaintiffs their due process rights, denied them access to family visits for up to forty-eight hours, refused to provide them with access to work release jobs, and refused them the ability to earn wages, nor do they receive vocational training due process.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full.

gold_sents: A group of prisoners at a North Carolina private prison sued the prison company and the Federal Bureau of Prisons for deliberate indifference to their medical and mental health needs.[SENTMARKER]After lengthy procedural maneuvering involving a change of venue from D.C. to North Carolina and failed attempts at class certification, the last remaining named plaintiff was transferred and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 26, 2007, two inmates at the Rivers Correctional Institute filed a class action lawsuit against the Federal Bureau Of Prisons (BOP) and GEO Group Inc. alleging that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to provide medical, dental, and mental health care to inmates at Rivers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the BOP and GEO had a policy of confiscating prescribed medical devices, such as braces and orthopedic shoes, for no penological reason, even when such devices have been prescribed and provided by other correctional institutions.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, many of the common area bathrooms were not accessible to persons with physical disabilities such as the plaintiff, Gregory Calland.[SENTMARKER]On July 25, 2008, the court dismissed the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and for failure to state a claim, or in the alternative, to transfer the case to the Eastern District.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for leave to file a third amended complaint, which was granted on July 18, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District of Carolina and the case was dismissed on July 25, 2008.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2011, the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for sovereign immunity for a prisoner's Eighth Amendment claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 23, 2009, an individual plaintiff filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of New Jersey under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Hackensack Police Department, Hackensack Municipal Court, Bergen County Jail in the City of Hackensack, Bergen County Municipal Court, and Bergen County Prosecutor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, bringing suit pro se, sought compensatory and punitive damages plus special damages for future legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff specifically claimed that the defendants violated his Second and Fourteenth Amendment rights by attempting to break in and enter his home, threatening to imprison him, fabricating stories to have him incarcerated, and asserting false criminal charges, which led to plaintiff spending three months and five days in county jail.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendant’s and plaintiff’s motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In Dec.[SENTMARKER]2014, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court’s decision to deny summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]Settlement discussions have since been unsuccessful and the case is ongoing in the district court, pending trial once public health conditions allow.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 23, 2009, a resident of Bergen County, New Jersey filed a civil rights suit in the United States District Court for the District of Newark against the Bergen County Police Department, the Hackensack Municipal Court, and several of its employees.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights by false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and conspiracy.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2010, the Court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On April 23, 2010, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, which was granted on April 23, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, which the District Court denied.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, 2005, the parties filed a second amended complaint in the same court.[SENTMARKER]This amended complaint alleged that defendants violated Aiello's civil rights and his right to a private right of action.[SENTMARKER]The parties also alleged a conspiracy to maliciously prosecute.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the parties' motion for summary judgement, and the case was dismissed with prejudice as to all defendants, with prejudice.

gold_sents: A deaf prison inmate who primarily communicates in American Sign Language filed a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act against the Oregon Department of Corrections, claiming they failed to communicate with him for over 14 years.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit claimed that, instead of providing interpreters, the prison made him train other inmates as his interpreters and they were not qualified to help him and were also privy to confidential information.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the Court granted partial summary judgment for the defendant.[SENTMARKER]Following a jury trial on the remaining claims, the Court dismissed the plaintiff's ADA claim for failure to exhaust administrative remedies under the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The jury awarded the plaintiff $400,000 in noneconomic damages.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded the plaintiff $683,873.13 in attorneys' fees, $18,155.19 in costs, and $3,924.79 in litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]Although both parties appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, they agreed to voluntarily dismiss their appeals in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2014, a deaf inmate filed a complaint in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Oregon alleging discrimination under the Americans with Disability Act and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Title II of the ADA, and the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the Oregon Department Of Corrections (ODOC) failed to provide him with accommodations for his hearing disability that would allow him to meaningfully participate in prison programs and services provided to inmates.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that ODOC failed to engage in effective communication with him as part of its offender management and rehabilitation program.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the inmate's motion for summary judgment, dismissed his claims for injunctive relief, and denied his appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the inmate is no longer in custody.

gold_sents: On November 10, 2011, the plaintiff--an Oregon Department of Corrections inmate-- filed this lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Oregon Department of Corrections violated his First Amendment free speech rights, his Fourteenth Amendment Due Process rights, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free of cruel and unusual punishment, when they rejected a return a letter written to another ODOC inmate because the envelope had a drawing on it.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the District Court enjoined the challenged prison policy.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2011, an inmate at Oregon's State Prison ("OSP") filed this civil rights action in the District Court for the district of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his First Amendment free speech rights and his Fourteenth Amendment due process rights when they rejected his mail containing artwork on the front of the envelope and delayed initiating mental health exams and rehabilitative treatment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment and a stay of discovery, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]On February 11, 2014, the court reopened the case and granted summary judgment on all of the defendants' claims.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants declaratory and injunctive relief pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case without further litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2013, the disability rights network of Pennsylvania (DRN) filed a federal law suit in the United States District Court for the Middle district of Pennsylvania on behalf of prisoners with serious mental illness who were held in solitary confinement in the state's prisons.[SENTMARKER]The DRN's complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment rights of these prisoners by failing to adequately take their mental health into account before disciplining them by placing them in long-term solitary confinement for extended periods of time.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that these prisoners were subject to extremely harmful and unconstitutional conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in January 2015 that required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with constitutionally adequate mental health care and to stop the practice of segregating them in restricted housing units (RHUs).[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Susan E. pegasus_output_sents: On October 21, 2014, a group of individuals and organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, the Pennsylvania Attorney General's Office, and the Philadelphia County District Attorney for violating the First and Fifth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a new law, the Revictimization Relief Act of 2014, which was signed into law by then-Pennsylvania Governor Tom Corbett, was a violation of the due process and First Amendment rights of a broad array of individuals, organizations, and groups, including Prison Legal News, the City Paper, and Solitary Watch.[SENTMARKER]On November 10, 2014, the Abu-Jamal plaintiffs filed a complaint, asserting that the Silencing Act is an unconstitutional restriction of speech in violation of First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' requests for declaratory and injunctive relief, declared the Act unconstitutional, and permanently enjoined the defendants from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, a prisoner in Pennsylvania state prison filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that his 22 years of solitary confinement violated the Eighth Amendment as well as his Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties concluded successful mediation as a result of systemic changes to Pennsylvania's policies concerning solitary confinement and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2013, a prisoner with serious mental illness and intellectual disabilities filed a lawsuit against the Pennsylvania Department of corrections, alleging that the department's use of solitary confinement violated his constitutional rights under the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act. According to the complaint, from June 1991 to January 1995, the prisoner was confined to a cell that exposes him to air temperature that is colder than the air temperature in the general prison population.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner also alleges that his prolonged years in solitary confinement deprived him of physical health and exercise, and that the conditions imposed upon him for the past 21 years are significantly harsher than those imposed on prisoners in general population.[SENTMARKER]In May 2013, the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division conducted a statewide investigation into solitary confinement on prisoners with mental illness or intellectual disabilities, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA).[SENTMARKER]The investigation found a pattern of constitutional violations, as well as violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) at the State Correctional Institution in Cresson, Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The investigation was conducted by attorneys with the Special Litigation Section and the U. pegasus_output_sents: On March 21, 2012, a class of inmates in Virginia's prisons brought this suit against the Virginia Parole board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of Virginia alleging that the Board's practices, policies and procedures violated their constitutional rights with respect to discretionary parole release.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the case was appealed to the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, 2012, the court granted the appeal, finding that the district court's dismissal of the case violated the plaintiffs' rights under the Due Process Clause and the Ex Post Facto Clause.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court held that the case should be certified as a class, and that the board's policies and practices violated the due process clause.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2016, a man with schizo-affective disorder and depression filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Vermont against the State of Vermont's Department of Correctional Services and the Vermont Departments of Aging and Independent Living (DAIL) under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Fair Housing and Public Accommodations Act (VFHPAA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants willfully and knowingly caused Plaintiff to be held in unnecessarily segregated circumstances when he would be eligible for community placement if the appropriate, State-funded available community supports and services were implemented.[SENTMARKER]The complaint sought declaratory, injunctive, compensatory, and punitive relief pursuant to the ADA and the VFHPAA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered a settlement agreement on June 6, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a system to identify and implement appropriate disability-related supports in the community to prevent continued, unnecessary and harmful institutionalization of prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay a total of $325,000 in damages to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 13, 2017, a group of current and former residents of the Alexander County housing authority filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois against the housing authority for violating the Fair Housing Act and the Illinois civil rights act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that for years, ACHA and its agents have discriminated against residents of its McBride and Elmwood family housing developments based on their race and familial status.[SENTMARKER]In 1974, the Department of Justice filed a suit against ACHA for intentionally segregating its two main public housing complexes by race.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was eventually settled, and ACHA agreed to stop segregation of its housing based on race.[SENTMARKER]However, for at least ten years, the defendants have implemented a rule prohibiting families with children from living in Connell Smith, Shoemaker, and several of the scattered site developments and improperly reserved them for seniors and people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants were warned that failure to comply with the Court’s order could result in dismissal of their claims for want of prosecution.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 29, 2020, a group of San José residents and a nonprofit organization filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court in San Jose against the city and its police department.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city's police department had violated the plaintiffs' First Amendment rights to free speech and assembly by restricting them from participating in demonstrations in the city.[SENTMARKER]In response to the May 25, 2020 murder of George Floyd by Minneapolis police officers, the plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]On June 7, 2020, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the police department's actions were unconstitutional and that the plaintiffs had been deprived of their constitutional rights.

gold_sents: This is a lawsuit brought by several black activist groups, legal organizations, and news media outlets, against the heads of various federal agencies, including the DHS, ICE, Federal Protective Services, and the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the deployment to Chicago of these federal agencies by President Trump during the protests that ensued after the police killing of George Floyd were unlawful and unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments by using these agents, and that they were in conspiracy to deprive Chicago residents of their rights.[SENTMARKER]When Joe Biden replaced Donald Trump as President, the change in administration mooted the case.[SENTMARKER]It was voluntarily dismissed by the plaintiffs in January 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: Plaintiffs have been engaged intensively in peaceful protest in Chicago for the past eight weeks.[SENTMARKER]They and their members have additional peaceful protests planned for today and the immediate future.[SENTMARKER]It also provides legal representation to protesters who are arrested.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights by sending law enforcement infiltrators to surveil protest groups and using technology to spy on the communications of protesters and organizers.[SENTMARKER]The district court in Portland denied the Oregon Attorney General’s motion for a temporary restraining order on standing grounds, Rosenblum, 2020 WL 4253209, and plaintiff subsequently dismissed the case.

gold_sents: Individuals issued summonses by the NYPD without probable cause brought a class action suit against the City of New York.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the NYPD's 'quota' policy is linked to officer promotion and demotion, and as a result, leads to commanding officers ordering police officers to arrest and issue summonses to individuals without probable cause, in contravention of the federal and state constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Judge Sweet, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, granted the case class action status in April 2012.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2017, Judge Sweet preliminary approved the parties' settlement agreement, in which the parties agreed to settlement benefits of up to seventy-five million dollars.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2017, the court granted final approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing for compliance purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who were issued summonses by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) in violation of the First Amendment right to peaceably assemble.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the NYPD violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights by issuing summonses that were later dismissed upon a judicial finding of facial insufficiency or were ticketed without probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 23, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $18,500 in attorney's fees and costs, subject to Court approval, to settle the class action.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is non-collusive and does not require the plaintiffs to pay any fees associated with the litigation.

gold_sents: On August 28, 1997, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the City of Steubenville pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §14141 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio to remedy an alleged pattern or practice of unconstitutional misconduct by officers of the Steubenville Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into consent decree contemporaneously with filing the complaint.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring and reporting continued into 2005, when the parties filed and the court granted a joint motion for termination.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 3, 1997, the United States District Court for the Southern District Of Ohio entered a consent decree in this case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the consent decree to resolve the subject matter of this action and the District Court approved the decree on September 3.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims, holding that there were genuine issues of material fact on the warrantless-entry and false-arrest claims.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2006, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case, claiming that the relief sought by the plaintiffs was in direct contradiction to the terms of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the case was dismissed on May 8, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a second motion to consolidate the case and the district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on March 3, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a new process for the hiring of a future police chief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide training in communications skills and avoid representation by the Department.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2012, African American and African American residents of Shelby County, Texas, filed a class action lawsuit against the county and the county district attorney's office, alleging that the county had violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from individuals who are, or appear to be, members of a racial or ethnic minority and their passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought in part, an injunction requiring the county to provide them with "mutually affordable health care."[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in August 2012 via a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties' dispute over attorneys' fees was resolved as a result of a mediator's proposal that was accepted by the parties.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are preliminarily approved, and the parties have entered into an interlocal agreement with Shelby County Precinct Constables Zack Warr (Pct.)[SENTMARKER]to adopt an impartial policing policy.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provides remedies for the plaintiffs' complaints, including the right to be notified before a canine sniff is used at a traffic stop and to have written notice provided to any person before a search is conducted.[SENTMARKER]The defendants have also agreed to make audio and video recordings of all traffic stops and all searches, seizures, detentions, and arrests that result from traffic stops, to be posted on the websites for the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to institute internal review procedures every quarter to ensure compliance with the consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The court may extend or shorten the four-year period.

gold_sents: In 2021, the ACLU and private counsel brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in response to President Trump’s June 11, 2020 Executive Order authorizing economic sanctions against individuals who assist the International Criminal Court in investigating or prosecuting war crimes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and §706 of the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory relief and an injunction that would prevent the Trump Administration from implementing or enforcing the Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2020, a group of individuals representing victims of atrocity crimes filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU's Human Rights Program, alleged that the Executive Order and its implementing steps violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting their constitutionally protected speech with the OTP.[SENTMARKER]The Executive Order, which was issued in September 2020, prohibited the plaintiffs from transferring or receiving information or informational materials from the OTP, and prohibited them from representing atrocity victims in ICC proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Charles R. Breyer, who granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment on June 15, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The United States is appealing the decision.

gold_sents: The Alliance Party and two third-party presidential sued the District of Columbia Board of Elections.[SENTMARKER]The D.C. city government had lowered the signatures required for ballot qualification from 5,007 to 250 on August 6, 2020, the day after petitions to appear on the ballot were due.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs contended that they had ceased collecting signatures because it was "impossible" to collect 5,007 signatures while adhering to social distancing guidelines, but would have continued their efforts if they knew they only had to get 250.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied a motion for temporary restraining order, the 2020 election was held and this case was dismissed soon after.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 7, 2020, a group of third-party presidential candidates filed a lawsuit against the District's Board of Election in the District of Washington, alleging that the board's enforcement of a law that lowered the signature requirement to secure ballot access violated their First and 14th Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an emergency temporary injunction and/or preliminary injunctive relief barring the board from enforcing the law and extending the deadline for third party presidential candidates to file election petitions to secure access to the District’s 2020 general election presidential ballot until September 1, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted their motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In 2015, residents of Jefferson County, Florida filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan was guilty of "prison-based gerrymandering," and was thus guilty of violating the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought and received a declaration that the 2013 plan was unconstitutional as well as an injunction requiring the defendants to produce an acceptable redistricting plan.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' plan was approved and parties then settled on the attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: Several citizens and residents of Arizona subject to the death penalty brought suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADC) and several associated governmental employees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the ADC's lethal injection procedure violated their First Amendment right to access governmental proceedings, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Eighth Amendment, and the Federal Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a stipulated agreement prohibiting the defendant from using certain chemicals for execution, among other limitation.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing after the Ninth Circuit remanded counts for retrial.

gold_sents: In 2012, plaintiffs filed suit in the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA), when applied retroactively, violated their rights to due process, was unconstitutionally vague, violated prohibitions on ex post facto laws, and violated their fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, upon remand from the Sixth Circuit, the district court held that SORA violated the Ex Post Facto clause and could not be applied retroactively.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2012, Plaintiff John Does I-IV and Mary Doe filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan against the director of the Michigan State Police, the State Department of Corrections, and the State Attorney's Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sex offender registration and address verification procedures in Michigan violated the Ex Post Facto clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that the registration and verification procedures violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now before the court on remand.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the parties agreed that the defendants would not require the plaintiffs to register as sex offenders for the rest of their lives, and that the case would be dismissed and sealed.

gold_sents: Six Insane Clown Posse fans, or "Juggalos," sued the DOJ and FBI in the the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under the Administrative Procedures Act and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging that the FBI had designated the Juggalos as a "loosely organized hybrid gang" in 2011, which had caused various harms to the plaintiffs, including extra police attention.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case upon finding that the designation was not a final agency action, and the Sixth Circuit affirmed the dismissal.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 29, 2018, a group of Black and Latino residents of Buffalo, New York filed a class action lawsuit against the City ofBuffalo and the Buffalo Police Department, alleging that the City had engaged in a systematic practice of targeting black and Latino neighborhoods and residents for aggressive and punitive traffic en-cement.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' policies, practices, and/or customs have directly caused the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles to suspend thousands of driver's licenses belonging to low-income people of color in Buffalo.[SENTMARKER]Most of the drivers pulled over for secondary inspections were Black, and the majority of the tickets, arrests, impounds, and impounds involved Black or Latino drivers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and injunctive and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on June 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 30, 2020, Disability Rights California brought a suit against Alameda County in the Northern District Court of California.[SENTMARKER]Disability Rights California alleged that Alameda County had discriminated against residents with serious mental health disabilities by institutionalizing and segregating them instead of providing adequate treatment and services.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2021, the Court granted Alameda County’s motion to dismiss with leave to amend and denied their motion to strike.[SENTMARKER]Disability Rights California has filed an amended complaint as of February 23, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2020, Disability rights California (DRC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the County of Alameda, the County's mental health services provider, and the California Department of Mental Health (DMV) alleging violations of the Americans with Disability Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and California's Medi-Cal program.[SENTMARKER]DRC's complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide sufficient community-based treatment programs to reduce the risk of 18 institutionalization and unnecessary segregation of people with mental health disabilities.[SENTMARKER]DRC also alleged unlawful segregation of individuals with mental illness in the county's psychiatric institutions.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss DRC’s claims for lack of standing and for failure to state a claim for which relief may be granted.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss with leave to amend because DRC had not stated a claim under the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 1, 2014, deaf and hard of hearing inmates in the Kentucky prison system filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky and the Kentucky Department of Corrections, alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they were denied access to telecommunications and denied interpretative services for religious services, job training, disciplinary hearings, public announcements, educational and vocational training effectively excluding them from many governmental services.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached settlement which was entered by the court in a consent decree in June, 2015.[SENTMARKER]A monitor was appointed, who will submit a  semi-annual report during the five-year term of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement includes provision of services and accommodations through a qualified interpreter and communication technologies, staffing, and training.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 24, 2015, two deaf inmates filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Eastern district of Kentucky, alleging that the state of Kentucky violated their rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide them with telecommunications services.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that deaf inmates were denied access to videophone services because the state did not provide access to telecommunications equipment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on April 27.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the state agreed to provide deaf inmates with telecommunication equipment and to provide qualified intepreter services to all deaf inmates.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the state to provide hearing aid earphones for deaf inmates and to make phone amplifiers available to deaf inmates in each prison.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the court ordered the prison to provide the inmates with videophones.

gold_sents: In January 2015, the plaintiff, a prisoner, filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections systematically denied medical care to individuals with severe eye conditions, including severe cataracts, in violation of the ADA, § 504, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the Department of Corrections changed their cataract policy, no longer denying surgery to individuals who had "One Good Eye."
pegasus_output_sents: In January 1983, a prison inmate filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania on behalf of inmates with severe eye conditions who were denied necessary medical care for cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pennsylvania's "One Good Eye" policy, which denied surgical treatment in a diseased eye if an inmate has some vision in the other eye, deprived them of their rights guaranteed by the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in January 1983 with the consent of the parties.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement that required the defendants to provide post-operative treatment for each inmate undergoing cataract surgery in accordance with the outside ophthalmologist's recommendation, including follow-up examinations, refraction for new glasses, and laser and surgical procedures to address any postoperative complications.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: Students in Mobile County schools sued the county for violations of the Fourteenth Amendment Right to Due Process by denying the students a hearing before issuing long-term suspensions and expulsions.[SENTMARKER]The case entered mediation and was settled on the terms of the agreement that amended the school district's disciplinary procedures and practices.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2011, a group of students filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the southern district of Alabama against the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County (the "Board").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Board violated the Fourteenth Amendment right to due process by imposing long-term suspensions on students without providing even the reduced due process required by the District's challenged policy.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were not adequately informed of the right to a due process hearing when their children were suspended without assignment to alternative school.[SENTMARKER]In June 2012, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the Board.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the School System would provide reasonable career preparation assistance and assistance with the graduation exam for all students who were suspended for more than ten days without proper notice or a hearing.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also provided that the plaintiffs would be required to submit a copy of their complaint to the School Commissioner's Office for review.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on June 30, 2012.

gold_sents: In 2017, four low-income African American mothers filed suit against the numerous officials of the State of Mississippi claiming the state failed to live up to the educational requirements set by the Mississippi Readmission Act of 1870.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory relief that the requirements are still intact.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2018 due to the state sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit which affirmed in part and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]The defendants requested rehearing en banc, but the Fifth Circuit denied the request.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a petition for review with the Supreme Court and a request to stay the Fifth Circuit's mandate in January 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2018, a group of low-income African-American women filed this class action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of the Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state of Mississippi had violated the Mississippi Read Mission Act by amending the education clause in the Mississippi Constitution after its ratification following the Civil War.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on several grounds, including that the plaintiffs lacked standing and that the case was barred by sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs moved for leave to amend their complaint to cure the pleading defects that they believe resulted in the dismissal of this case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion and entered an amended Final Judgment dismissing the case without prejudice, which the plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2009, a high school student and his younger sister filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York, alleging that the school district, its Board of Education, Superintendent, agents, and employees violated Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972 (EAA), and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (EC 14th Amendment) by denying them permission to form a Gay-Straight Alliance (GSA) organization.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants repeatedly denied their requests for permission to use the school's public address system to form the GSA.[SENTMARKER]The district denied the plaintiffs' request for a permanent injunction, and the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on the basis that the district's policy with respect to maternity leave was in the public interest.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on April 8, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on April 10, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' claim for punitive damages against the district was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The court also entered a judgment against the defendants in part.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 28, 2007, a lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama on behalf of a group of African-Americans who alleged that a pest control company discriminated against them by denying them employment based on the color of their skin.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendant's office allowed individuals to complete applications and submit them at the office even when the office had no available positions for hire.[SENTMARKER]In January 2011, the parties reached a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on January 27, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The settlement fund consisted of $2,500,000, which included all costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was achieved after nearly five years of litigation and extensive discovery.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to stay this action pending mediation.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for preliminary approval of the settlement with this court on November 3, 2011 and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 29, 2009, a class action lawsuit was brought in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Northern District Of California against Samsonite Company Stores, Inc. and its parent company, Samsonite Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Labor Standards Act ("FLSA"), California's Labor Code, and New York's Fair Employment and Housing Act ("FEHA"), by misclassifying some of its store managers as non-exempt and engaging in outside networking activities on the company's behalf.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $850,000 to all 89 of the class members to resolve all outstanding wage and hour claims under the FLSA, California, and FEHA.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the court on May 29, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the case would proceed as a collective action under the FEHA, and that the court would determine the amount of attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2018, a group of low-income housing voucher holders and a nonprofit organization filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Columbia against the U,S.[SENTMARKER]District Department of HUD and HUD Secretary Ben Carson, alleging that HUD's decision to suspend implementation of its own promulgated rule, the Small Area Fair Market Rent Rule (Small Area FMR Rule), violated the Fair Housing Act of 1968 and the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 (HCD Act).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring HUD to implement the Rule on its effective date of January 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were African-American, Latino, and other racial minorities, wanted to move from poor and racially segregated communities to areas of greater opportunity but were being blocked by HUD’s action from doing so, along with the nonprofit organization Open Communities Alliance.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, finding that the two-year delay of the Rule’s implementation was arbitrary and capricious, and that HUD had failed to show that it had the authority to delay the Rule's implementation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a permanent injunction, which the court granted on June 15, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 18, 2001, and September 3, 2002, the United States filed a civil action in the Northern District Court of Indiana alleging discrimination against persons with disabilities under the Fair Housing Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Edward Rose Sons, several affiliate companies, as well as individual architects and architectural firms, had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by failing to include accessible features required by the Act in a number of apartment complexes it developed in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Illinois, Virginia, and Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]On February 24, 2003, the Court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining the defendants from occupying or further constructing 19 apartment buildings at Westlake Apartments in Belleville, Michigan and Lake Pointe Apartments in Batavia, Ohio until they could be redesigned or retrofitted to be brought into compliance with the Fair housing Act. On August 25, 2004, the Sixth Circuit court of Appeals affirmed the decision of the district court granting the U.N.[SENTMARKER]'s motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2005, the former defendants entered a consent order to retrofit 49 apartment complexes to enhance their accessibility to individuals with physical disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The consent order will remain in effect for five years.
