gold_sents: On June 4, 2013, plaintiffs, natives of Mexico who had agreed to voluntary departure from the United States, filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Central District of California under the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), 8 U.S.C. §1101, and state law against the acting director of Homeland Security, U.S. Customs and Border Protection ("CBP") and Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement ("ICE").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's agencies in southern California violated INA by coercing plaintiffs into accepting voluntary departure through misstatements, omissions, threats, and/or pressure in violation of defendants' own regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on March 11, 2015, where defendants agreed to allow applications from the class members that would enable their return to the United States and their legal position prior to acceptance of voluntary departure.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 4, 2013, a group of individuals and three non-profit organizations filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Southern district of California against federal immigration enforcement agencies for their unlawful voluntary departure practices in Southern California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that implementation of the program deprived the deportees of their rights under federal statutes and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed that the plaintiffs would be allowed to return to the United States in a manner that restores them to the legal position that they occupied prior to their respective voluntary departures.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 11, 2013, before the hearing.[SENTMARKER]On November 5, 2013, the parties filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was denied by Judge Abrams.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2014, the parties attended a settlement conference with Judge Abrams and the parties reached an agreement.[SENTMARKER]On May 23, 2014, Judge Abrams entered a final judgment in favor of the class, which required the parties to settle the case for $700,000.

gold_sents: On July 10, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed this FOIA suit against U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought records pursuant to a FOIA request about the defendant's use of a contractor to process and transport immigration detainees, some of whom had allegedly suffered injury and death due to the contractor's malfeasance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an order from the court that the defendant provide the records.[SENTMARKER]This case was combined with a suit from a private plaintiff alleging mistreatment in ICE and G4S custody in July 2019.[SENTMARKER]Document production appears to be continuing smoothly at a rate of 750 pages per month, but shifting production online due to COVID-19 has yielded some issues in getting documents over to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Document production is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the ACLU filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California (San Francisco) on behalf of the ACLU Northern California and East Bay Express, a local independent newspaper, seeking information about the treatment of immigration detainees in ICE custody.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU sought records about the detention and transportation of individuals in ICE's San Francisco Area of Responsibility, including the use of private contractors, the detention policies, procedures, and guidelines for detaining and transporting immigration detainees, and the retention of private transportation providers.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2018, the ACLU and EBE submitted a FOIA request to ICE seeking records related to the detention, transportation, and retention of individual detainees in the San Francisco area.[SENTMARKER]ICE responded to the FOIA request by failing to produce a single document in response to either the First FOIA Request or the Second FOIA Request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU's motion for partial summary judgment and ordered ICE to comply with the FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 13, 2020, the State of California and the University of California filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for rescinding the in-person learning exemption for F-1 and M-1 nonimmigrant students.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the rescission of the exemption violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) because it was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit in April of this year, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the case should be dismissed on the same or similar grounds.[SENTMARKER]In a separate action, the State also filed a suit against DHS on July 10, 2020, alleging that the rescinding of the exemptions violated the APA because the exemptions were issued at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the State's motion for summary judgment, and granted the parties' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.

gold_sents: On July 20, 2010, the American Immigration Lawyers Association (AILA) filed suit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for failing to adequately respond to FOIA requests regarding USCIS procedures for inspecting potential H-1B visa fraud.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2012, the District Court ordered DHS to provide adequate description of the exempted information in response to the FOIA request so that AILA could make a proper segregability determination.[SENTMARKER]This was the last action in this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2011, the American ImmigrationLawyers Association (AILA) filed this Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia seeking the release of records concerning agency policies and procedures relating to nonimmigrant temporary workers and particularly the adjudication of petitions for their lawful employment in the US.[SENTMARKER]AILA challenged the defendants' failure to comply with the FOIA requests, including the failure to segregate non-exempt information from allegedly exempt information, and the alleged applicability of FOIA exemptions to the records sought.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, asking the Court to determine that they satisfied their obligations under FOIA as to all documents produced or withheld, that they properly invoked exemptions pursuant to several FOIA exemptions, and that they did not waive their ability to invoke exemptions because of information that exists in the public domain.[SENTMARKER]The parties did not dispute that the BFCA Report has been publicly disclosed.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants summary judgment as to the entirety of their searches and subsequent responses to plaintiff's FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Central American mothers and children detainees brought suit against the Department of Homeland Security and its various agencies for the government's unlawful expedited removal policies at the Artesia Family Residential Center.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in January 2015 after DHS remedied the violations of Plaintiffs' rights in their immigration proceedings and closed the Artesia facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 30, 2015, a group of asylum seekers filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Washington against the Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were detained at the Artesia Family Residential Center in New Mexico, alleged that the government's new expedited removal policies and procedures prevented them from pursuing their asylum claims, and to seek the assistance of counsel in doing so.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the plaintiffs alleged that ICE officers had applied coercion to dissuade plaintiffs and other asylum seekers from seeking legal counsel and otherwise asserting their rights through the legal process.[SENTMARKER]ICE officers, however, denied the plaintiffs' request for expedited processing, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents who were separated from their young children filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the district of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, Texas Civil Rights Legal Aid, Inc. D.D.C.[SENTMARKER]and two other parents, filed this suit on behalf of their children under the age of five who had been detained by the government without regard to parental fitness.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2018, the Attorney General announced a "zero-tolerance" immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]Under that policy, all immigrant parents unlawfully crossing the US-Mexico border with their children would be subject to criminal prosecution.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2018, two of the plaintiffs, M.G.U.[SENTMARKER]and A.P.F., were detained together in Texas.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction seeking immediate reunification.[SENTMARKER]On July 5, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order requiring the government to provide reliable, daily information about their children's well-being by July 10, 2018, and those age five and over by July 26, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On July 16, 2018, the Court granted plaintiffs' TRO application with respect to certain outstanding requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to meet and confer and provide a joint status report to the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court issued a final judgment in favor of the defendants on July 16, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on June 20, 2019, seeking class-wide injunctions and a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted on July 20, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2019, the court issued a judgment against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The court granted plaintiffs’ motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: This action, filed Jan.[SENTMARKER]31, 2017, challenges President Trump’s Jan.[SENTMARKER]27, 2017 Executive Order ban on admission to the U.S. of nationals of Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that in preventing a Syrian national with a valid U.S. visa from returning to the U.S. pursuant to the EO, the defendants violated the First Amendment Establishment Clause, Fifth Amendment due process and equal protection rights, the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Administrative Procedure Act, and international law.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by private counsel and Bernard Harcourt of Columbia Law School, is a resident in the University of Illinois Chicago/Advocate Christ Hospital.[SENTMARKER]He returned to the United Arab Emirates to get married on Jan.[SENTMARKER]23, and upon returning to the U.S. to continue his residency, he was detained at Abu Dhabi International Airport on Jan 29.[SENTMARKER]Despite his valid visa, he was detained pursuant to the EO.[SENTMARKER]If the plaintiff cannot return to the U.S., he faces the risk of being deported to Syria, where he is a citizen but has never been a resident.[SENTMARKER]That same day, the plaintiff also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Elaine Bucklo.[SENTMARKER]At a status hearing on February 1, the parties told the judge they had reached a "settlement in principle."[SENTMARKER]On February 2, the plaintiff successfully entered the United States at Chicago O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, the plaintiff filed a motion for voluntary dismissal and leave to reinstate on or before August 1, 2017.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bucklo granted this motion and terminated the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 31, 2017, a medical resident of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Illinois against Donald Trump, John Kelly, and Kevin McAleenan, acting as the President and Secretary of DHS, respectively, in connection with the President's executive order temporarily suspending the entry of certain nationals from seven countries.[SENTMARKER]According to the terms of the Executive Order, the entry into the U.s. of non-citizens from Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen is "suspended" from 90 days from the date of the EO.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff, who was born in the UAE and was in possession of a valid J-1 visa issued to complete his residency at the University of Illinois College of Medicine/Christ Advocate Hospital, was detained at Abu Dhabi International Airport on January 29, 2017, and subsequently refused entry onto an Etihad Airways flight bound for Chicago, O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2017, the Plaintiff filed a motion to intervene, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for a temporary restraining order and a permanent injunction, and issued a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff on February 10, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the Defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice, and with leave to reinstate the case on or before 8/1/17.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed as moot.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2013, 13 Indian guestworkers filed suit in S.D.[SENTMARKER]Miss.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme.[SENTMARKER]In Oct. 2013, the court transferred this case to E.D.La where it was consolidated with the Achari lead case.[SENTMARKER]The Achari case was dismissed due to settlement agreement but the court retained jurisdiction.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2006, a group of Indian workers from India brought this suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work in unsafe and unsanitary conditions at Signal's facility in Pascagoula, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that Signal threatened them with reduced pay, suspension, dismissal, or deportation if they complained about the conditions.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated with a separate suit in October 2013 and the parties agreed to a settlement in October 2013.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]In October 2013, the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: In 2015, six refugees living in Utica, NY filed this class action in the Northern District of New York against the Utica School District Board of Education and the Utica City School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants consistently denied Utica residents between the ages of 17 and 20 who were limited English proficient (LEP) and immigrants access to educational opportunity.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties reached a settlement requiring the defendants to end their discriminatory practices and enact a detailed remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the consent decree is ongoing as of November 2018.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2016, a class action was brought in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of New York on behalf of limited English proficient (LEP) immigrant students aged 17-20 who were excluded from Proctor High School in Utica, New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had a policy and practice of excluding LEP immigrant students from high school and diverting them to either the Newcomer Program or the APPLE Program.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants did not test LEP students to determine their level of English proficiency before placing them in the Newcomer program and did not offer them the option to transfer to Proctor High.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on June 6, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is effective immediately upon the signature of the court and requires the defendants to address language barriers that impede equal participation by ELLs aged 16-20 in its instructional programs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a permanent injunction.

gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a class action in the United States District Court for the District of Western New York against the Executive Office of Immigration Review (EOIR), the Department of Justice (DOJ), and the Department's Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking class certification, a declaratory judgment, and a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The petitioners alleged that the EOIR, the DOJ, and ICE violated the immigration and nationality act, the administrative procedure act, and the Fifth Amendment by detaining individuals without bond for more than seven months at the Buffalo Federal Detention Facility.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification in part and denied in part the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the district court on July 22, 2020 and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In part, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed as to the class members detained at the RCC.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the defendants violated the administrative procedures act by failing to provide the plaintiffs with a custody hearing and that each class member must be released unless the government provided clear and convincing evidence that the detained individual is a danger to others or a flight risk.[SENTMARKER]On July 22, 2020, the court dismissed the case without prejudice, granting the plaintiffs’ motion for class certification and denying the defendants’ motions to dismiss.

gold_sents: In May 2015, parents of children born in Texas sued the Texas Department of State Health Services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, all Mexican or Central American citizens, asked for the release of their U.S.-citizen children's birth certificates, which defendant would not issue after refusing to accept the parents' consular identity documents.[SENTMARKER]The parties privately settled in July 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 10, 2012, the Mexican consulate in McAllen, Texas issued a photo ID card to Mexican citizens residing in the United States.[SENTMARKER]The Mexican consulate then denied the Mexican citizen's mother-in-law's request for a birth certificate for her son and daughter because it was too old.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff's complaint alleged that the defendants' policy of denying birth certificates to children born in Texas on the basis of their parents' immigration status violated the Fourteenth Amendment due process clause and the Equal Protection clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a Declaratory Judgment, finding that the Defendants' policy violated the Due Process clause and denied the plaintiffs the right to access their children's birth certificates.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the Plaintiffs' request for an order requiring the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with certified copies of the birth certificates of their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the State of Texas filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, the League of United Latin American Citizens, Travis County, Maverick County, and the Texas Organizing Project Education Fund ( TOPEF) alleging violations or state and federal law in the San Antonio Division of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The State alleged that El Paso engaged in a pattern and practice of prohibiting enforcement of federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the suit for lack of jurisdiction, ruling that the City sought an impermissible advisory opinion.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2017, the District Court granted the defendants' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to sue each other.

gold_sents: On May 3, 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice investigated the Harrison County, MI jail.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ found violations of inadequate staffing and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Apparently after negotiation, the Attorney General filed an action under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. 1997 et seq., against the jail in 1995.[SENTMARKER]Six days later, Judge Walter J. Gex III approved a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree mandated doubling the number of officers, increased training, and hiring of medical professionals for the physical and mental health of the patients.[SENTMARKER]The decree was enforced sporadically throughout the next ten years.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2015, the parties filed a joint motion for dismissal, with the county agreeing to continue to use its best efforts to improve its mental health and medical care.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on August 12, 1995.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought by the United States Departments of Justice and Justice Department's Civil Rights Division under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act of 1993 (CRIPA) in the Southern district of Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the constitutional rights of inmates confined at the Harrison County Adult Detention Center (HCDC) by failing to provide them with adequate access to the courts, inadequate training, adequate medical staffing, adequate mental health care, and inadequate access to legal materials for research and writing.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in May 1993, which required the defendants to comply with the conditions of confinement and treatment of the inmates at the HCDC.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered by Chief District Judge Louis Guirola, Jr. on August 12, 2003, pursuant to which the defendants agreed to provide inmates with access to courts by, inter alia, providing them with meaningful and effective access to law books and legal research materials, and to implement policies and procedures at the jail.[SENTMARKER]On August 12, 2013, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case, which was dismissed by Judge Guirola.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, each party to bear its own attorney fees and costs, and the parties agreed to settle the case with the consent decree.

gold_sents: In 2003, prisoners filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Erie County Sheriff's Department had an unconstitutional policy and practice of strip-searching prisoners when they entered the county facilities.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the Supreme Court ruled that a similar strip search policy was constitutional in Florence v. Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case argued that their case was distinguishable from Florence.[SENTMARKER]However, no further action occurred in the case after 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: In the course of a lawsuit by a class of arrested persons against Erie County (and certain of its officials) alleging that they were subjected to unconstitutional strip searches of non-felony detainees, the United States District Court for the Western District Of New York (Western District) held a hearing in June 2006 on the issue of strip searches.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that since at least 2001, the Sheriff’s Department had implemented a policy to subject every detainee who entered the Erie County Holding Center or Erie County Correctional Facility to an invasive strip search without regard to individualized suspicion or the severity of the offense alleged, in violation of the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a writ of mandamus, and the district court's April 17, 2006 order was vacated.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to compel the release of certain documents, including e-mails between the plaintiffs and the Sheriff's Department.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendants' request for a stay pending appeal and the case was dismissed on June 26, 2006.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2006, the plaintiffs filed a second motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, which was granted by the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a stipulation dismissing their respective cross claims and the plaintiffs sought to interview other employees as witnesses as witnesses to the incident.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 20, 2020, three pretrial detainees filed a class-action suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Western district of Tennessee against the Shelby County Sheriff's Office, alleging that their constitutional and statutory rights were being violated by the conditions in their jail due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to protect medically vulnerable people and people with disabilities detained in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a proposed consent decree in which the jail agreed to provide at least one mask to detainees and to implement a number of other measures to protect people from the pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On June 10, 2020, the Court denied Defendants' motion and certified a class and subclass of medically vulnerable and disabled individuals detained at the jail as a class.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2020, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was dismissed by the Court on July 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties then reached a settlement agreement in which they agreed to implement several measures to ensure the safety and well-being of people detained in jail during the pandemic and to reduce the jail's population.

gold_sents: In August 2014, detainees at the Franklin County Jail filed a lawsuit alleging that jail officials used excessive force against them and that the jail provided inhumane living conditions, in violation of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In March 28, 2016, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The defendant paid $400,557.66 in attorneys’ fees and was required to hire additional staff, renovate the prison, and adopt new mental health services policies.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2014, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington on behalf of inmates at the Franklin County Correctional Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's widespread unconstitutional 13 practices, including the use of four point restraints against inmates, violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief and sought a temporary restraining order barring those practices.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on February 5, 2016 and the case was closed on July 31, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs were entitled to an award of their 19 reasonable attorneys' fees and costs pursuant to Fed R.P.[SENTMARKER]23(a) 23(b)(2).[SENTMARKER]The defendants have denied the allegations in the complaint and continue to deny liability for the allegations.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2015, a private company sued the federal government in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the government's use of the National Security Letters (NSLs) in counterintelligence investigations to demand non-content information from telecommunications and Internet service providers violated its First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the NSLs violated the First Amendment because the government requested information based on First Amendment protected activity, including requests for information on the company's customers and employees, to the press, members of the public, and to members of Congress.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to address the first amendment issues presented in the revised NSL statute.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit reversed the lower court's decision in part and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit held that, as amended in the 2015 NSL law, the nondisclosure requirement does not run afoul of the First amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit agreed, and the case is now pending before the Second Circuit.

gold_sents: In 2014, an investigative reporter filed suit under the Freedom of Information Act against the National Security Agency and U.S. Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants were improperly withholding records concerning the NSA's surveillance of federal and state judges.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the defendant conduct an email search for draft memoranda or opinions concerning such surveillance program.[SENTMARKER]The search wielded no results.[SENTMARKER]A settlement agreement was reached paying plaintiff's attorney's fees on February 27, 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2014, Plaintiff Jason Leopold filed a FOIA request under the Freedom of information Act (FOIA) seeking records related to surveillance of federal and state judges.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to conduct an adequate search of the requested records.[SENTMARKER]In July 2015, the district court granted the defendants' first motion for summary judgment, finding that the search would impose an unreasonable burden on the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a second motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the parties agreed to settle the case for a fee waiver.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2016, the parties filed a motion to re-open the case, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on August 11, 2016.

gold_sents: On September 16, 2016, The Associated Press, Gannett Satellite Information Network LLC, and Vice Media, LLC, filed a lawsuit seeking information about the recently purchased tool allowing government access to the phone of one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California on December 2, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion on September 30, 2017, finding information at issue was protected under FOIA exemptions 1, 3, and 7.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 30, 2017, two news organizations, USA TODAY and The Washington Post, filed a FOIA request under the Freedom Of Information Act (FOIA) seeking information about the FBI's use of a third-party vendor to circumvent the need for a court order to access the locked iPhone of Syed Rizwan Farook, one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California last year.[SENTMARKER]The FBI initially denied each request on the basis of FOIA Exemption 7(A), which permits agencies to withhold records or information for law enforcement purposes to the extent that the production of such records could reasonably be expected to interfere with law enforcement proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On April 21, 2016, the Washington Post filed the FOIA request with the FBI for records of the publicly-acknowledged business transaction that resulted in the purchase this March of the so-called iPhone access tool.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2016, the FBI denied the Vice Request, and on May 31, 2017, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment in favor of the News Organizations.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the records sought by USA TODAY were public records pursuant to FOIA  552, and that the court should order the FBI to produce the records requested by the news organizations.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' costs of this proceeding, including reasonable attorney's fees, as authorized by FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 17, 2006, plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the National Security Agency alleging that the Terrorist Surveillance Program was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On August 17, 2006, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan (Judge Taylor) agreed and enjoined the program.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2007, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit vacated the order and instructed to dismiss the case based on lack of standing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2006, the ACLU and the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the Eastern district of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a permanent injunction against the NSA's warrantless wiretapping and data mining program and a declaration that two aspects of the program violated the Separation of Powers Doctrine.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the basis of the state secrets evidentiary privilege and their lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court and it dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, 2007, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a ruling that dismissed the case as moot and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On September 4, 2007, the case was re-opened and the plaintiffs filed a motion for a declaratory judgment and an injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed on the ground that such surveillance would henceforth be FISA-compliant and that the plaintiffs had no standing for any of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the decision to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Sept.[SENTMARKER]8, 2014, a same-sex couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Indiana under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against a county clerk and the Indiana Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state's ban on same-sex marriages violated the their 14th Amendment rights to due process and equal protection.[SENTMARKER]After the 7th Circuit struck down Indiana's marriage ban, the state agreed to recognize the plaintiffs' out-of-state marriage pending a final resolution to the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2014, two same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Indiana against the State of Indiana, the Lake County Clerk's Office, and the Indiana State Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, Veronica Romero and Mayra Cherry, were married in the state of Illinois on March 7, 2014 and were living in Lake County, Indiana with their two minor children.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2014, the court granted a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction against the Defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be stayed until the Supreme Court issues its decision regarding the appeal in the case.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2014, the Court granted the Defendants' motion for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending an appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

gold_sents: In 2013, three same-sex couples married under the laws of other states filed a lawsuit, individually and on behalf of their children, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky, challenging the constitutionality of Kentucky's laws prohibiting same-sex couples from marrying and voiding within Kentucky marriages of same-sex couples validly entered into under the laws of other states and countries.[SENTMARKER]Judge John Heyburn found for the plaintiffs on July 1st, 2014, and issued the final order declaring Kentucky laws banning same-sex marriages to be unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]This order was stayed and then reversed by the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] April DeBoer and Jayne Rowse, a lesbian couple living in Michigan, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky on February 27, 2014 against the State of Kentucky and the Commonwealth of Kentucky, challenging the constitutionality of Kentucky’s laws excluding same-sex couples from marriage.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the laws violated the due process and equal protection guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The State moved to dismiss the lawsuit for lack of standing, and the district court tentatively agreed.[SENTMARKER]The district court preliminarily enjoined the state from recognizing out-of-state marriages on the birth certificates of the plaintiffs' children.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of Massachusetts held in 2003 that the State’s Constitution guaranteed the right to marry.[SENTMARKER]In 2013, the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed the District Court’s decision and held that the state’s law violated the equal protection and due process guarantees.[SENTMARKER]The case was restyled and the plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeal for the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held that there was no reason to believe that the plaintiffs had standing to file this suit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court held that they had not shown that they would be harmed by the state's refusal to recognize their marriages on their children's birth certificates.[SENTMARKER]The cases were dismissed and the parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would not appeal to the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In November 2003, three same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District District Court for the Northern district of Oklahoma, challenging the federal defense of marriage act and Oklahoma's amendment to the Oklahoma Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DOMA and the Oklahoma Amendment violate the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In response, the Oklahoma officials moved to dismiss, claiming venue was improper, the plaintiffs lacked standing, and the suit was barred by the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment and the case was stayed pending a ruling by the Tenth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]In November 2004, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint naming the State of Oklahoma as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The court permanently enjoined enforcement of Section 2 of DOMA, Section 3 of Oklahoma Amendment, and Section 7 of the Oklahoma Marriage Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In October 2004, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion to withdraw as an intervening party, granted their motion to dismiss as moot, and granted their declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On November 3, 2003, the court issued an order enjoining the state from enforcing Section 2 and Section 3.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the defendants in October 2004.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This case was brought by workers with limited English proficiency, whose jobs were lost or threatened by foreign competition against the U.S. Department of Labor, seeking injunctive relief, a declaratory judgment and costs for the DOL's failure to provide adequate training under the Trade Act of 1974.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on December 30, 2005 and resulted in the establishment of a program for Limited English-Proficient workers in the El Paso area by the DOL as well as widespread policy changes as to the administration of the job training benefits.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2002, the Association of Border Workers (ATF) and several of its members filed this lawsuit in the Western District of Texas against the Department of labor for violating the Trade Act of 1974 (Trade Act) in its administration of job training benefits for "limited English proficient" (LEP) workers in El Paso, Texas.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2003, this Court granted the Department's Motion to Stay the Original Texas Case.[SENTMARKER]On November 5, 2004, Plaintiffs filed a nearly identical suit in the Federal District Court for the District of Colurnbia.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to fund and administer a project for limited English proficient trade-certified workers in the El Paso area.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on December 17, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which each party would be responsible for their own attorney fees and costs associated with the project.

gold_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African American inmate in the Arizona State Prison Complex in Tucson filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and the Arizona Department of Correction in the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the prison segregated him by race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on December 22, 2015, under which the defendants would narrowly limit racial consideration in prison housing and employment opportunities, and pay $5,000 in monetary damages to plaintiff as well as $195,000 to plaintiff’s counsel in attorneys’ fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2013, an African-American inmate at the Arizona state prison complex in Tucson, Arizona, filed a pro se civil rights suit in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona, alleging racial discrimination and de facto segregation based on race.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged that he was assigned to and retained in segregation on the basis of his race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On June 2015, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On January 2016, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement an integrated housing program, develop and implement policies, procedures, and practices necessary to implement a "discriminatory employment program," and to pay monetary damages to the Plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]On March 2016, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, a group of California prisoners with mental illness filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation alleging that the prison system's policies regarding prisoners with mental disabilities violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in 2015 and the court retained jurisdiction to enforce the terms of the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: This is an action for relief from Defendants’ violation of the rights of persons with psychiatric disabilities under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. On December 1, 2005, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties could not reach an agreement.[SENTMARKER]On November 17, 2006, the parties filed a Rule 12(b) and (f) motion to dismissal.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed on March 15, 2007, and the parties engaged in settlement negotiations with the 18 assistance of the Coleman Special Master.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, 2007, the parties agreed to a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2011, the parties appealed the decision of the three judge court to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed the decision.

gold_sents: In 2014, Disability Rights Florida filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain inmates with mental illness at Dade Correctional Institution had been subject to torture, beatings, verbal harassment and food deprivation in violation of their Eighth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that these inmates had received insufficient care in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Rehabilitation Act. Disability Rights Florida requested declaratory and injunctive relief to deem these practices unlawful and unconstitutional, and assurance that such practices would not continue.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement which required improved conditions for prisoners and ran through November 2017.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent litigation in this case resulted from its consolidation with a related civil rights case seeking monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]That portion of the litigation settled for $4.5 million in 2018.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 14, 2014, the Plaintiff filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on behalf of persons with mental illness confined by the State of Florida and their families.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated the Rehabilitation Act and Title II by failing to provide adequate treatment and services to those confined.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a private settlement agreement in May 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case would be dismissed with prejudice on May 31, 2017 if no material breach of the agreement had occurred and the parties could not reach an agreement regarding reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2017, the parties filed a joint motion for administrative closure of the case to allow time for the implementation of the settlement agreement through negotiation or mediation.[SENTMARKER]The Court dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Parties agreed to extend the date by which Plaintiff is required to dismiss or re-open the case by six months with all other terms of the Agreement remaining unchanged.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to pay the Plaintiff reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses.

gold_sents: Deaf inmate at the Georgia Department of Corrections filed lawsuit for injunctive relief in the form of communication aids and damages for pain and suffering.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following a show cause order from the judge suggesting that case should be consolidated with a nearly identical case.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, a blind inmate at Georgia's Central State Prison filed a lawsuit against the Georgia Department of Corrections (GDOC) alleging that the GDOC violated his rights under the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RLUIPA) by failing to provide him with auxiliary aids and services at important meetings and events while under GDOC's control and supervision.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide the blind inmate with American Sign Language (ASL) interpreters and other auxiliary aids.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to stay discovery pending consideration of their motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On February 16, 2017, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 22, 2013, the U.S.[SENTMARKER]Food and Drug Administration approved a new direct acting antiviral (DAA) treatment for Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a serious and communicable disease that can cause severe liver scarring, liver damage, cancer, and death.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, the Missouri Department of Social Services and the Missouri HealthNet, denied coverage for medically necessary treatment for some Medicaid enrollees with HCV because of the defendants' arbitrary and improper policies that restrict treatment only to the sickest beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this suit under Title XIX of the Social Security Act against the defendants under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Medicaid Fraud and Abuse Act (MFA) in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants from requiring three months of negative drug and alcohol screens prior to submitting requests for DAA approval.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs more than $1 million in damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of the FDA's approval process for the new DAA treatment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Four incarcerated women alleged that their First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights were violated by being housed in the same facilities as transgender women.[SENTMARKER]After years of litigation, the claims were eventually dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 12, 2018, three female inmates of the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the Northern District Of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the BOP's policy of transferring male inmates to the same facilities that house female inmates violated their right to bodily privacy and the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.[SENTMARKER]Act) and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were subjected to cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eight Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 25, 2017, the court ordered that the case be dismissed pending the resolution of ongoing settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2018, the court returned the case to active status.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to negotiate a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: This case was filed by a trans woman incarcerated in a men's prison in Washington State on September 5, 2017 in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleges that the blanket policy in the Washington Department of Correction denying prisoners access to gender affirming surgery amounts to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]She is represented by the ACLU, and is seeking injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a preliminary settlement agreement on March 20, 2020, and proceedings were stayed for 180 days in an attempt to implement the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 27, 2017, a transgender female inmate, CORR CRONIN LLP, filed a civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Washington state department of corrections, alleging that the department's policy banning gender confirmation surgery for all inmates violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' policy was a blanket ban on gender reassignment surgery, precluding surgery without any consideration for medical necessity.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiff with medically necessary treatment for her gender dysphoria, including allowing her to use women's undergarments and other feminizing methods, and that the court would dismiss the case with prejudice once the terms of the settlement were satisfied.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on April 15, 2019.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 15, 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Western district of Washington on behalf of indigent persons charged with crimes in the municipal courts of the City of Mt Vernon and Burlington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating the constitutional rights of the class by systematically failing to provide assistance of counsel to the defendants, thereby violating both the federal 20 and state constitutions.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to extend the duration of the contract by two years to 2 December 31, 2012 and to pay the plaintiffs for reasonable attorney's fees from the other party.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 5, 2011 and the parties entered a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs would be reimbursed for reasonable attorneys' fees in the event of any litigation.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 19, 2018, CNN's White House correspondent, Jim Acosta, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Washington against the White House, the Secret Service, and President Donald Trump.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' decision to revoke Acosta's press credentials violated his First Amendment rights and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The White House had not informed CNN and Acosta that his credentials were revoked in advance of the revocation.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, 2018, the defendants prohibited Acosta from fully covering the President on a trip to Paris to mark the centennial of the end of the First World War.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction against the defendants on November 19, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: When mass protests against police violence were exempted from New York’s COVID-19 gathering restrictions, but congregational worship continued to be prohibited, two Catholic priests and three Orthodox Jews brought this lawsuit, alleging that New York officials were discriminating against people of faith.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 26, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2020, a group of religious organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Judge's Northern District Court in New York, alleging that the New York State Attorney General's Office and Mayor de Blasio violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights to freedom of exercise, speech, assembly, and expressive association, and their Fourteenth amendment right to equal protection.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunctive relief, and the parties agreed to a final injunctive order to allow the plaintiffs to file an appeal.[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2020, the plaintiffs filed an application for a temporary restraining order (TRO) Dkt No. 7.[SENTMARKER]In their most recent filing, plaintiffs sought an order restraining and enjoining the defendants from enforcing any gathering limits to outdoor religious gatherings; and (2) from imposing any limitations on indoor gathering... for religious gatherings in parity.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 1970, a group of African-American students in the Detroit public schools filed a lawsuit against the Detroit Board of Education, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, local and state officials, and the Detroit Federation of Teachers alleging intentional racial segregation.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Detroit School District was segregated on the basis of race and ordered the parties to submit plans to desegregate the district.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the District Court for an expedited trial on the merits.[SENTMARKER]On June 12, 1973, a divided Court of Appeals, sitting en banc, vacated in part, and remanded for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The District Court ruled that plaintiffs were not entitled to preliminary injunctive relief and declined to rule on the constitutionality of Act 48.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Sixth Circuit sustained the district court's denial of plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction but held that portions of the Act 48 were unconstitutional and at the same time ordered that the Governor and the Attorney General remain as parties to the litigation.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 1986, the Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
